PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to today's March quarter national accounts figures, which show that private investment has collapsed to its lowest level in five years; our net foreign liabilities have jumped to almost $200 billion; exports of goods and services have slumped by almost 2 per cent; and overall growth was a negligible 0.6 per cent for the quarter. In light of these facts, and particularly the collapse in investment, does the Government still believe, if it ever did, that Australia will achieve the economic growth rate of 4 3/4 per cent forecast for 1992-93 in its `One Nation-One Job' statement?

—The national accounts figures released today show that we have had three consecutive quarters of growth since the economy bottomed in the middle of last year. Those three quarters of growth amount to 1.5 per cent. These moderate growth figures are expected at the start of a recovery phase. As I said in a debate in the Senate last week, that was largely the pattern of behaviour in coming out of the previous recession, although this recession, of course, has been longer. I also made the point—
—There is no end in sight.

—Yes, there is an end in sight. If that is unpalatable to Senator Panizza, I am sorry about it, but there is an end in sight. Senator Short, of course, I think quite properly, concentrated on the investment side in particular, and the investment figures are disappointing, but they are not inconsistent with the change in the pattern of growth. Investment is always a lagged indicator, as is employment. Business investment will turn around in response to the pick-up in demand, helped by the One Nation statement measures and by the low interest rates and low inflation rate. It will also, of course, be helped by the rising corporate profits reported in the national accounts which confirm the corporate profit figures released by the ABS, I think, earlier this week.
—They were down.
—No, corporate gross operating surplus rose 2.9 per cent and the corporate profit share rose to 14.6 per cent.
—Not when you take account of tax and interest.
—The honourable senator can take account of anything he wants, but that is the measure.
—But—
—Order! Senator Short, you have asked the question.

—Finding some statistics unpalatable because he is buoyant with gloom and dedicated to catastrophe, Senator Short decides he will change the measure which is normally used—and that is very convenient. There are always arguments of convenience advanced by the Opposition in relation to these matters, and that is another one by way of interjection.

PARA.TAB: The Government welcomes the publication of the national accounts figures. They do show that the economy has returned to growth, albeit slow growth. There are a number of indicators which suggest that that growth picture will improve and that the economy is well on the way to coming out of recession. In respect of investment, let me say again that the corporate profits picture, the interest rate and inflation figure all set the scene for what is normally a lagged performance indicator, that is, business investment.

Nobody would throw his hat in the ring about the speed of recovery, but there has been a good, sustained recovery over the last three quarters which will improve in the next three quarters, and I suppose that is what Senator Short is worried about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the Minister has totally failed to answer my question, which asked whether the Government still believes that the 4.75 per cent growth rate for next year is achievable. Given his quite obvious refusal to endorse that fairies at the bottom of the garden growth rate forecast for next year, will he now come clean with the Senate and the Australian public and acknowledge that the unfunded spending proposals in the voodoo economics `One Nation-One Job' statement are even more unachievable than they were from the outset?

—I have refused to acknowledge that on a number of occasions. Certainly, with the publication of these national accounts figures and the other statistics which have been published this week, Senator Short is unlikely to get me to do it now, and I do not.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Although it has nothing to do directly with APPM, there are some interesting comparisons. Is the Minister aware of a workplace agreement developed at Kimberly-Clarke Mills based on wage increases in return for improvements in productivity? Can the Minister advise honourable senators whether this agreement is proof that the present industrial relations system can produce in terms of workplace productivity and cooperative employer-employee relationships all that its critics claim that it cannot do?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —This is some industrial relations good news.
—Look at these articles.

—The employees at Kimberly-Clarke's Lonsdale plant in South Australia—which is a high technology plant manufacturing a range of goods including, Senator Newman may be interested to know, disposable nappies—have now reached a workplace agreement. It is a good example of innovative workplace agreements being reached within the existing industrial relations system—a system that we will modify soon with the approval of the Senate to encourage further this type of agreement.

PARA.TAB: The Amalgamated Footwear and Textile Workers Union and the management of Kimberly-Clarke have cooperated in developing an agreement which provides for significant improvements in productivity at the Lonsdale plant. It arose out of close consultation and joint decision at all levels of the enterprise. It was praised by Deputy President Riordan of the Industrial Relations Commission when he described it as something exceptional and highly commendable and added, `I congratulate the parties to the agreement and hope that their cooperative attitude will last for their mutual benefit well into the future'.

This is a high technology plant. It is a plant in which, under the terms of this agreement, there will be semi-autonomous work groups formed. They will be multi-skilled and they will operate the plant in close consultation with management over the managerial decisions which will ensure, we believe, a high quality output from the plant. There is a heavy emphasis on skill development, workers working as a team and ensuring that all workers in the team have the same level of skills. The agreement will provide for annualised salaries. It will incorporate an element that compensates for overtime and shift premiums and ensure that this plant—a 24-hour continuous shiftwork plant in which employees work in 12-hour shifts two days on and two nights on, then four days off—works very efficiently.

The outcome of this agreement is that there will be a productivity jump at the Kimberly-Clarke plant. Management will be able to market its products competitively, here and overseas, in a way in which it will be able to secure and expand its position in the market. Its work force will have opportunities for greater skilling and better career prospects.

This is an important development. It is a good demonstration of how our system of industrial relations works. Those sorts of agreements, unfortunately, would be put in jeopardy if the Opposition's industrial relations approach ever had a chance to gain root because the essential trust and confidence between management and workers this sort of agreement promotes would not be present in the Opposition's approach. Senator Aulich, in asking me this question, referred to APPM. All I can say about APPM is that that is a sneak preview of what the Opposition's industrial relations policies will produce in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Why did the Government make export market development grants totalling half a million dollars over the 10 months to September 1990 to Mr Noel Ling, the proprietor of a number of English language educational institutions, mainly for Chinese students, that have since closed through bankruptcy? Is this the Mr Noel Ling who has not repaid any of his debts to the Commonwealth, which is currently suing him for $8m, arising from losses suffered by overseas students who were unable to obtain visas to Australia after paying their tuition fees and who, in March 1990, lent $281,979.95 to Mr Gregory Symons, who was also involved in a notorious education scam? Given that the Government was aware of the Chinese student education problem in early 1990, why was Mr Ling paid two export market development grants of $200,000 each in May and September 1990 while he was generating a huge loss to the Commonwealth, or are such considerations inappropriate when the Government is handing out export market development grants to the mates of mates?

—I am advised that three EMDG payments have been paid to Mr Ling, and this information has been given to the Opposition. One grant of $139,835 was for the 1987-88 grant year and that was paid in December 1989. The second grant of $200,000 was for the 1988-89 grant year and that was paid in May 1990. The third grant of $200,000 was for the 1989-90 grant year and that was paid in September 1990.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that there is no documentation held in Austrade's EMDG files or, so far as I am aware, anywhere else in the Government system which suggests that Mr Ling had any contact or relationship with Mr Symons. I do not deny that there may have been some such relationship of the kind to which Senator Baume has adverted, but there is no documentation to that effect and I presume, as a result, no knowledge of any such relationship. One is, of course, constrained on giving specific information in any detailed fashion as to the nature of these grants and what they were for. I am able to say here, as elsewhere, some negative things about what they were not for.

Certainly, I am advised that Mr Ling has never applied for, so far as Austrade records are concerned, or never received EMDG moneys relating to either the Marshall Islands or business migration schemes. As I have said on other occasions, business migration schemes are expressly excluded from the statutory definition in the schedule of the Act as to what constitutes an eligible service. I am also able to say, so far as Austrade documentation is concerned, that Austrade certainly had no representations made to it on Mr Ling's behalf by Senator Richardson or any other parliamentarian. Again, for what it is worth, the file discloses no reference at all to Senator Richardson. I make that as a negative statement, but that is true universally of all these matters in respect of which allegations have been made.

Might I say something general about the EMDG system, because it is constantly misunderstood—whether wilfully or otherwise, I am not sure—how this system operates. It has been going as a statutory scheme since back in the mid-1970s. It is designed, of course, to assist businesses with their pre-export preparation for overseas market entry. The scheme is administered by Austrade and, as such, has been part of my departmental umbrella since November last year, and only since then.

There are something like 2,000 claims annually—that is the expected number for this year, 1991-92—at a total cost of $134m. The scheme is essentially self-administering through sharply defined statutory criteria. Forms are submitted addressing the particular detailed questions which are spelt out in the documentation. There is an investigating officer who looks at each such application when it is made and tests the documentation against the criteria on his checklist. Where the documentation appears to be insufficient or inadequate, then that is followed up, often by a site visit to the business in question, if that is necessary to produce the result.

As we have said before, the criteria for the administration of this are not qualitative and not discretionary. They do not base themselves on any assessment of the viability of the business in question, nor do they make judgments about the quality of the particular export enterprise, whether relating to a service or a sale of goods in question. Payments are made after the event, not before, and are based on detailed documentation. There are statutory criteria limiting the amounts that can be paid and the number of times one can come back and dip at the well.

We have said before that the criteria and the system under which the legislation operates are not such as to lend themselves to representations, to manipulation, by even the most evil-minded perpetrator of such frauds upon the Commonwealth. It is a straightforward scheme that is largely self-administering and, to that extent, there really does not seem to be any foundation for any of the aura of smelliness or fishiness that, with the utmost respect, Mr President, the Opposition is trying to generate about this or any other payment.

It has to be understood that this is the context in which this system operates when one is exploring—as I am quite happy to do now or in the debate afterwards this afternoon—any particular query that is made about any particular application. I am constrained by statutory criteria from being more explicit about what the money is actually spent for, but I am not constrained from uttering some negatives about what it was not spent for or applied for. I will be happy to do that in such a way as to get rid of most of the concerns that seem to have been expressed on this subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Opposition understands quite well the statutory requirements. What is intriguing in this situation is that the left hand of the Government—or should I say in this context the right wing of the Government—is owed money by someone and in fact is suing that person at this stage, while at the same time another wing of the Government is paying out money to him or her. I ask the Minister: are any checks made in this extraordinary organisation to ensure that that situation does not obtain and that the Commonwealth is not handing out money at the same time as it is suing someone for money? In view of the Government's decision to refund money to overseas students who have paid tuition fees to Australian institutions but who were subsequently unable to obtain visas to enter Australia, I ask: what proportion of the total amount outstanding that the Government has been unable to collect from people like Mr Ling is made up of Mr Ling and his associate organisations and what is the total outstanding?
—It is not in that portfolio, and you know it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray has answered the latter question for me. I will be happy to pass on the question to the appropriate Minister, but obviously I do not have the capacity to answer that. The problem is the way the way the EMDG Act is presently cast—and this was approved by the Opposition without, to my knowledge, any question or complaint about this particular statutory language. Section 12(2) of the EMDG Act deems:

ANSWER.PARA: Where the Commission determines that a claimant has a grant entitlement, the Commission shall pay to the claimant a grant equal to the amount of the grant entitlement so determined.

So once a determination is made, Austrade is required by law to pay the grant to the individual concerned, the trustee, the receiver or the liquidator for the benefit of creditors, if that is the particular situation that is involved.

PARA.TAB: That is the statutory obligation. If there are any deficiencies in the statutory scheme, there is a reasonable opportunity to draw attention to those in the course of the debate on the legislation itself. As far as I am aware, Senator Baume has not taken advantage of that opportunity. If he wants to draw attention to some perceived policy inadequacy, he is welcome to do so. He has done so. That is something that can be pursued and Mr Kerin has indicated a willingness to do that.

As I have said in this place, and as Mr Kerin has said publicly, the difficulty is that once the nature of the scheme is changed from being largely an automatically administered, self-administered system, the administration costs involved will be dramatically increased. Whether the trade-off is worth it in order to get the kind of satisfaction that members of the Opposition want about other current debts owed to the Commonwealth by the person in question, or from the point of view of any other of the criteria that is troubling them, is a matter for policy argument. It is not a matter on which the Government needs to feel in the slightest bit defensive, given the Opposition's embrace of this scheme which, in the past, has been total.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Defence familiar with a recent report in the Australian and a subsequent press release by the Opposition defence spokesman, Mr Downer, that suggest that the Minister and his office have been implicated in a proposal that would effectively breach Government policy on an Australian industry involvement in contracts? Is the Minister in a position to respond to such suggestions?
—I said last night in an explanation to the Senate that I had a certain prescience that a colleague may ask this question today. Once again, the prediction has come true.
—You forgot to take it from him.

—No, I did not. The situation is that Techway did approach my office to say it had difficulty in communicating with the Department of Defence over the contract. As a result, a meeting was convened between the Department, Techway and a member of my staff. At that meeting, a variety of discussions were held as to how to assess Australian-New Zealand content in these computer contracts. It was agreed that, as there had been differences between the two groups, we would ask DAS to do an audit of it and basically abide by its decision. The decision that day was to do that and that is what has subsequently occurred.
—DAS was supposed to be doing it all the time.

—No. DAS does it on a three-monthly basis, not on a day-to-day basis. In these specific difficulties, DAS was asked to do it. Subsequently, one of the officers involved in this process wrote a memo which disagreed with our decisions. His division head immediately made his view known that he did not agree with the memo. When it was sent to my office, my staff member also made it quite clear that we did not agree with the contents of that memo. It should be noted that, when that memo was leaked, there was no signature from me, any of my staff or the division head approving, noting or otherwise that memo.

PARA.TAB: It is on the basis of that memo and that memo only that Mr Downer and others have alleged that people in my office have tried to cover up and do nothing about this issue when the truth is directly the opposite. I intervened to make sure that an audit was done to make sure that the contractual obligations were being met. If we did not have someone who just shoots from the hip and does not investigate anything, this issue would not have forced what will probably end up being legal action for defamation based on that press release.

I have taken the opportunity yesterday and, again, more extensively today to refute what Mr Downer has said. I hope that he would at least bother to contact my office and get the facts before he puts out these polemical, rhetorical and stupid press releases in which he cannot even get his grammar right.
Senator Walters interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that Senator Walters try reading one. It is very difficult. He uses the word `circumnavigate' instead of `circumvent'. He has issued press releases accusing me of reducing the number of battalions from four to six—I do not know how that is done. He has put out 11 press releases, but the library can track down only eight because he cheats and puts different numbers on them to make it look as though he is more active than otherwise.

PARA.TAB: I take the argy-bargy of all that in fairly good grace except, and only except, when implications are made that my staff have interfered with contractual relationships.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has your Department been reviewing it all this time and has DAS?

—Senator Newman can get up and ask whatever question she likes. I happen to be answering Senator Loosley's question, not hers. If she wants to get up and defend her colleague who puts out this sort of trash in press releases, she can get to her feet and do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to claims that Papua New Guinean troops killed hundreds of Bougainvillians in the Wakunai area during Independence Day celebrations on 18 May, including by the aerial strafing of villages using Australian Nomad aircraft, and to yesterday's denial by the PNG Government that any killings occurred. Given that the person who it is claimed broadcast the news of the alleged killings, Bishop John Zale, is a respected and prominent local figure, what steps has the Australian Government taken to independently check the allegations? In particular, can the Government ascertain whether an Aita village leader, Mr Kapuito, and his family were killed as is claimed? Given that the PNG Government and the BRA have proved to be unreliable witnesses in their public relations war, does the Government accept that independent sources of information about events on the island are essential?

—I am aware of claims that have been carried by Radio Free Bougainville concerning a possible incident near Wakunai on 18 May. The PNG Defence Force has dismissed these allegations as a fabrication and villagers from the area who have been recently quoted in the Port Moresby Post Courier have said that no such incident occurred. There is certainly no evidence to suggest that a Nomad aircraft was involved. Indeed, Radio Free Bougainville is alleged to have said that a PNGDF Arava aircraft circled Arawa on 31 May. In fact, a photograph accompanying the Port Moresby article portrays a machine gun being fired from an Arava aircraft, not a Nomad as reported. Papua New Guinea purchased these aircraft some years ago from Israel. These are straws in the wind. One is not able to give a definitive response to this, but at least in that respect the report is clearly inaccurate.

PARA.TAB: I have no precise details on whether Mr Kapuito and his family were killed in the incident. Given the lack of substance in other claims made by Radio Free Bougainville on this and other occasions, I think one should approach that report with a great degree of caution until it is confirmed. It is the case that Radio Free Bougainville has been very active in making propaganda claims over the last few weeks. Certainly, Bishop Zale has been particularly active in making a number of broadcasts inciting local resistance to the PNGDF.

A further difficulty is that the BRA, by destroying facilities on Bougainville, by seizing and burning the Cosmaris—the vessel carrying medical supplies—by refusing to allow medical supplies to be distributed from north Bougainville to the centre and by a number of its other actions, bears a very heavy responsibility for the current conditions which exist there.

The bottom line on all of this is that it is very difficult for the Australian Government to assess these kinds of reports, to make judgments about their accuracy. Essentially, they are internal matters for the PNG Government to resolve. Certainly, we believe that the Bougainville dispute can be settled only by the Papua New Guineans themselves and, hopefully, through the process of negotiation. Once again, on behalf of the Australian Government, I encourage all parties to refrain from violence and open up a dialogue so that this matter can be properly, sensibly and peacefully resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the reports that the European Community has agreed to cut farm subsidies by up to 29 per cent and meetings being held between the United States and the European Community on cuts in farm subsidies. Can the Minister inform the Senate about, first, the progress in those talks and, secondly, the prospect for a speedy and successful outcome in the Uruguay Round?

—I am indebted to Senator Jones for asking me this question. It is another substantive issue about which we have not heard a peep out of the Opposition over the course of the last two weeks. The contrast is pretty stark between the sorts of issues which are fascinating those opposite and those which are of real importance to this country. I will let their consciences speak for themselves.

PARA.TAB: The decisions taken by the EC on 21 May about CAP reform are a very welcome sign that the EC is at last willing to change the direction of its agricultural support policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —A judicial inquiry will get you.

—At least so far as cereals are concerned—I know how fascinated Senator Walters is on the subject of cereal—the EC is moving away from delivering the bulk of its support by ripping off consumers through high domestic prices to now greater use of direct payments to farmers.

PARA.TAB: However, we have to caution that this is not the millennium; the EC is continuing to provide absurdly high levels of support to its farmers. Where the EC is cutting prices—in particular, cereals, but also, to a lesser extent, beef—farmers are being largely compensated by way of direct payments. Still, the key issue is whether the way that support is being doled out will, in fact, lead to significantly lower levels of production. If it does, the reforms are worth while; if it does not, we have not achieved anything. The full details of how the programs will be applied are not yet available and it will also require quite a deal of economic analysis to estimate the likely market impact.

With cereals, for larger farmers to obtain subsidies to compensate for lower prices, they will have to set aside under the scheme 15 per cent of their crop area. That will restrain production and it will have a positive effect on the market but no-one is yet in a position to say by how much. For beef, while there are some limits in terms of numbers of animals, to the direct subsidies that farmers will be paid, it is again not clear at this stage whether that will be effective in reducing production. For dairy, the production quota system is being maintained but substantial reductions in production will be required in the future to have a big impact on the world market.

Pressure on the EC, both bilaterally and through the Uruguay Round, especially from the US and the Cairns Group, has obviously been an important contributing factor in getting the EC to move on CAP reform, as is its own dawning realisation at last that the crippling cost of the CAP simply had to be dealt with. Australia made its own contribution to this process through, it will be recalled, the widespread distribution of the pamphlet Are you paying too much?, which did have a quite significant press impact in Europe.

An important positive element of the decisions, especially those on cereals, is that they do potentially open the way now for breaking the stalemate on agriculture in the Uruguay Round. The EC has been blocking the negotiations, particularly over the questions of how to treat domestic support arrangements and quantitative disciplines on export subsidies. Now that the EC has begun to move on this, our hope and expectation is that the Europeans will be able to show the flexibility that is required to accept an outcome to the agriculture negotiations, consistent at least with the principles of the Dunkel text tabled last year, which have been accepted by the Cairns Group.

As to the current state of those negotiations, one is still poised uneasily between optimism and pessimism as to the current state of play. Further bilateral negotiations at ministerial level took place between the United States and the EC in Washington on 27 May. My understanding is that those negotiations were constructive in tone but further efforts will be needed before solutions to outstanding issues can be found. Flexibility from the EC is still the critical element required to bring these negotiations to a successful and early conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I remind the Minister that on 4 March I asked a question concerning Senator Richardson's proposed visit to Taiwan, which I am told was cancelled at the direction of the Minister or his office. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether Senator Richardson acquainted him with the purpose of his proposed visit or sought his assistance or that of his office with any of the arrangements or introductions for that visit? Was the Minister, or is he now, aware of whether Senator Richardson's visit, which I understand included a stopover in Hong Kong on 21 and 22 March, was designed to coincide with a visit to Hong Kong or Taiwan by Mr Symons, particularly as the official visit was shown as being to the United States, the United Kingdom and France?

—Senator Richardson is only one of a number of Ministers who have expressed informally an interest, if the occasion arose and if Government policy permitted, in making a visit to Taiwan. The particular context in which each of these discussions has been held with me has invariably been that of the pursuit of the Minister's particular ministerial role and responsibilities. I can certainly recall nothing different in the very brief and passing conversation that I had, to the extent that I can recollect it, with Senator Richardson on this subject.

PARA.TAB: They were always simply exploratory discussions about this, with Senator Richardson or any other Minister, because the position remains, and will remain—obviously, until altered—that the Government does not permit visits to be made to Taiwan by Ministers, either in their official or unofficial capacity, because of the difficulties that are obviously associated with ensuring the compatibility of that with our present China policy.

This is an issue that is under constant review because relationships are evolving in the region. In particular, the relationship between Taiwan and the People's Republic of China is clearly evolving and maturing, as are Taiwan's commercial relationships, at least, with a lot of other countries, including ourselves. So this is an issue which the Government is currently looking very closely at as part of our ongoing review of Taiwan policy. But for the moment our policy remains quite firm in the way that I described it and was communicated as such by me to Senator Richardson. I did not enter into any further discussion with Senator Richardson or anybody else as to why they might be wanting to go there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Evans did not mention whether it was the normal practice to go to the United Kingdom, the United States and France via Hong Kong.

—A lot of people do that in order to break their journey. It is a logical and obvious place to break a long plane journey to Europe and to have an overnight stop in the same time zone. If I had any time I would do that myself, rather than take these long-haul flights. I make no judgment about that. Besides that, on a number of occasions of those stopovers, it is obvious that Senator Richardson transacted some very useful business on behalf of the Government, for which I thank him and congratulate him. It is a damned sight more constructive a role than has been played by anyone on the other side of politics for as long as I can remember.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health inform the Senate of the recent allocations to Queensland under the Medicare incentives package? What are these allocations for? Along with the grants announced for South Australia last month, do they indicate the Government's commitment to the hospital system and patient care?

—I think Senator Crowley must be referring to the $7.8m provided to Queensland under the Medicare incentives package very recently. Indeed, that package is a very important part of our strategy to ensure that Australian hospitals provide a very effective and efficient service to those who require care within them. It will be used in a manner highly compatible with the objective of providing that very good care. The sum of $2m will be used to increase the availability of day surgery procedures—this will be of interest to Senator Herron—in nine Queensland hospitals.

PARA.TAB: Currently, about 25 per cent of all hospital procedures in Australian hospitals are undertaken on a day only basis. It is a widely held view that, ultimately, almost half of all hospital procedures could be day only. This component of the funding to Queensland will ensure that the incidence of day only surgery will continue to move in the right direction.

There are obviously significant advantages from the point of view of the efficient use of hospital resources. Also, it can enable patients to recover within the home environment rather than in the hospital. This theme is also illustrated by the fact that more than $5.7m will be directed towards increasing post-acute services that allow the early discharge of terminally ill patients. Fifteen hospitals in Queensland will benefit from this package.

This shows that the Government is committed to the quality of care within our public hospital system in a way which is immediately to be contrasted with the proposals of the Opposition which, as Senator Herron will know, will leave public hospitals in the States denuded of funds. Because the Opposition proposes to reduce the expenditure to the States by 5 per cent, it must reduce the funds put into public hospitals, and the Opposition hopes to fill the gap with private insurance premiums. That is the way the Opposition intends to fill the gap—without any improvement in services.

So what we have here is a great boost from Medicare for Queensland hospitals. It is consistent with the Government's strategy of upgrading the provision of good health services based on a good public hospital system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to my question to him last Thursday relating to trips by Senator Richardson to Hong Kong and China, in which I asked what assistance was provided by his Department for each of those trips, and to Senator Evans's answer after Question Time yesterday. Is it not also a fact that the Australian Consul-General in Hong Kong gave Senator Richardson an economic briefing on Australian investment in Hong Kong on 25 September 1990? Why did Senator Evans not advise the Senate of this briefing yesterday? What was the substantive nature of this briefing? Can the Minister guarantee that the briefing provided by the Consul-General did not relate in any way to the business interests in China or Hong Kong of either Multiplex or Mr Greg Symons? Will the Minister table all documents relating to this briefing, including briefing notes provided to Senator Richardson, minutes of the meeting between the Consul-General and Senator Richardson, and any communications between the Minister's Department or the Minister's office and the Consul-General in relation to the briefing?

—I am not aware of whether there was any economic briefing given by the Consul-General in Hong Kong on 25 September or, if there was and there was a record of it, why I was not made aware of it in giving the answer I did yesterday. Again, the substantive content of any such briefing seems to be entirely a matter of speculation and, on the face of it, speculative hypothetical fabrication by Senator Alston of exactly the same kind that we have heard from him on numerous occasions here. If he has any substantive basis for suggesting there was something remotely improper about that, let him give us the evidence for it rather than just putting semi-prejudicial material on the public record in the way he now has. I will seek further information on this, and any relevant documentation that is capable of being tabled consistent with confidentiality provisions I will be happy to table.

—Mr President, I take a point of order and invite you to ask the Minister to withdraw the disparagement contained in the answer. The question merely asked: why was the briefing not mentioned yesterday, what was the substance of the briefing and did it relate to Mr Symons or Multiplex? To then proceed to slander me across the chamber, in my submission to you, Mr President, should warrant your inviting the Minister to withdraw that comment.
—In reply to the point of order, I cannot hear every word that is said at Question Time. I heard `speculative' and `hypothetical'. I do not think they were out of order.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. What action has been taken by the Government in relation to the marketing of infant formulas in Australia? Does Australia now comply with the WHO instrument designed to prevent infant mortality and morbidity as a result of the inappropriate marketing and use of such formulas?

—Senator Giles has raised a very important health question. Quite clearly, a society can very quickly change its culture and its outlook in relation to breast feeding, which is quite clearly the best, most nutritious and most healthy way in which to feed young infants. Indeed, with high pressure advertising, it can be the case that young mothers are diverted into using infant formulas in an inappropriate way as a substitute for breast feeding rather than as a last resort or an alternative when that particular method of feeding is not available.

PARA.TAB: Senator Giles also mentions the World Health Organisation, which has published an international code on the marketing of breast milk substitutes or infant formulas. It is extremely important that in Australia we have agreement from the producers, the distributors and the importers of these particular substitutes in order to ensure that advertisements do not occur in the marketplace in a way which, as I say, can mislead young women into adopting a less nutritious method of feeding their children.

Over a couple of months late last year, all interested parties were gathered together by the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs in order to negotiate an agreement. Indeed, the chief executives of five or six importers or distributors gathered in Melbourne on 21 May to sign an agreement, a document witnessed by Mr Howe and me. That was on the eleventh anniversary of the adoption by the World Health Organisation of the code which governs the marketing of these infant formulas. Those chief executives of the Australian manufacturers and importers agreed not to advertise these products and not to engage in practices which, as I say, could lead to a distortion of choices that ought to be made purely on health grounds by women in relation to the feeding, particularly the breast feeding, of their infants.

This new agreement must, of course, conform to the requirements of the Trade Practices Act. For that reason it is now being submitted. But I am quite sure that the Trade Practices Commission will be very sympathetic to the public interest in respect of this matter and will give a very good hearing to the argument that this agreement ought to be maintained in the market place. I hope that the TPC, favourably disposed to the public interest argument here, will endorse this very important agreement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to a speech he made in the Senate on 24 August 1982—
—It was a great one. I remember it well.
—I hope that Senator Evans does too. In that speech, Senator Evans said:

QUESTION.PARA: Negligence is totally incompatible with the doctrine of ministerial responsibility which is assumed to exist, which is claimed to exist, in any Westminster system of government.

I also refer to a speech by his former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, on 27 October 1988, where he outlined the grounds upon which Ministers should resign. He said that a Minister should resign if there had been a significant act of wrongdoing or `omission' or the Minister `obviously should have known, and done something' about a particular matter. I ask the Minister: does he stand by his and his former Prime Minister's remarks?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do, absolutely. The concept of ministerial responsibility, however, only begins when something goes wrong and there is a question about who takes the blame for it. That is the context.

PARA.TAB: In the circumstances surrounding the implication against me—a breach of ministerial responsibility, against my own principles—it is not at all obvious that anything went wrong in any ordinary sense of the English language, and I will explain that point in a moment. Nor is it the case that anyone is to blame for such events as did occur. If Senator Hill is talking about my ministerial responsibility—and I presume he is—the question at issue is whether I should have been told about a possible contact that was made between Mr Symons and our Washington Embassy back in April of this year at a time when, it is reasonably clear, my Department knew of it and passed the information to my office.

I want to make clear that there was nothing inherently wrong about such a contact being set up or occurring in the first place. It is not as though there had been obvious maladministration, mis-expenditure of public money, a breach of public trust, a criminal action or a default of any other kind. The matter in issue is simply whether I had been told about a possible contact occurring. There is nothing inherently wrong in such a contact occurring. In the light of all the information that has been revealed since then, no-one's judgment has been altered on that. There was certainly nothing wrong about the way in which the matter was handled by the Washington Embassy when the particular contact did take place which was foreshadowed as being possible by the communication in question.

What went wrong that is a matter for which anyone should accept responsibility? The only thing that allegedly went wrong was a failure to communicate that particular information to me. Was that a blameworthy failure to communicate? I certainly did not regard my failure to be told of the particular detail in question as constituting any kind of blameworthy conduct on the part of my office, notwithstanding the calumnies that are being spread in that context. I did not see any neglect. I certainly did not see any culpable neglect of the kind for which someone should accept responsibility, query the Minister and query the staff member concerned.

I will go through the reasons why, because it is important to put these matters on the public record. To the extent that the communication in question, the one in April, was about the arrest which occurred in the Marshall Islands, and the reports of some phone contact with the Marshall Islands having been made by Senator Richardson—that was the way in which my senior adviser remembered the call in question—that was not about anything new as far as I was concerned or as far as he was concerned. That was simply confirming information—putting it into a different context—which I knew about and which my senior adviser knew about.

I know some people derive some nourishment from endlessly gossiping to each other, telling each other things they already know. I know lots of people who are like that, with nothing better to do. But I and my staff have better things to do than to tell each other—particularly across half the world—things that we already know. So to that extent, there was nothing blameworthy about the failure of communication.

The adviser in question manifestly did not recall the Washington reference, on his own testimony, which I do not doubt for a moment. Even if he had, it has to be understood and we have to appreciate, for God's sake, that if we are talking about wrongdoing, if we are talking about someone being blameworthy—whether it is a Minister on his behalf or anyone else—at that particular time there was nothing particularly significant about that piece of information which has everybody so excited subsequently.

Anyone could be forgiven for omitting to remember, or to pass on, a piece of information that was so inherently insignificant at the time. When it is remembered, and I wish to goodness I had remembered last week that this was the day in question, that the day in question, 6 April, was the very day that the assault took place on the Iranian Embassy—in a context which generated a huge amount of excitement in my particular office, with phone calls having to be made in and out all day long and, in fact, all hell breaking loose being a reasonable description of it, and in an environment where I was away and two other senior staff members were away—the fact that something slipped between the cracks in the way that this obviously did is even less obviously a matter for blame when directed to my staff or to anyone else.

The only reason that I even mentioned my failure to be advised about this particular matter was obviously because of the necessity to do so in order to explain why it was that I had not, in fact, misled the Senate when I said on 7 May that I had no knowledge of a particular contact or likely contact in Washington. I had no knowledge for all the reasons that are clearly now on the public record. The question of my knowledge was squarely in issue; it had to be established in order to put my credibility beyond doubt that I had not been the subject of any communication.

It is not a matter of blaming anyone; it is not a matter of wrongdoing by anyone; it is not a matter of any default or wrongdoing in the system such as should attract `responsibility' by anyone, let alone ministerial responsibility. There has been more nonsense, with the utmost respect, Mr President, spoken on the subject, written on the subject and broadcast on the subject of ministerial responsibility than any previous incident that I can recall in my 13 years in this place. I back away not one iota from what I said on the subject of ministerial responsibility in 1982 or at any other time. Those principles are clear, they are well understood, but they simply have no application in this case, and any fair minded person should be able to make that judgment for himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to today's Australian newspaper article headed, `PM backs ACTU pay claim'. I ask the Minister: does not this backing contradict and undermine one of the fundamental claims of proposed superannuation legislation; that is, that any levy on employers will be counted in future national wage cases?
—I saw the headline, I have not read the article and I certainly have not got any information on it. I will try to get information for Senator Kernot.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I just cannot accept from the Leader of the Government in the Senate that he is not talking about ACTU and superannuation in his conversations with the Treasurer and the Prime Minister. I am asking the Minister: will the levy be counted or will it not? Is it a case of this time and not next time? What can we believe on this fundamentally crucial issue?
—I am telling Senator Kernot that I have no information about what was said by the Prime Minister to the ACTU, and I will obtain it.
—Why didn't you get a briefing on it? Aren't you representing him?

—All these whiz kids opposite who have never done anything in their lives interject, `Aren't you this?' and `Aren't you that?'. They have never done anything in their lives except sit in Opposition, which they are doomed to do for the future. I will obtain an answer from the Prime Minister for Senator Kernot as soon as possible and I will give it to her.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. What penalties apply to limited liability companies and their directors who fail to submit their annual returns to the Australian Securities Commission on time? How late do they have to be before any action is taken?

—I understand that companies are required by the corporations law to lodge an annual return with the Australian Securities Commission, I think not later than some seven months after the end of the preceding financial year. There is a penalty, I think, of some $500 for failure to lodge an annual return. So that is the scope of it.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, failure to lodge within the statutory time period is something that does occur from time to time with respect to private companies. The ASC would normally issue a penalty notice; it would act in that way. That is all I can tell Senator Baume at the moment of the general way in which that section operates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In that case, could the Minister advise the Senate: what action will the Government be taking by way of fines or other measures against Euphron Pty Ltd—a company in which Mr Paul Keating and his family hold a 50 per cent interest costing $430,000—which has not yet filed its annual return for 1990-91 which was due on 31 January 1992, along with companies associated with the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd, in which Euphron is a shareholder, such as Olympia Refrigeration Sales Pty Ltd and Jensay Pty Ltd, both of which have not filed their returns with the ASC for the years ended 30 June 1989, 1990 and 1991? Will Mr Keating's family company, or did Mr Keating's family company, Pleuron Pty Ltd, have to pay the $500 penalty when it put in its return three months late on 24 April this year?

—Senator Baume has mentioned the names of several private companies. He said that some are family companies. I am not quite clear as to the extent to which it is said that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has a partial or a full interest in some of those companies.

PARA.TAB: In so far as any decisions are made for the levying of a penalty in relation to failure to lodge a return, that would be a matter properly and utterly within the competence and jurisdiction of the Australian Securities Commission. It would not be a matter for which the Government would wish to try to influence the Australian Securities Commission in any way either to favourably dispose it towards any particular company or, of course, to try to encourage it to levy a penalty. It is a matter entirely within the jurisdiction and discretion of the Australian Securities Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. The Minister will be aware of the major contribution made by carers, mainly women, who care for elderly and disabled family members at home. However, is the Minister aware that their entitlement to the domiciliary nursing care benefit has remained at $42 per fortnight since 1981? Will the Minister advise what steps have been taken to review the carers allowance to ensure that appropriate recognition is given to the economic value of women's work in caring for the nation's elderly and disabled?

—The fact is that the Government has taken a very real interest in the role of carers, particularly those who are relatives of aged and frail persons or those who have to take care of disabled young people within the family. Quite often, without in any way trying to indulge in stereotypes, clearly the carers are women who are caring for frail, aged partners or for perhaps disabled children who are growing older. They undertake a considerable burden on the part of those relatives, and we are a more compassionate society because such people at times undertake such burdensome duties.

PARA.TAB: But it is also a fact that there needs to be a government structure to help those carers. The home and community services program, of course, provides many services which help with respite care for the aged and which provide for home nursing, home help, food services, home maintenance and modification, and community transport. These are all of direct benefit to carers in so far as they relieve them of some of the duties which they would otherwise have to undertake.

The domiciliary nursing care benefit is not means tested; it is a benefit paid to carers of people who would otherwise be eligible for nursing home care. Senator Reynolds was quite right about the rate; I think it is $3 per day. That rate is being looked at in the review of the effectiveness of the domiciliary nursing care benefit. We must try to find the best ways possible to support carers and to recognise their contribution to the community. We are constantly reviewing the effectiveness of the various programs, particularly within the home and community care sector. Those are the programs that need to be taken into account when looking at the total picture of government support for carers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The One Nation statement reiterated a cryptic comment from last year's Budget that, in addition to employer financed superannuation, the Government will be giving consideration to using employee contributions and tax cuts to increase the total level of superannuation support by a further 3 per cent of earnings so that by the end of the decade virtually every employee will have savings equivalent to 12 per cent of his earnings. Could the Minister advise the mechanism by which this will be achieved? Does this mean that employees will have to pay 3 per cent of their earnings via PAYE-type deductions into a superannuation fund in lieu of 3 per cent of tax to the Government?
—I assure Senator Watson that I will speak to the Treasurer about that and get a quick answer on this issue.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

I now wish to add further to the answer I gave yesterday. However, payments will not be made on a blanket basis. Each client will have to apply and have his or her individual circumstances assessed. —I was asked a question yesterday by Senator Panizza about what had been done by the Department of Arts, territories, sports and environment—
—You have had a busy week.

—Yes, I have had a busy week, and a good one. Senator Panizza asked me to inquire as to what had been done to have the kit withdrawn from schools. I am advised by the Minister that the Department wrote to each school that was known to have been supplied with the kit and asked for the kit to be withdrawn. Senator Panizza wanted a kit. —Yesterday in Question Time, Senator Durack asked whether I, my office or my Department had been contacted by the Attorney-General about information relating to charges faced by Mr Symons in the Marshall Islands. I responded that I was aware of some consultation on consular aspects of this particular matter back in April but I said I was not aware of any more recent contact and promised to check that.
—Speak slower.

—I will have to speak really slowly so that Senator Boswell can understand it. I will try. I have checked and I am advised by my office and the relevant areas of my Department that no contact has taken place with the Attorney-General since the contact in April to which I have referred.

PARA.TAB: As to that particular contact, might I repeat for the record what I understand the Attorney-General has put down in the other place a few minutes ago, to the following effect. That action arose out of the Symons matter in the sense that the Marshalls' Attorney-General, Dennis McPhillips, had raised the possibility of a future extradition request by the Marshalls in that matter. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Short this day relating to the national accounts figures.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry to see Senator Button leaving the chamber. He might learn a little bit about his economy and national accounts statistics if he stayed. During Question Time, in response to my question about the March quarter national accounts, Senator Button claimed, amongst other things, that the profitability of business was rising in this country as shown in the March quarter national accounts. To illustrate that, he referred to one of the figures called the gross operating surplus of the business sector. What that figure omits to show—because it does not include it—is the interest and tax paid by the private sector on its gross earnings. As a measure of the ability of the corporate sector to make profits and to invest and reinvest, the gross operating surplus is a meaningless concept. The accurate concept is the net operating surplus which takes into account interest and tax paid by businesses.

PARA.TAB: On that basis, in the national accounts, the net operating surplus fell from $25 billion in the December quarter to $18.9 billion in the March quarter. I would think that that is one of the largest falls in net operating surplus ever recorded. The March figure is below even the figure for the September quarter 1991 of $20.6 billion.

In the Budget figures last year, the Budget statements showed a table giving the figures and a graph for the net operating surplus. That showed that as at June last year the net operating surplus of businesses in Australia was at the lowest level it had been since figures were first recorded a quarter of a century ago. There was some pick-up in the September and December quarters of this current financial year, but we have now had a huge plunge in that figure in the March quarter.

Other statistics contained in the national accounts figures for March confirm the figures I have just referred to. For example, company retained earnings, which is a very important source of savings and investment in Australia, collapsed from plus $2.1 billion in the December quarter to minus $2.2 billion in the March quarter. In other words, there was a dissavings by companies during that period and a major turnaround in their position of well over $4 billion. Similarly, in the March quarter, household savings collapsed and were down to $2.5 billion. That compares with $6.9 billion in the December quarter, which is a massive fall. Overall, national savings in the March quarter showed a minus figure of almost $500m compared with a plus figure of $1.6 billion in the December quarter, and even that historically was a very low level.

What those figures show—quite contrary to what Senator Button implied and indeed stated in his response to my question today—is that savings have collapsed in this country. The pick-up that had perhaps been starting to occur very tentatively in the September and December quarters of this financial year has turned around very strongly to a negative position in the March quarter. That reflects only one thing: that the business community and the household sector in Australia have lost confidence completely in this Government and have lost the wherewithal to save and invest.

Of course the business community will be neither able nor prepared to invest while the Party on the opposite side remains in power. Why would it? This Government has absolutely lost control of its economic policy processes. The Budget is totally out of control. We have had a deterioration in the fiscal position of the Commonwealth of almost $19 billion in the last two years alone, which is absolutely unprecedented in Australia's history. The implications of that for the year ahead and beyond are enormous in terms of the negative influences on the business community.

It is therefore no wonder that today Senator Button absolutely walked away from the `One Nation-One Job' growth forecast of 4 3/4 per cent for next year. He knows as well as us that that is an unachievable figure. Therefore, there is no way in the world that the growth prospects, spending proposals and all the other fairies-at-the-bottom-of-the-garden proposals that are contained in that statement can be achieved. It is unfortunate that Senator Button, in his response to my question today, chose to give such a misleading impression of the implications of the March quarter national accounts.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Michael Baume this day relating to the company Pleuron Pty Ltd and the Australian Securities Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The question put forward by Senator Michael Baume is really a continuing saga of the preferential treatment that seems to be handed out to Mr Keating and companies associated with him. On numerous occasions in the recent past I have drawn attention to the fact that Mr Keating failed to lodge his tax returns for 1985 and 1986. I read into the record of the hearing of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts the other day a copy of the letter written by Mr Cortese, the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation, to the Hon. P.J. Keating, MP, the then Treasurer and, of course, the boss of the Commissioner of Taxation, at his private address at Red Hill. I draw attention to the fact that it was such a nice, friendly little letter, which said:
The purpose of this letter is to draw your attention to the need for you to file your 1986 income tax return which is now outstanding.
As recently discussed your 1985 return is also well overdue.
I appreciate how busy you have been but I ask that you now give urgent attention to the filing of your returns especially that for the 1985 year.
Should you wish your return can be posted marked for attention:-
If you wish to deliver your return you could contact Ms Ellis on—
and the phone numbers are given—
or myself.
Your co-operation and early response would be appreciated.
I seek leave to table that letter.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point is that Senator Baume has pointed out to this chamber that, yet again, the Tax Commissioner appears to have given a favour to the—I beg your pardon, the Australian Securities Commission, in this instance, has purported to give a favour to a corporation associated with Mr Keating.
—Wrong speech—it is not the Tax Commissioner.
—I said, `the Australian Securities Commission'.
—You corrected yourself.

—Yes, I did. Nonetheless, we are talking about the Government giving favours and priority treatment to, firstly, Mr Keating as a private taxpayer and, secondly, to Mr Keating's company through the normal course of the need to file returns. I have also shown that, as distinct from Mr Keating being given the advantage of a nice letter to remind him to file his tax return, some 10,794 Australians were convicted in 1990-91 for the non-lodgment of a tax return.

PARA.TAB: Where are these decisions made? What action will be taken concerning the company returns of Mr Keating's companies? Where is it on the record that they are pursued like any other corporation is pursued? Senator Baume has drawn a most important question to the attention of the Senate. It shows that, once again, there seems to be one rule and one law for all Australians except for Mr Keating, who seems to get specialised treatment from one Government department or another.

Senator Baume, having brought that question to the attention of Senator Tate, deserves an answer as to what action will be taken, and all correspondence relating to this matter deserves to be tabled in this place so that we can make a true assessment of just which way even-handedness is practised in the Public Service as a whole. We will be able to see whether exactly the same pattern is followed by the Australian Securities Commission as was followed by the Commissioner for Taxation, Mr Boucher. Indeed, the way that Mr Keating's personal tax return was treated justifies the Fightback policy that we need a board in place in the Taxation Office.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table the annual return to the Australian Securities Commission of Pleuron Pty Ltd.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to this motion to take note of the answer to a question regarding company returns, I do not want to have a prolonged debate because, to be quite frank, I do not have enough information. The way in which a failure to lodge a company return is dealt with is a matter for the Australian Securities Commission. I have absolute confidence in its integrity and its independent capacity to make a decision as to whether to invoke, and to what extent it would need to invoke, the particular provisions of the Companies Act. I have indicated to the Senate that the Act provides for penalties for failure to lodge an annual return.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Bishop looks at the Hansard transcript of her remarks she may see that she was carried away to the extent of suggesting that already there is evidence of what she would call special treatment, favourable treatment, some sort of priority, being given to Mr Keating with respect to this matter. There is no evidence whatsoever that that is the case.

She has asked for correspondence and the like to be tabled with respect to this matter. By way of a cautionary note, all I would say is that if this is a matter which is still to be the subject of a penalty being levied or a court proceeding being undertaken, quite clearly it ought to stay within the confines of the ASC until those decisions are taken. After the judicial process, after the process of the courts, it might be appropriate to review the process in a way which is compatible with confidentiality and other requirements of the operations of the Australian Securities Commission. I think Senator Bishop may be a little premature in her request in that respect.

I will be seeking further information. I think it is important for the people of Australia to understand that there will be no political interference whatsoever from the office of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) or from my office with respect to that element of the portfolio; that is, the Australian Securities Commission. This matter will be left entirely to the ASC to discharge its duties to this nation, as indicated by the Parliament in setting forth the various provisions dealing with the lodging of company returns.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The fact of the matter is that Senator Baume pointed out that the due date for filing the return of Pleuron Pty Ltd was 31 January; it was filed as at 21 April—late. The Senate will want to know—and Senator Baume and I will both want to know—whether any action taken to follow up this matter with respect to penalties was instigated before or after this matter was raised in the Senate today.

PARA.TAB: For the Minister to simply say that all dealings with these matters is even-handed and that there will be no political interference leaves this question unanswered: what action was taken with regard to the follow-up of Mr Keating's late returns? Why was he singled out for special treatment when 10,794 Australians last year were, in fact—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you referring to his tax returns?

—I am talking about his personal tax return now. The analogy I am drawing is between the way one government department treats an individual and the way another government department treats the same individual—in other words, one rule for Australia as a whole and a different rule for Mr Keating.
—The mates.

—As my colleague here says, the mates. We could say that we almost have two nations. The point that I want to stress is that we want evidence of what action, if any, is taken after this date, and we want to know whether any action was taken prior to this date and attention being drawn to the matter. The same applies to those other companies, some of which are up to three years late.

PARA.TAB: In dealing with the question of the tax return, I said that the question remains unanswered as to what follow-up action was taken concerning Mr Keating's late returns. We have seen the completely uneven-handed treatment of individuals whereby Mr Keating gets one sort of treatment and Mr Phillip Smiles is prosecuted in an extraordinary way under the Crimes Act instead of the Tax Administration Act when the Australian Tax Office admits in an answer to a question of mine during Estimates that there is no precedent for prosecuting on a matter of apportionment under the Crimes Act. In other words, a precedent is being established when the Australian Tax Office knew that what was at stake was Mr Smiles losing his seat and the Greiner Government falling. This is not very even-handed from anybody's perspective.

There are many questions that remain unanswered. The questions of influence or otherwise—be it direct, perceived or anything else—with regard to Mr Keating's personal matters and his corporate matters are ones that certainly require answering.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—the petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. the petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PARA.TAB: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bishop (from 245 citizens), Senator Campbell (from 10 citizens) and Senator Kemp (from 50 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

PARA.TAB: Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469,274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of the Nullarbor Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned oppose the attempts by the Federal Government to World Heritage List the Nullarbor Region.
In doing so, we condemn the State and Federal Government for failing to consult with the residents of the Nullarbor in relation to the listing proposal.
Further, we affirm the excellent record of pastoralists, highway operators and the local communities in protecting the heritage and environmental value of the region.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PARA.TAB: (1)Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2)The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3)These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That every abortion kills an unborn baby.
That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
That the first duty of the Parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life.
That in 1989/90 alone Medicare subsidised 69,587 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to subsidise abortions through Medicare by passing the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia respectfully shows:
That the current Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance made by prospective citizens of Australia pledges allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, Her Heirs and Successors.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

PARA.TAB: Legislate to change the Australian Citizenship Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance to a pledge of Allegiance to Australia and the people of Australia, to reflect the true nature of Australian Government and society.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1.We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL FLAG.
2.We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the Nation's history.

PETITION.TITLE: British Commonwealth Occupation Force, Japan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectively request that:

That all former members of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (B.C.O.F.) Japan, who have not established eligibility through other military service, be granted eligibility for the Service Pension, and all benefits thereto, including the issue of campaign medals.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to so grant this request by legislation enacted by Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Government Funding of Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:
Every abortion kills an unborn human baby. More unborn Australians are killed every year (80,000) than the Australian death toll for the whole of World War II (30,000).
Australia's population is aging. Our live birth rate is below replacement level.
About 98 percent of abortions in Australia are performed for non-medical reasons (see SA Health Commission statistics).
Post abortion depression is a silent epidemic and is linked with the growing incidence of child abuse by mothers who have previously had abortions.
The Australian Government should not fund the killing of future Australian citizens.
Mothers with problem pregnancies need positive help to carry their babies to full term.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
pass the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990, and
help pregnant women with problems to continue their pregnancies.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
