SPEECH.PARA: AN HUMBLE PRAYER AND PETITION TO HIS EXCELLENCY
His Excellency, The Honourable William George Hayden A.Q
Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia and
Commander in Chief of the Defence Force,
Government House,
CANBERRA, A.C.T., 2600
MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY
I know it is my duty to keep you informed as to MY WILL on any matter that comes before the Parliament or should come before the Parliament.

Between 15 and 19 January 1988 Kevin John Woods, Michael Anthony Smith, Phillip Masiz Conjwayo and Barry Desmond Bawden were detained in Zimbabwe under the Zimbabwean Emergency Regulations for offences committed against The African National Congress (A.N.C.). At that time a state of war existed between the A.N.C. and the Government of South Africa, the A.N.C. operating from bases in Zimbabwe, carried out acts of terrorism and sabotage against South Africa. Woods, Smith, Conjwayo and Bawden were only allowed access to a lawyer on 2-3 February 1988 after making and signing damaging statements which were obtained by torture and duress (their families were also arrested and only released after Woods, Smith, Bawden and Conjwayo made and signed their statements).

They were held on remand as political prisoners and paraded before the world's press as "South African Spies" and "Agents of South Africa" yet after conviction have been detained as common criminals under appalling conditions. Beahan was arrested in Botswana on 28/7/88, was tortured and illegally handed over to Zimbabwe, was held on remand as a political prisoner and on conviction detained as a common criminal. Woods, Smith, Conjwayo, Bawden and Beahan were in the employ of the South African Government, were arrested after carrying out directions of the South African Defence Force against designated A.N.C. targets. Woods, Smith and Conjwayo are being held in solitary confinement. Bawden and Beahan are likewise held in degrading and appalling conditions with hundreds of common criminals. Their actions were of a political nature whilst a state of war existed between South Africa and the A.N.C. This situation no longer exists and yet they are still detained as common criminals under conditions where their health and well being is in jeopardy. It is MY WILL that the Australian government use its influence to:
1.have their status restored to that of political prisoners;
2.have their conditions of imprisonment changed according to their status as political prisoners; and
3.facilitate their release under the political prisoner release/exchange process underway in South Africa.
I do most humbly and respectfully pray and beseech Your Excellency to convey MY WILL to both Houses of the Parliament.
I am one of Her Australian Majesty's respectful servants.
GOD SAVE THE QUEEN!

SPEECH.PARA: PUBLIC WORKS COMMITTEE
2 June 1992
Mr President
In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, I present the report relating to the following proposed work:
The refurbishment and fitout of Juliana House, Phillip, ACT.

The report which I have just tabled is for the refurbishment and fitout of Juliana House in the Phillip-Woden area of the ACT. This project is sponsored, and will be managed, by the Australian Estate Management, a Division of the Department of Administrative Services.

Australian Estate Management is accountable to government for the effective asset management of the office estate, of which Juliana House forms a part. The office estate is fully commercialised and tenants, principally government departments, pay market based rents.

The proposed scope of the work will include: repairs to damaged ceilings, replacement of carpets, upgrading of electricity supply and all mechanical services, including lifts and the fire protection system, in order to meet relevant Australian building codes and standards.

Disabled persons facilities will also be provided in accordance with the relevant codes. These will include: ramp access to the main entrance to the building, lifts with voice indicator facilities, lower controls access for wheelchair users and braille controls for the visually impaired.

The Government had given its approval for the design and commencement of refurbishment at a total cost of $8.27 million dollars with expenditure of four hundred and sixty thousand dollars in 1991/92. Australian Estate Management subsequently sought additional funds of five hundred and ten thousand dollars from the Department of Finance to increase the scope of works, to carry out a major upgrade of the lift services. These the Australian Estate Management considered were below normal requirements of modern office accommodation.
The estimated total cost for the project now stands at $8.78 million with expenditure of four hundred and sixty thousand dollars in 1991/92. The project is scheduled for completion by January 1994.

The Committee believes that every effort should be made to complete this project by the end of 1993, in order to avoid the considerable cost which could be incurred by the traditional Christmas period close-down of the building industry.
The Department of Health, Housing and Community Services will occupy the refurbished Juliana House.

Since its creation in July 1987, the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services has been pursuing an accommodation policy aimed at collocating its staff in central and state offices. In Canberra, it is collocating in the Woden-Phillip area and by its move to Juliana House will relinquish comparable space in privately leased accommodation.

The Committee agrees that a need exists to refurbish Juliana House to bring it up to modern office standards for leasing to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. Accordingly, the Committee has approved the project.
The Committee, however, has reservations relating to the cost benefits of this proposal to the prospective tenant.

The Committee was disturbed to learn that the financial impact of the re-negotiation of leases on the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, will result at best in a cost neutral budget. In all probability, the department anticipates a small budgetary increase.
Nor does the department anticipate any staff savings or a reduction in the number of vehicles used for courier service by its move to Juliana House.
The Committee was told by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services that the benefits it would derive from moving to Juliana House were in the main, qualitative, such as:
easier access by clients and service providers
flexibility to accommodate organisational change
enhanced security of its resources.

Juliana House is a product of the basic office block design of the 1960s. It stands amongst equals with a cluster of buildings in the Woden Town Centre, all taking their names from the ships of the first, second and third fleets.
When the Committee inspected Juliana House prior to the public inquiry, it saw a building with little aesthetic appeal and with many of its services at the end of their operational life.

The Committee questioned the value of retaining this building, but Australian Estate Management maintained that, neither a "fire sale" nor leasing are options in the building's present condition. Also, that it was quite likely that an unrefurbished empty building in the Phillip-Woden area would remain vacant with loss of benefits to the Commonwealth.
Based on this judgment, the Committee recommends that the proposal should proceed.
However, the Committee is of the view that the estimated cost for the refurbishment and fitout estimated at $8.78 million dollars is excessive.
Juliana House was presented to the Committee as a structurally sound building, requiring no major internal or external structural changes.

In addition, during the last ten years, maintenance work of approximately six hundred and four thousand dollars has been carried out on Juliana House. The work described included many of the upgrades proposed in the current scope of the work.

During the public inquiry, the major part of the Committee's questions centred on the issue of cost reduction of the work. The Committee was presented with alternative floor layouts to those proposed, and in the Committee's view, these have merit and should be examined.

The Committee rejects a proposal for the provision of a block of unisex showers on the ground floor. The Committee believes that the block of showers is inappropriately located, adjacent to the conference facilities and the public area. The Committee is of the opinion that, an alternative proposal to modify the plumbing in the male and female toilet area on each floor, has merit and should be implemented.

The Committee concludes that the cost of the proposal estimated at $8.78 million dollars is excessive. The Committee recommends that the project, including floor layouts should be thoroughly re-examined with the aim of substantially reducing the estimated costs.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments in relation to the report of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works entitled The refurbishment and fitout of Juliana House, Phillip, ACT which has just been tabled. Within the report, the Committee has approved the cost of the refurbishment of part of Juliana House in the sum of $8.27m and an additional sum, bringing it to $8.78m. The project is scheduled for completion by January 1994, although the Committee recommends that it be completed by the end of 1993 to avoid the additional costs of the summer break which would otherwise be added to the cost of the building.

PARA.TAB: The matter I refer to in particular is the very disappointing fact that expenditure of only $460,000 is scheduled for 1991-92. Of course, we do not actually know whether the expenditure for the remaining amount will be allocated in the forthcoming Budget. The reason this is of importance to the ACT is that more than 1,500 office workers have been moved from the Woden and Phillip areas in recent times. Most of them have been moved to Tuggeranong.

I certainly do not object to office workers being relocated in Tuggeranong, because honourable senators will remember that at the time the Government approved the construction of the Tuggeranong town centre it had already promised that by the time its construction was complete there would be government office workers in the area, and that was not the case. The impact on the shopkeepers who then went into the Hyperdome at Tuggeranong was absolutely devastating. It is only some years after that that area is even beginning to look like a viable trading area.

Office workers have now been moved to Tuggeranong and it is Woden that has suffered the loss. The fact is that Juliana House, this building we are now considering, has been empty for some time as workers have been moved out of it. There are other empty blocks, Medibank House, the Cosmopolitan building, the Sir Keith Campbell building and Scarborough House—the patent office works out of Scarborough House at the moment—a mix of government and privately-owned buildings, but it is substantially government employees who have been moved from the area. Any area from which one moves about 1,500 office workers is very significantly affected. In Woden Plaza, a number of shops in the area nearest the office buildings have fallen on very heavy times. Quite apart from the recession we had to have and everything else that has affected trading, this particular area has suffered the loss of 1,500 office workers and has no great prospects of them returning there in the very near future.

We are told that the Juliana House project, which is the subject of the report before us today, is not expected to be completed until January 1994. I reiterate my concern that the $460,000 being spent in this financial year presumably relates only to some of the design work being done for the building. Whether the Government will allocate funds in the next Budget to enable the project to be completed on time or whether it will be deferred because of budgetary considerations is a matter of great interest to traders in the Woden and Phillip area, especially since we do not know when office workers will return to the other buildings that I have mentioned.

I could go on at some length. But I reiterate: there has been a total lack of concern by the Government about the impact that the allocation of office space for its employees will have on people who have, in good faith, been established in the area for some time. Juliana House was opened in the 1960s. It was trading before Woden Plaza was built—as were some of these other buildings. The project has been handled in a such a way that absolutely no regard whatever has been shown for the shopkeepers and traders in that area. I repeat: I am not suggesting that office workers should not have been placed in Tuggeranong. But there certainly was not any planning or any consideration of the impact on private sector companies in Canberra when these decisions were made.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate calls on the Government to establish an independent judicial inquiry to inquire into and report, within eight weeks, on the following matters—

TAB.TAB: (1)The appropriateness and propriety of the conduct and decisions of ministers, ministerial staff and departmental officers in relation to the business activities of Gregory Symons.
(2)The need for, and possible terms of, a code of ministerial conduct.

SPEECH.PARA: In moving the motion, I draw attention to two separate aspects of this proposed judicial inquiry. The first relates to the many questions raised in recent weeks regarding the possible intercession by a Minister, Ministers, staffs of Ministers or members of the bureaucracy on behalf of the business dealings of Mr Symons. The second, which is really a quite separate issue although it has arisen out of this matter, is the appropriateness of the ministerial conduct which has surrounded these issues.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important to recognise that in relation to the latter matter when Senator Richardson resigned from the Ministry he did so claiming that his reason lay in not wishing to damage the ability of the Government to go on and win the next election nor to do damage to the Labor Party and the Government. Senator Richardson himself has not admitted, and we have not heard any Ministers on the Government side admit, that what he did in interceding on Mr Symons's behalf was in any sense behaviour inappropriate for a Minister. We believe that matter, along with the question of the actions that were or may have been taken, should be tested—and should be tested before an independent judicial inquiry.

As I have said, the behaviour of Senator Richardson which has been catalogued repeatedly in this chamber in issuing a reference, as he claims, with very little knowledge of the business background of Mr Symons begs the question whether that was appropriate behaviour for a Minister, knowing as he did at least that the business which was to be set up was not even to be conducted in Australia but conducted overseas. Was that indeed appropriate behaviour for a Minister? We believe that it was not appropriate and there are probably quite a few people in this chamber who believe that that was not appropriate.

We believe that sort of decision should be tested so that in the future we are not left in this vague area—and the vagueness of it was actually agreed to by Senator Evans when I asked him the specific question in this case relating to Senator Richardson's intercession on behalf of Mr Symons for the return of the passport after he had been arrested. Specifically, the question to Senator Evans was: was it appropriate for Senator Evans to have given the advice to Senator Richardson that Senator Richardson could make such an approach? Senator Evans in his reply said that this was a vague area. We may well all agree that it is a vague area.

Under those circumstances, when a person is actually before the courts in a foreign country and the intercession is on behalf of that person in relation to one of the matters before the courts, should a senior Minister intercede in any way in that action in the foreign country; or should that be the prerogative exclusively of the Foreign Minister? I tend to the latter view. The point I am getting to is that Senator Evans agreed that that was a grey area; it was one which required further elucidation. Consequently, it would be very useful to bring to bear on this matter an independent person who could look at these matters and, hopefully, lay down some sort of criteria by which we might be guided and by which Ministers in future might be guided.

Throughout much of the questioning in these last couple of weeks, there have been implications—and I do not put it any higher than that—that members of ministerial staff, other Ministers or bureaucrats perhaps have been leant on to further the interests of Mr Symons. So far, we do not know whether that has occurred, and in answers to those sorts of questions Senator Evans principally but also others have said, `You provide the evidence and then we will carry out an inquiry'. It seems that that really is the wrong way to go; that with all the evidence within government departments it is appropriate that that evidence be brought out from there rather than that those who are in the dark as to what might have gone on be required to produce the evidence first of all. We make no judgment in relation to these matters as to whether these intercessions by other persons did or did not take place, whether they were or were not appropriate, and to what extent they may have furthered the business interests of Mr Symons. But it does seem to us that we have reached a point in this situation where the business of the Senate is becoming bogged down. Today's Notice Paper lists 64 Bills still to be dealt with in a period of 2 1/2 weeks, and there is an urgent need to get on with that legislation.

We have not supported a Senate inquiry, and I think most people recognise that a Senate inquiry would be an unlikely forum to come to very satisfactory conclusions in either of the matters that I have placed before the Senate today. With a Senate committee comprising three members of the Opposition, one could imagine that in a period such as this leading up to an election there would be strong emphasis on, let us say, gunning for the Government. On the Government side, there would very likely be very strong defence, irrespective of whether it were justified or not. At the same time as that inquiry was going on, it is very likely that as titbits of information came out there would be continual press meetings—particularly from the Opposition side—keeping the issue alive. For that reason, as I think Senator Hill himself has recognised on several occasions, an independent inquiry is a more appropriate way to go.

Returning to the issue of ministerial conduct, honourable senators will recognise from the terms of this committee of inquiry that it is also a prospective look at an appropriate code of ministerial conduct because the Government has not addressed the issue of ministerial conduct at all. Senator Richardson's explanation that his assistance to Mr Symons was in the course of his normal duties relating to his constituency has not been questioned by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), despite the fact that this explanation does not stand up to the slightest scrutiny. Senator Evans's actions in giving the green light to a highly controversial phone call to the President of the Marshall Islands has similarly not been questioned—although, as I indicated, Senator Evans has indicated that that permission is a grey area which requires some further elucidation.

Of course, hanging off this is the suggestion, which has been dealt with in some questions, of the rumours which were circulating in the Marshall Islands as to whether other approaches were made to other Ministers in the Marshall Islands. It would be useful to bring those rumours before an independent committee which was aware of them to find out whether they had any substance.

The closeness of Senator Richardson's connections with Mr Symons's business activities has raised rumours and suggestions that subterranean influences were brought to bear to expedite Mr Symons's various dealings with government departments. I stress again that the Democrats pass no judgment on the accuracy of these suggestions. However, we are convinced that they will not be put to rest until an independent, credible and public inquiry is conducted. The Democrats are convinced that a Senate inquiry is a totally inappropriate forum for the airing of these issues. Unlike Senate inquiries, a public, open judicial inquiry would be objective and justice far more likely to be done and be seen to be done.

Mr Symons obviously had extraordinary access to Senator Richardson and to the resources of his office. The assistance provided, we believe, went well beyond the bounds of Senator Richardson's responsibility to his constituents. For example, there is the provision of the reference on ministerial letterhead without any background checks. What are the appropriate checks?If Ministers are to provide references under such circumstances for businesses in foreign countries, first of all, should those references be issued? If they are to be issued, what sort of checks are appropriate so that not only is the good name of this country protected but also that those in foreign countries are protected from the activities of somebody of perhaps doubtful business background?

The rapid assistance for migration applications by Mr Symons's clients is another matter. While parliamentarians, of course, commonly deal with immigration problems, the normal procedure is to provide help once applications have been delayed or rejected. Senator Richardson's office seems to have actually lodged applications on behalf of Mr Symons and those applications appear to have contained false information.

There is the matter of the placing of the phone call to the head of another country to request that Mr Symons's passport be returned to allow him into Australia to prepare his defence to the charges of forgery. Most Australian parliamentarians limit their interventions in legal proceedings to prisoners of conscience imprisoned by undemocratic regimes with poor human rights records. None of these conditions apply to Senator Richardson's actions. Again, I stress: what are the appropriate limits for a Minister to intercede in legal proceedings in another country? It would be very useful to be able to lay down some firm guidelines.

We also have the intercession by Senator Richardson with the President of the Senate for the purposes of expediting Mr Symons's access to US congressmen. As I indicated, we have already made a judgment regarding Senator Sibraa's actions here, believing that he was an instrument of the incredible intercessional web woven by Senator Richardson. Nonetheless, it indicates the extent to which ministerial influence can be exercised through other people. The question arises of whether that influence was exercised through others in a ministerial capacity or a staff capacity or through the bureaucracy.

It is not just good enough to pass these and other forms of assistance off as constituency duties; they are not. They are nothing if not cronyism at work to the detriment of the reputation of the Government and, as it turned out, to the detriment of the reputation of this country. They have embroiled Senator Sibraa and Senator Evans, with Senator Evans giving what the Democrats regard as inappropriate—and I stress again, inappropriate—advice on the question of the phone call to the Marshall Islands President.

In this context it is hardly surprising that suggestions of pressure being applied below ministerial level in support of Symons are circulating widely. It has become clear to the Democrats that these rumours—these stories—will not go away without an inquiry. We believe that it is in the interests of the Government also for such an inquiry to be held to lay to rest these stories.

It may be that nothing will be revealed. Nevertheless, it is important that the air be cleared and that the issue of ministerial standards be addressed. I return to that point: in the context of this Senate, where we do not even have a code of ethical behaviour for senators, much less Ministers, we believe that it would be very appropriate for this to be addressed and for the matters to be teased out. This would be a very useful starting point for such a teasing out and the laying down of at least a draft code of ministerial conduct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept that there is any justification for a judicial inquiry of the kind proposed by Senator Coulter today. He divides the issues, as does his motion, into two parts. The issues within the proposed terms of reference so far as the actions of Ministers, ministerial staff and bureaucrats are concerned have been the subject of sustained public exposure for more than a month now, as well as pretty relentless assault here in this Parliament for the last week and a half.

PARA.TAB: Notwithstanding all that exposure, there has simply been no prima facie evidence of wrongdoing that has emerged on the part of any Minister, ministerial staffer or departmental officer in relation to the business activities of Mr Symons that could possibly justify this kind of inquiry. It might be unreasonable to ask for conclusive evidence before one sets in train an inquiry of this kind, but it is not unreasonable to ask for prima facie evidence. I suggest to Senator Coulter, in all fairness, that he ought to consider whether any government in the world would be prepared to set in train an expensive, time consuming and necessarily very sensitive exercise of this kind without there at least being prima facie evidence of actual wrongdoing to justify it.

There are two particular areas that Senator Coulter has referred to, I think, in various public comments that may justify close scrutiny by such an inquiry. One is the matter of access to export market development grants by Mr Symons or companies with which he may have some association. In the course of my remarks I want to address in some detail that particular issue to try to demonstrate to Senator Coulter, in all fairness, that despite all the herrings that have been laid out, they are, in fact, all red and they do not lead anywhere, and an inquiry would simply have nowhere to go in pursuing those particular matters.

Similarly, so far as immigration issues are concerned, Senator Tate, in the time available to him, will address in a little detail the kinds of issues that have been raised. Hopefully, he will also demonstrate that there is simply nothing on the record that could possibly justify an inquiry in that respect.

To the extent that questions have been raised about Senator Richardson's associations with Mr Symons while he was a Minister, it is the case that Senator Richardson has already paid the ultimate political price for those associations with his resignation. To the extent that there was a belief, even if not accepted by Senator Richardson or others in the Government, that those associations were inappropriate in some way, then Senator Richardson has paid the price for them.

Any questions that relate to him in this respect are at best now as a result moot, and at worst involve a rather unhappy and unedifying form of persecution of him. To the extent that, on the other hand, what are involved here are not questions of the behaviour of individuals but larger questions of principle about ministerial conduct—and that is the second part of Senator Coulter's motion—it is the case—

TALK.START.PARA: —Precisely; was his behaviour appropriate?

—That ministerial conduct is presently governed by the requirement to lodge declarations of interest, is governed by the rules concerning the dealing of people with lobbyists and is governed by the general conventions of the Westminster system of government.

PARA.TAB: There will always be argument about the precise description and application, in particular, of the last category—the conventions of Westminster government. There will always, I suspect, be grey areas. It is inappropriate to believe that an inquiry of the kind that Senator Coulter is talking about by a single judicial officer would, any more than the Bowen inquiry, for example, some years ago, produce absolutely definitive guidelines of a kind that were universally accepted, universally applicable, without any doubt in any particular situation.

I have addressed today the question of ministerial responsibility as it has been raised in relation to me concerning my answers in this place and my state of knowledge on various matters and the events that led up to them. I also answered in some detail on Thursday, 28 May last week the question that was put to me by Senator Coulter about the particular phone call and my responsibility for that. I acknowledge that there are debatable issues arising out of, as I indicated last week, that latter matter, but I honestly suggest to Senator Coulter that this Parliament is the best place to debate issues of that kind. If we are going to seek any ultimate resolution of them, we cannot expect some judicial officer to do the job for us in a way that will answer all these questions once and for all.

As an example of the kind of issue that has been constantly raised over the last few days, I come back to the question of access by Mr Symons or companies on his behalf to EMDGs. Earlier in Question Time I described the general way in which the export market development grant system works. Again, for the sake of brevity, I will not repeat that now. It is terribly important to understand the minimal extent to which discretion applies in the administration of those particular grants and the relatively automatic way in which criteria are satisfied and ticked off, and moneys are paid.

I would like to go through all the various contexts in which these particular grants have been raised in recent days and at least explain why it is that, in our judgment, there is no basis for an inquiry to be pursued so far as any of this is concerned. I am constrained in what I can say about particular applications because of the secrecy provisions of the Australian Trade Commission Act and the Freedom of Information Act. I have no discretion to release documentation or, for that matter, any detailed information derived from such documentation concerning the business affairs of another person without first giving that person the opportunity to put a case as to why the information should not be released. That constrains me now in my ability to talk in detail about what the actual activities were that were the subject of these various grants. But I am not constrained, of course, from being quite explicit about material that is not contained in files or records that bear upon this, and I think it might be helpful, in putting all this in some context, to go into that in a little detail.

The grants fall into various categories. The first are those that have gone directly to Mr Symons as a sole trader, as an individual, or to some company with which he has had a major, explicit association. There are two such grants in that category. The first worth mentioning is that to Unipac International in 1990-91. The most I can say about that project is that it did operate in the Pacific area, but that it involved the education sector and that it, certainly on all the knowledge we have, on the advice available to me, did not involve the business migration scheme in any way.

As to that particular grant, it was paid to Mr Symons as a sole trader in December 1991 in the amount of $131,443. Austrade informs me that it has no evidence connecting Mr Symons's activities in the Marshall Islands with payments he had received under the EMDG scheme in relation to this matter or, for that matter, anything else; nor has Austrade had any representations made to it on Mr Symons's behalf in relation to this matter by anyone, including Senator Richardson. Generally I am advised by Austrade that it dealt with this matter no differently from the way it deals with any of the other 3,000 or so Australian small to medium businesses which apply for an export market development grant each year. I have already said that this grant was quite unrelated to the Marshall Islands and quite unrelated to any business migration service, which is not an eligible service within the meaning of the Act anyway.

The second grant that was made to Mr Symons, or at least to a company with which he was a prominent player, was the grant to Feedtech Pty Ltd—and that was in 1986-87—for what I can describe only as a project in north-east Asia in the agricultural sector but not involving steel mills, business migration or anything of that kind. The Feedtech grant was for $141,559. The notice of determination for it was issued on 26 July. The company was paid the amount in question on 23 August. A question has arisen about the status of the company—being in receivership and so on. That has been separately debated. I have nothing more to add in relation to that aspect of the matter except to draw attention again to the statutory obligation of EMDG to make pay-outs notwithstanding the status of receivership, liquidation or whatever of the company in question. As I have acknowledged to Senator Coulter, that does raise a policy question that perhaps needs some review in light of this, but it is not something that is susceptible to judicial inquiry in this context.

As to the Feedtech grant, there is no documentation on Austrade's files which suggests that Feedtech applied for or received EMDG moneys remotely related to either the Marshall Islands or to business migration. There is no evidence that Austrade had representations made on its behalf by Senator Richardson or by anyone else. There is no evidence of representations being made, for that matter, in China, Hong Kong, Taiwan or anywhere else by Senator Richardson or any other parliamentarian. To the extent that this may have had something to do with China, this particular grant was not involved in any way with the steel industry in China or anywhere else. So I can state a series of negative propositions about that which may put to rest some particular furphies.

Apart from those two particular matters, Austrade has no record of any contact with either Mr Symons or Feedtech, the company of which he was managing director, at any of its 14 offices in Australia or its 65 offices overseas, other than that which necessarily occurred in the normal and stringent processing of the EMDG applications in question for these two particular grants.

What is to be said about businesses with which Mr Symons is alleged to have had some association? A number of firm names or businesses have been mentioned in this respect in recent days. I will quickly go through them. One was the Pacific Design Group. That has been the subject of an FOI application by Mr Peacock and there have been questions also from Senator O'Chee. Pacific Design Group has received two payments under the EMDG scheme, the first in April 1991 for $128,066 and the second in October 1991 for $129,057, for the 1989-90 and 1990-91 grant years respectively.

The Pacific Design Group files in Austrade have nothing in them to suggest that it had any dealings at all with Mr Symons; there is nothing in the files bearing upon that issue. There is nothing to suggest that there had been any dealings with Senator Richardson in relation to that. There is nothing to suggest that there were any representations made to Austrade on behalf of that business by Senator Richardson or any other parliamentarian. There is nothing to suggest that there were any dealings with the Marshall Islands by that particular company. There is nothing to suggest that it was involved in business migration schemes in the Marshall Islands or anywhere else. And there is nothing to suggest that it applied for or received any EMDG moneys pertaining to the use of consultants of any kind, either in Australia or overseas.

I do not think that leaves any room for any further questions about Mr Symons's involvement with that. It certainly does not so far as any wrongdoing or state of mind or knowledge on the part of Austrade itself and its officers is concerned.

Now let us come to Multiplex, in relation to which a number of questions were asked. Multiplex has had EMDGs made available to it. For the sake of time, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the page of information that bears upon the question of the two EMDGs made to Multiplex of Western Australia. I am sorry that I did not give advance notice.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Austrade advises that two EMDG grants have been paid to Multiplex Constructions Pty Ltd of Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: One grant of $6,633 was for the 1985-86 grant year.
The other grant of $36,030 was for the 1986-87 grant year.

PARA.TAB: Both grants were paid on 28 December 1989 after initial nil determinations in respect of both years.

SPEECH.PARA: Nil determinations were made on 21 November 1988.

After internal Austrade review instigated by Multiplex, and provision of necessary information, the final grant determinations were made on 10 November 1989 for $6,633 and on 19 December 1989 for $36,030.

PARA.TAB: Multiplex is a claimant in respect of the 1990-91 grant year.

SPEECH.PARA: This application has not yet been processed.

PARA.TAB: Austrade has no record of the Multiplex (NSW) Constructions Pty Ltd, of New South Wales as having received any payments under the EMDG Scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to Multiplex, to the extent that it was involved, in respect of one of these grants, with an EMDG application in China bearing upon the steel mill in Tianjin which has been the subject of public speculation, that did not involve Mr Symons in any way. To the extent that it involved Senator Richardson, the only reference to Senator Richardson in Austrade documentation is to his being a member of the group which visited Tianjin in 1987: a submission was made as part of the EMDG application listing the participants in that particular mission and Senator Richardson's name was listed among those participants. I said all of this in the Hansard on 28 May at page 2909; I have nothing to add.
—Do you have a list of the group?

—I am unable to say, consistently with the confidentiality provisions that govern this. Subject to Multiplex itself being prepared to release it, I am not in a position to say who the other members of the group were. But that is something in respect of which I think there is an FOI application, and it may be that there will be no difficulty, ultimately, about releasing that.

PARA.TAB: I was asked a question about BHP and I simply note what I said on the record on 28 May at page 2911 of the weekly Hansard; namely, that there is nothing in Austrade files to suggest any EMDG application in any relevant respect by BHP. We have been advised by BHP that Mr Symons was involved in the sale of a steel mill in 1989, not to Tianjin but to Wuxi. There is nothing to connect this with Senator Richardson's other visit to China.

So far as other inquiries are concerned with other companies, Mr Peacock has made some FOI applications. One set is in respect of Mr Ling. I answered a detailed question today from Senator Baume in that respect. I understand the Opposition has also sought information on EMDG payments to James Capel Australia Ltd and Rene Rivkin. I understand the files on these grants are currently in transit from Sydney to Canberra. I am unable to state categorically what is not in them but, to the extent that anyone wants me to pursue this, I will be happy to advise the Senate on that matter in a supplementary answer as soon as I can.
Information about the grants in question has been made available to the Opposition and, again for the sake of brevity, I seek leave to incorporate the details of that in Hansard at this point.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

James Capel Australia Ltd has received two grants under the Export Market Development Grant Scheme—first grant of $200,000 for the 1988/89 grant year—the second grant of $200,000 for the 1989/90 grant year.
First grant was paid in July 1990 whilst the second in November 1990.
There is no other record of EMDG payments paid to James Capel Australia Ltd other than those described above.
Rene Rivkin received a grant of $2,160 in respect of the 1984/85 grant year.
There are no other records of Mr Rivkin receiving any benefits other than that specified above.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Opposition has sought information on 12 other companies in relation to the EMDG scheme. I simply say in this respect that there is no information in Austrade's EMDG files on these companies. This means that none has either applied for or received any EMDG payment.

PARA.TAB: I put all this material on the public record simply to indicate—I hope persuasively—to the Democrats in particular that we are honestly prepared to chase up any question that is raised in relation to any of these particular matters and to explore files. But none of the material that exists on any file at the moment, combined with the Democrat's knowledge now of the way in which the general system operates so far as EMDGs are concerned, really does give rise to any colourable suggestions whatsoever.

No government can lend itself to proposals for judicial inquiries in that sort of situation. It is a very different matter if there is some prima facie evidence of actual wrongdoing. We are, of course, prepared to look at any prima facie evidence that arises and to judge what the best way of handling that is, but when there is no such evidence and it is just a series of allegations and suggestions being made, hypothetical scenarios being constructed and the general argument being put by the Opposition and others that this is all a bit unhappy and unsavoury looking, in all honesty and good faith I believe that we are entitled to resist an inquiry premised on so flimsy a set of foundations.

I repeat that Senator Tate will specifically address the immigration issues that have been raised to the extent that he is able to do so, subject to his own confidentiality constraints. We are perfectly happy—as I hope I have made clear over the last week and a half—to respond to any specific allegation that is made, fully and forthrightly. I am presently considering—and it has just been made available to me earlier this afternoon—the documentation that has been the subject of FOI evaluation in a preliminary way by the Department. I hope to be able to make my own evaluation of that in the later hours of today and give a response on that as soon as possible.

We are not acting in any way that is seeking to conceal anything that we remotely believe is describable as wrongdoing or misbehaviour. Certainly, should such prima facie evidence come to light, we stand ready to submit it to any scrutiny that is really appropriate objectively in all the circumstances. For all those reasons, I urge the Democrats to think again about the legitimacy and justice of the call for the inquiry that they have made and to reconsider their position when it comes to the vote.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support the Democrats' motion. As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, we have for some time been seeking an inquiry into this matter. We have put down a notice of motion in the Senate seeking a parliamentary inquiry, because that is within the province of the Parliament. We have always thought that a judicial inquiry would be appropriate. However, we have doubted the good faith of the Government to set it up, if I might say so with respect. From what I have heard from the Minister today, the Government will continue to fight tooth and nail against such a judicial inquiry—such a public inquiry—into these matters.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the process of questioning in the Parliament is not really suited to what we are seeking to do and that is to put together the picture of what is a complicated business migration scam. I can, however, advise the Senate of a few pieces of the jigsaw that have now become apparent, stressing that there is still a lot that is unknown. We do know that about $US1.25m has been lost through this scam. We know that it was put together by a mate of the Labor Party, and particularly a mate of Senator Richardson, one Greg Symons. We know that it is a story about connections with government used to advance improper objectives. We know it was to involve the granting of passports to the Marshall Islands, primarily to get entry for the recipients into the United States. We know it was to cost so-called investors a quarter of a million dollars US per head. In other words, before the scam was discovered, five investors had paid up.

We know that, although it was the brainchild of Symons, there is also the involvement to an undetermined extent of another lawyer, one Finch, who had worked in the Marshall Islands. We know that they used innocent professionals to help develop their scheme. These professionals are reputable people who were induced, at least in part, by a glowing reference of Senator Richardson on ministerial letterhead in favour of Mr Symons. That was a reference both as to his personal bona fides and also as to his sound business background.

We do not know for certain when that was written, but I have seen one copy that was forwarded to one of these professionals who had been brought within this program on Social Security fax letterhead dated 7 June. It does seem that, in fact, the reference may have been written for the purpose of Mr Symons's Marshall Islands venture. We know that it was a reference which was wrong in fact. Symons had a tarnished business background, to express it in its most favourable terms. It is a background littered with creditors as Symons seems to have moved from one scheme to another.

The cover for the scheme was to be the development and operation of a technology park and university in the Marshall Islands. This was to produce an aura of legitimacy. Whether Symons ever intended the construction of the project we do not know. Interestingly, there are still some who believe that it could have been a feasible project if he had gone about it legitimately. The real inducement for investors was to be access to the United States via, first, citizenship in the Marshall Islands and then a passport. It seems that Mr Symons made a mistake in that he asserted that Marshall Islands passports gave investors immediate access to the United States. So he set about seeking a change in US law and, again, sought the assistance of his influential friend, Senator Richardson, who introduced him to Senator Sibraa, the President of the Senate, who then wrote to the Australian Embassy in Washington for help.

I might mention in passing that of course Senator Richardson also made contact with the United States Ambassador to help Mr Symons with his project additionally. Of course, Senator Sibraa, who is in the same faction as Senator Richardson, astonishingly neither checked the facts with the Department of Foreign Affairs nor informed DFAT in Canberra or the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Furthermore, he got the facts in his reference wrong in that he asserted that Australia had been asked by the President of the Marshall Islands for help.

The extent to which the Australian Government helped in Washington is still unclear. It seems that the diplomat Mr Lamb, whom I readily acknowledge is a respected and experienced diplomat, had reservations, despite the fact that Symons was promoted to him as a friend of Richo's and that Symons reinforced the Richardson connection by producing a copy of a memorandum purportedly from Mr Symons to Senator Richardson detailing the scheme and asserting Senator Richardson's knowledge of the scheme.

We do not know exactly what Symons represented to Mr Lamb, because the Government is not prepared to let us hear Mr Lamb's story. We do find it astonishing that the memorandum was not forwarded to Canberra with the Sibraa letter back in November or when the controversy raged here in Canberra during April, but again we are denied the benefit of an explanation.

We find it disconcerting that this key document was not discovered until after the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) demanded a search of DFAT's files in mid May. Of course, Senator Richardson has denied ever seeing a copy of this memorandum.

With this letter of introduction from the President of the Senate under presidential letterhead, the Richardson reference under ministerial letterhead and the copy of the memorandum purportedly to Senator Richardson from Mr Symons, no doubt a strong case was made out in Washington of Australian Government support for what Mr Symons was seeking. Despite his so-called connections, it seems that changing US law was not so easy.

Back in the Marshall Islands there is no doubt that Mr Symons had gained government support in principle for his scheme—again, we understand, using the Richardson reference and, interestingly, the letter of introduction from Senator Sibraa to Mr Lamb. I say `interestingly' because how he came by that is a mystery in itself. Senator Sibraa advised the Prime Minister that the only copy he had of it had gone to Lamb in Washington.

It will be alleged that the Marshall Islands Government did not approve the details of the business migration scheme or, in other words, that it was not ready to go into operation. Using genuine documents from the Marshall Islands and allegedly using others which were not genuine, it seems that Mr Symons continued to impress, firstly, those he had engaged to develop and market the scheme and, secondly, potential investors, including all of those who did become investors. They were victims.

Another victim was Mr Chang. He was a victim in that he was an investor. Because Symons was unable to obtain Marshall Islands documentation for him, there was a need to get Chang Jnr back into Australia where he had been a student in order that he might continue his studies. It was decided by Mr Symons that this should be done through Fiji. Thus followed the supporting documentation from Multiplex—and here is this name which was mentioned by Senator Richardson's office. But a mistake was made. Clearly, the first of such documents was supposed to be with regard to Chang Jnr, but it was addressed to Chang Snr. An astute immigration officer of the Australian Government in Suva became suspicious and the abuse was defeated.

On the face of the documents, Multiplex has some explaining to do. I understand that Multiplex will argue that it was also misled by Symons. An inquiry will no doubt establish the facts in that regard. As for the part played by Senator Richardson's office in that matter, that would also be a subject of the inquiry.

It is alleged that Mr Symons's inability to deliver the product offered to investors led to the false documents and forgeries which are the substance of the charges in the Marshall Islands. We are obviously not interested in the issue of the alleged forgeries in the Marshall Islands, which will be pursued within the courts of the Marshall Islands. However, the intervention by Senator Richardson in then contacting the President of the Marshall Islands for the benefit of Mr Symons is something which obviously had the potential to embarrass Australia and should be examined by a committee.

The DFAT file note of 6 April regarding the rumour that Senator Richardson might have been contacting not only the President but other Cabinet Ministers seeking leniency for Symons should also be investigated. The suggestion is that Senator Richardson may have been engaged considerably beyond that which Senator Evans authorised. The authorisation by the Foreign Minister for Senator Richardson to seek to intervene in any event is, in our view, astonishing and should be looked at further. If I have time, I will return to the role of the Foreign Minister in due course.

It may have been that US residency was the inducement Symons was primarily offering his investors. However, he also made claims of being able to offer preferential access to overseas education facilities for students and entry into Australia if necessary which, it seemed, he sought in relation to the application of Chang Jnr. How Mr Symons was so confident that through his connections he was able to fix these things would also have to be looked at by this inquiry. How he was able to at least in part fund the venture, which seemed to be basically a business migration scheme—notwithstanding what Senator Evans just said to the Senate—with Austrade support through an export marketing development grant also requires proper investigation. We regard it as insufficient for Senator Evans to simply come in here and say that he has looked at the documents and we should have no reason for concern, particularly in light of the fact that Symons seems to have been the beneficiary of a number of such grants, as has his associates.

The way that Mr Symons was to use the export of education services may turn out to be the basis for legitimate claims for EMDGs, but that is something that will have to be investigated. We would seek the report of the judicial officer to be appointed in due course.

It was thus a scam involving a lot of money that had the potential to draw in much more but for the skills of the migration officer in Suva. It was a project developed in Australia and promoted by Australians, and is an international embarrassment to this country. That Australian officials were drawn into it to facilitate the scheme at the request of the most powerful within the Australian Government is particularly worrying. At least one Australian citizen lost a large sum of money, and it seems that some of the funds may have filtered back into Australia through a series of bank accounts in Hong Kong. However, since they have returned to Australia, they have not been able to be traced further.

The Australian people have a right to know the true story and the full story. So far, the picture of this Government has basically been one of obstruction. If the Government had nothing to hide, it would have instituted an independent inquiry weeks ago. But in this matter there is the issue of the mates of the New South Wales Right. Mr Keating is a mate, which is why he will fight this inquiry tooth and nail. Never mind getting to the truth and demonstrating to the Australian people that they can have faith in ministerial standards; never mind protection for the innocent and those at the moment who have no voice, such as the public servants who are not being permitted to put their side of the story by Senator Evans; and never mind Australia's international reputation in the United States, Taiwan and the Marshall Islands. The protection of his mates is more important to this Prime Minister. That is why the Parliament must persist until the Government is forced to meet its national responsibility. That is why the Parliament must insist on accountability.

If I had time, I would look specifically at the role of the Foreign Minister in relation to this matter, much of which is incidental to the primary case that is to be investigated by this inquiry. However, bearing in mind that we on this side have been limited to a speaking time of half an hour in this debate, and to be fair to my three colleagues who intend to use the last 15 minutes allotted to us, I will not do it on this occasion. I will use the occasion to mention to the Foreign Minister that I am looking forward to quoting to him in the very near future many parts of his 1982 speeches on ministerial standards and the Westminster system and to put them into the context of his deficiencies in this matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to try to persuade the Senate that it should reject this proposal to set up a judicial inquiry into certain aspects of ministerial conduct relating to the Marshall Islands affair. I do so because, whilst Senator Coulter has tried to cloak this exercise as a very noble one and has attempted to have a goal or an aim of ensuring the proper functioning of the Westminster system so that we might have confidence in ministerial conduct—he talked about the need for codes of ministerial conduct—this is being pursued for sheer political advantage.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter knows that the matter is running out of steam within both this chamber and the general community. In order to keep the matter running through the winter months, he has determined that we should have a forum which will probably generate some adverse publicity for the Government but will certainly, he hopes, keep himself in the limelight. It seems to me quite extraordinary that, of all people, Senator Coulter should, as I say, try to cloak this exercise in the garb of independent judicial inquiry as though that had some particular aura when he and the Australian Democrats were guilty of the most outrageous denials of natural justice to Senator Richardson in the weeks leading up to the current couple of weeks of the sitting of the Senate.

A headline in the Australian of 16 May stated, `Senate threat to muzzle Richardson'. The Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Coulter, announced his verdict before Senator Richardson had prepared and lodged his written report to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Senator Coulter announced his verdict in advance of giving Senator Richardson an opportunity to be heard. The most elementary principle of natural justice is that a person should be heard in his own defence before a verdict is pronounced. For Senator Coulter to come in here with this holier than thou attitude and say that we need to have this type of inquiry seems to me to be totally subverted—it was certainly put into perspective by the conduct of the Democrats in the lead-up to this fortnight of the parliamentary sittings. In fact, I find it quite incredible. It is no surprise that the Opposition has been tempted to support this exercise precisely for the reason that there is political advantage to be gained.

I would have thought it is at least incumbent on the Democrats to discharge a fairly heavy onus of proof to convince this chamber that there is a need for a judicial inquiry as opposed to the ordinary processes of the Parliament which allows ministerial responsibility to the chamber or the Parliament as a whole. Basically, all Senator Coulter said was that there are rumours around the corridors which need to be chased down—there are suspicions, there are allegations, there are matters which are spoken of in mutterings and grumblings; misgivings are being expressed and suspicions are being voiced. He said—and I wrote these words down—that there are rumours around the corridors. Of course, Senator Coulter admitted that nothing may be found.

This is a fishing expedition. The inquiry would be set up simply in order to see whether there is any more dirt. That is what it is all about. There is nothing more to it than that. We have not heard what the rules of evidence will be but, presumably, they will not be those that are strictly applied in a criminal trial. All sorts of allegations will be made which will smear, distort and harm the reputation of individuals. The allegations may be answered by the end of the inquiry and, as Senator Coulter has said, in the end there may be nothing adverse to be found, nothing of substance to be reported on. In the meantime, the reputations of people will be destroyed. In so far as those reputations are blackened in the course of the inquiry, that may serve some political purpose. In fact, when the National Crime Authority was set up I decided that it ought to meet in private precisely so that the reputations of people would not be destroyed in the course of an inquiry.

If it were the case that the Government could be said to be guilty of frustrating an examination of relevant matters, of trying to impede, frustrate or obstruct Federal agencies from doing their duty in relation to these matters, there might be something to talk about. But Senator Hill himself has talked about how astute, skilful, uncorrupted and perceptive immigration officials were in rejecting applications based on the Multiplex letters, for example, to Suva.

Indeed, I might mention that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) has indicated that those letters ought to be the subject of the fullest inquiry by his departmental officials to see whether there was a prima facie case of breach of the law. The Multiplex executive has circulated a letter to all of us—which is his right, given the public controversy which has arisen. This ought to be welcomed. Certainly, it should assist in the investigation of these matters. Today Mr Hand decided to write to me asking that I bring the matter to the attention of the Australian Federal Police to investigate whether any offences have been committed against the Commonwealth. Of course, I have passed that on to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police. I table that document for the interest of honourable senators.

In relation to the Attorney-General's Department, once again the conversations which had been held between the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands and an officer in the Department have been chronicled in the Senate. In so far as the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands has forwarded certain material, that has in turn been sent on to the Australian Federal Police who have reported—and I think this has also been the subject of an answer in the Senate—that, on an examination of the papers, there was no particular offence against Commonwealth law disclosed. The Australian Federal Police had not thought that the materials and papers warranted referral to any other law enforcement agency in Australia. Nevertheless, the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands has sought to forward further material. We have provided him with a contact in the New South Wales police in so far as matters raised in the Marshall Islands might also indicate fraud in terms of New South Wales law.

So at every stage there has been the fullest cooperation by the Ministers—the Attorney and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs—and their officials in ensuring that everything is done with the highest degree of propriety. Therefore, there is nothing to justify an inquiry. There is no suggestion that Ministers or ministerial officers have stood in the way, obstructed or frustrated the proper parliamentary process of questioning relating to the various issues surrounding Mr Symons and the Marshall Islands.

Finally, I note that the second part of the motion speaks of the need for, and possible terms of, a code of ministerial conduct. It may well be—although, I do not say so—the judgment of this chamber or the other place that a code of ministerial conduct should be devised. I think it would be enormously difficult to construct a code of conduct in a way which was able to foresee every possible circumstance as the political life of the nation evolves. But if it were possible to construct such a code of conduct, it ought to be done by this place. The Senate should exercise its proper role as the body to which Ministers are responsible. To hand over that task to a judge or a QC, however eminent, seems to be a total abdication of duty on the part of senators in this place or members of the House of Representatives. If there is to be a code of ministerial conduct to make the requirements of ministerial responsibility clear so far as this chamber is concerned, let us take on that responsibility and do it ourselves. I think that could be done through the committees of the Senate.

Nothing has been brought forward by Senator Coulter which indicates that there is anything of substance which cannot be looked at, assessed or judged by the normal processes of this chamber—through Question Time or some other process. There is certainly nothing which Senator Coulter or the Opposition has said which discharges what I believe to be a heavy onus of proof to indicate what, in substance, would justify an independent judicial inquiry. Therefore, I ask the Senate to reject this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support all that my colleague Senator Hill has said with respect to the motion; indeed, I accept all that Senator Coulter said in moving the motion. I found Senator Evans and Senator Tate remarkably conciliatory and appearing to be full of sweetness and light in order to try, at the last minute, to pull the wool over the eyes of the rest of the chamber as to why we should not have this independent judicial inquiry.

PARA.TAB: In the five minutes available to me, there are five new matters that I wish to refer to. The first is the reference in the motion to an independent judicial inquiry to report within eight weeks. I take that as eight weeks from today, which would be 28 July. However, if it takes the Government two weeks to determine who is to conduct this inquiry and to see the inquiry genuinely launched, I suppose it could be some 10 weeks before it reported. This chamber would be gravely concerned and would voice that concern most loudly if, when we return on 16 June, this proposed resolution of the Senate has not been acted upon. I note that eight weeks from today is 28 July; eight weeks from 16 June, when we next sit after the week break, would be 11 August, one week before the Budget.

Reference is made to `report'. I believe that the report of that independent inquiry should be made public immediately. That means that it should be given immediately to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the Leader of the Australian Democrats, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, and, of course, to the Prime Minister as well.
Secondly, the Opposition has fully welcomed Senator Coulter's motion. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of the statement made by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) yesterday.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: 1 June 1992
GOVERNMENT MUST ESTABLISH JUDICIAL INQUIRY

The Opposition welcomes Senator Coulter's Notice of Motion calling on the Government to establish an independent judicial inquiry into Greg Symons' business activities and his connections with Ministers.

The Government should establish the judicial inquiry immediately to be conducted by a retired Judge or someone of equivalent status. The inquiry should have similar powers to those of a Royal Commission and Counsel assisting the Commissioner and should inquire into and report upon the following matters, all of which have been raised in the public domain:

the full extent of Mr Symons' relationship with Senator Richardson, Senator Sibraa, other Ministers, Senators, Members of Parliament and their offices including their knowledge of his business affairs in Australia and elsewhere
the knowledge and involvement of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Mr Symons' business activities in the Marshall Islands, the United States and elsewhere
the knowledge and involvement of AUSTRADE in awarding EMDG grants to Mr Symons, and related companies
the knowledge of the Attorney-General's Department concerning Mr Symons' activities in the Marshall Islands, Australia and elsewhere
the circumstances surrounding Mr Symons' business migration scheme to the Marshall Islands and to Australia and any offences which were committed in connection with such a scheme
the role played by Multiplex in Mr Symons' business migration activities and other business activities
the role of Rothwells in Mr Symons' business activities
the administration of Mr Symons' composition with his creditors

The government should consult immediately with the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in drawing up the final terms of reference for the inquiry and in the selection of the judicial appointee to conduct the inquiry.
The Marshall Islands affair has raised questions of the highest national importance. They go to the very heart of honesty and integrity in government.

It's time the Government co-operated in seeking answers to the many questions which have been raised regarding the involvement of Government Ministers and Office-holders, their offices and departments.

The dishonesty, incompetence and lack of effort displayed in the Government's handling of the entire affair are exactly the same characteristics which have created policy paralysis and prevented the Government from implementing policies to actually reduce the number of unemployed Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Thirdly, I wish to refer to Senator Coulter's preference for an independent judicial inquiry rather than a Senate inquiry. I understand, from the references he made, that it would avoid what he would see as the danger of overt politics. I make the assertion very genuinely—and I would in any circumstance—that the Senate committee system is one of the most undervalued means of inquiry in this nation. I believe that there is maturity in the Senate to conduct an inquiry like this very appropriately. For instance, Senator Tate was involved in a Senate inquiry into the conduct of a judge. He acted with maturity and on the basis of evidence in finding that there was a case to answer in the matter of Justice Murphy. If there was a select committee of the Senate on these terms of reference, we should expect maturity and the full forms of the Senate in the way in which that inquiry would be conducted. If the Government does not act upon this motion to be adopted today in the Senate, there will be no alternative—I put this to Senator Coulter—but for us then to move on 16 June that there be a Senate inquiry with similar terms of reference.

PARA.TAB: Fourthly, clearly the terms relating to an inquiry into the conduct and decisions of Ministers, ministerial staff and departmental officers do not exclude parliamentarians, business connections, such as export market development grants, overseas student programs, Multiplex, Rothwells, the details of Symons' bankruptcy, his creditors, the immigration applications and so on, all of which are part of the web which needs to be inquired into. Not only are the Marshall Islands and Taiwan concerned, but also Hong Kong and China.

Fifthly, all of the documents asked for by Senator Hill, myself, Senator Kemp, Senator Bishop and other honourable senators ought to be immediately required by the inquiry because we have not received all the documents that we have asked for of Senator Evans and of this Government. I believe that all the questions which are not yet answered ought to be immediately referred by that inquiry to the Government so that all of that information is available to the inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of my colleagues in relation to the motion moved by Senator Coulter. In the brief time available to me, there are a number of points that I wish to make. It was very clear from the remarks of both Senator Tate and Senator Gareth Evans that they really had not got to the nub of what I understand Senator Coulter was saying. Put simply, Senator Coulter has rightly expressed the greatest of concern about standards of government in this country and the standards of Ministers. It is very clear from the remarks of Senator Evans, and from recent remarks by Mr Keating in the other place, that the Government has accepted that Senator Richardson has resigned but it has made no particular judgment on those matters.

PARA.TAB: Dr Hewson asked Mr Keating in the other place yesterday whether he still stood by and had confidence in the statement that Senator Richardson had presented to him. I say to Senator Coulter that it is very clear that Mr Keating was very careful to duck that wording, saying that the question at this point, in view of the fact that Senator Richardson was no longer a Minister in this Government, was not relevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still relevant.

—It is still relevant. We read regularly in the press that it is hoped that, if by some mischance a Keating Government is re-elected in this nation, Senator Richardson expects to be given a Ministry. Yet we have no view from any of the Ministers who have spoken whether Senator Richardson's behaviour was appropriate—
—Or not.

—Or was not, as Senator Coulter says. It strikes me that what we are really looking at here is the whole nature of the standards of this Government. It is quite possible that Ministers in this Government and the Prime Minister do not see anything wrong with the behaviour of Senator Richardson. Senator Coulter said—I agree with him—that Mr Symons seemed to have extraordinary access to Senator Richardson, and he speculated whether we are not seeing yet another example of cronyism at work in the Labor Party. In order for this Parliament to reassert parliamentary standards and to re-assert proper standards of ministerial conduct, it is essential that an inquiry be undertaken to examine the issues which have been raised.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans spoke for a long time. Yet I felt that he barely touched on the matters that Senator Coulter raised. He said, `Where is the prima facie case for such an inquiry?'. I suggest to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there are a number of issues that clearly have to be examined by this inquiry. I wish to look at the prima facie case in relation to one issue. That issue touches on the words of Senator Coulter—whether there was extraordinary access by Mr Symons to a senior Minister in this Government. Let us look at what this extraordinary access was, and at the prima facie case that Senator Richardson was far too heavily involved in Mr Symons' activity.

First, there was the famous letter of reference—a letter of reference that we understand, from a variety of sources, was important in attempting to get the Marshall Islands business migration scheme off the ground, and it was shown to many people who subsequently became involved.

When things started to go sour, we had the famous phone call to the President of the Marshall Islands by Senator Richardson. It was an extraordinary event, which even Senator Evans has termed unprecedented. What sort of mate is Senator Richardson that he would involve Senator Evans in such activity? Then we had the extraordinary involvement of Senator Richardson's own office in the migration problem which emerged in relation to one of the investors in this scheme. Then we had other events such as the constant arrangement of meetings by Senator Richardson with people such as the US Ambassador, Mr Sembler, and the involvement of the President of the Senate, Senator Sibraa. During this time there were regular meetings by Senator Richardson with Mr Symons and, at times, Mr Finch.

I put to the chamber that the prima facie case has been effectively established. We need to have this particular inquiry to ensure that the full facts of this matter come out and to ensure that this Parliament has a strong view and puts a strong view to the Government and the people of Australia about the need for high standards in government.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
