PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 1 June, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That the report of Estimates Committee B be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991-92 and the motion moved by the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, for the report of Estimates Committee B to be adopted. When the Bill was last considered, the Committee was considering program 7 of the Department of Finance, which relates to the Australian National Audit Office. The question before the Chair is that the motion be agreed to.

—In relation to the building that was leased by the Curtin Foundation or the Australian Labor Party to the Australian National Audit Office, what is the value of the building or that part of the building that was the question of the lease?
—The only information available to the Commonwealth is the rental value of that part of the building occupied by the Audit Office, which is reflected in the lease.
—Senator McMullan does not have a value. What is the annual return on the lease? Perhaps I can work it out that way.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a matter for the Commonwealth; it a matter for John Curtin House Ltd. Our concern is the costs to the Commonwealth and an assessment as to whether it is good value for money for the Commonwealth. The relevant authorities have concluded that it is. The question of whether it is a good investment for the property owner is not a concern of the Commonwealth.

—I understand Senator McMullan's answer. I also understand that he is trying to get out of answering my question. I am trying to ascertain whether the Government, or the property group in this case, made a wise investment in taking on that building for a lease. It looks as though Senator McMullan is not prepared to disclose that.

PARA.TAB: On seeking information around Canberra, I have found that the average prime rental price in the CBD can range from $340 per square metre to $364 per square metre. The price can go up as high as $390 per square metre. It is very interesting to look at these figures because the Department of Administrative Services, say, four years ago was objecting strongly to paying $220 per square metre for offices in the CBD in Perth, and that was for a low square metreage.

I have also found out from my research around Canberra that rental increments are normally 7 per cent. The yield lies between 8 1/4 per cent to 10 per cent. I inquired specifically of the area where the Labor Party's building, which has been leased so conveniently to the National Audit Office, lies in Barton. The average rent for a new building is between $310 and $350 per square metre. The increment is 7 per cent and the yield is 8 1/4 to 10 per cent. Of course, this all depends on the quality of the building.

I disclose to the Committee that I have had a certain amount of experience in development—not with this size of project—and in obtaining tenants. I have never successfully obtained a government department; I have had to settle for people like Elders Ltd, ANZ Bank and that sort of ilk. From that experience, I have found that the more secure the tenant generally the lower the return will be on the dollar. I see that in relation to the building in Barton there is a yield of 8 1/4 to 10 per cent and an increment of 7 per cent, which is far short of the increment that is allowed in the contract.

I have also discovered that the length of lease varies in a new building. One looks to try to get as long a lease as possible. It seems that the maximum lease one can obtain in Barton is 10 years with an extension of five or 10 years. In this case, the Department has signed a contract at a 2 per cent increment above the common rate. Being a high security tenant like the Commonwealth Government, one would think that the increment would be below the average of 7 per cent, not above it. The Government has signed a contract at 9 per cent.

Senator McMullan will not tell me or give me an indication of the yield. That means that he is covering up the value of the building. It is no good the Parliamentary Secretary shaking his head. The Government has signed a first up lease of 15 years, which is unheard of. Someone has said that is akin to winning charities. I wish I could sign up a deal before I even got the project going with an increment of 9 per cent and with an unknown yield. If Senator McMullan will not tell me what the yield is, I presume that it is above these figures I have quoted here, that it is above the going rate.

What did the Government do? When did it look after the interests of the taxpayers of Australia? Nowhere in my living memory—and that is a reasonable length of time—have I found where one can pick up a 15-year lease with a five year option with a highly secure tenant and a big increment. That would produce a very big return on one's money. I take it that it is a big return on the money because I cannot get any indication from Senator McMullan of the yield.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not think there was a question.
—By the Minister's silence, I presume that he agrees with my statement.
—No.

—Senator McMullan should let me finish and then see whether he agrees with me instead of saying `No, no' and shaking his head as a few others do on the other side. He is agreeing with me that the Government has signed the lease for a term of at least five years above the norm. The normal term a property developer can hope to secure is 10 years with a 10-year option. I take it, by Senator McMullan's silence, that he is pleading guilty to signing a 15-year agreement, plus five years, which is far and above that which any private developer could hope to get in this city or any other city. I presume he pleads guilty to that.

PARA.TAB: I also presume that the Minister pleads guilty to signing a lease that returns to the landlord above the going rate. The yield on any property generally varies in inverse proportion to the risk taken and according to location. If one builds in Canberra, one expects a far lower return than if one builds out west of the Black Stump. Of course, there is a difference between building in Canberra, Sydney or Perth. One expects a return when one is secure in the knowledge that the tenant will pay rent at the end of the month. If my family company decided to put up a building in Canberra, then went around private industry in Canberra looking for a tenant, the tenants would say, `Your company is very secure in Canberra. Our money is fairly secure', and the return would be down. They would screw us further and further down. But here we have the Government signing a lease with an obviously far greater yield. By his silence the Minister has pleaded guilty to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't talk rubbish!
—I am not talking rubbish; I am talking from practical experience.
—You are making up—
—I am not making it up. That is accusing me of being a liar and I do not take kindly to that.
—You are making it up about me.

—I am not making it up about Senator McMullan; he is pleading guilty by his silence to signing an agreement for longer than the norm of 10 years. That is not normally done. When one signs a lease agreement for longer than five years in Western Australia one has to register it almost as though it was a land transfer. Senator McMullan has not denied extending the term.

PARA.TAB: I will return to yield. The yield to the Labor Party must be pretty good for Senator McMullan not to disclose it. Then there is the increment, and the security of having a tenant paying the money at the end of every month—or probably one month in advance, as it normally is. Perhaps Senator McMullan could tell us whether the rent is paid one month, three months or 12 months in advance. The increment is far greater than could be expected anywhere else. The Parliamentary Secretary is shaking his head again—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, no!

—He will not say why he has signed an agreement to an increment which is higher than it would be in the commercial field. I also understand—and please tell me if I am wrong—that the Department is doing its own fit-out, and I think a figure was mentioned for that. On my quick whip around Canberra this morning I also found out that even with prime buildings in prime areas there is a holiday incentive. If one goes to Perth one can get holiday incentives in new buildings—not second-hand buildings or buildings that have been up for 10 years—of up to 12 months holiday. Of course, the Tax Commissioner made sure that he extracted his share of it. Even around Canberra there are some incentives with new buildings, such as fit-outs and holidays. If there is one, I do not think Senator McMullan has disclosed it here. Will Senator McMullan answer my questions or will he plead guilty to all three charges?

—Order! Before I call Senator McMullan, I suggest that to continually say that an honourable senator is pleading guilty is very close to a personal reflection. I ask honourable senators to keep that in mind.
—If Senator McMullan objects to that terminology—
—Senator Panizza, would you take your seat. I was giving some advice, which is an indication that I object to it as Chairman.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason I did not respond to Senator Panizza is that there was not a question. In view of the time that we have already taken on this matter, it does not appear to me to be very useful to be making speeches backwards and forwards. Senator Panizza chose to wrongly interpret the situation, so I regret that I have to respond briefly.

PARA.TAB: The appropriateness of the increment was dealt with adequately by Senator Bolkus who provided the relevant information. With regard to the fit-out and incentives, the tenant will have rent-free occupation during fit-out and a $400,000 payment from the lessor, both factors, as far as I know, which were disclosed previously. It is not a matter for the Commonwealth to determine the return for landlords—

TALK.START.PARA: —What on earth are you talking about? You are one and the same. The Commonwealth Government is the Labor Party.
—Order! Senator Walters.

—Just this once, Mr Chairman, a little tolerance with that interjection would have been helpful. To have such ignorance exposed so magnificently is helpful to everybody. There is a very significant distinction, the proprieties of which have been scrupulously observed by the officers who have made these decisions. To conclude that they have made decisions—we are not talking about ministerial decisions, but decisions made by responsible officers—
—Senator Walters is correct.
—They are not in charge of their departments. What rubbish!

—If Senator Walters assumes that all actions are taken by people with corrupt motives, she should think about why she comes to that conclusion. Here we have honest public servants making decisions about what they think is in the public interest and acting accordingly. All of us, when we make decisions about what we think is in the public interest, because we are paid by the taxpayers, are entitled to be scrutinised about whether we got it right, but it is not correct to reflect upon the motives of everybody.

PARA.TAB: I was intending to be helpful about the return. If Senator Walters would be quiet for a minute I will help her colleague. The value of the building is not a matter for the Commonwealth to know. I do not know the value of buildings which other bodies for which I have some responsibility are leasing. I know how much rent is being paid, and that is all I know. Senator Bishop said that the building was costing $80m. I do not know whether that figure is correct but that is the figure that she gave. Those opposite should do some calculations based on that figure and work out the return for themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe for one moment that, unless there are a lot of other tenants, even the Labor Party would put up a building for $80m and then lease it out for the figure that has been mentioned.
—It is not my figure Senator Panizza; it is Senator Bishop's figure.

—All right. I conclude by saying that I deduce from Senator McMullan's answers that if the Government is prepared to give away an increment that is higher than the norm for a term far higher than the norm, then it is time that the Department found itself some better negotiators in this depressed market.
—How can they?

—That is for Senator McMullan to answer. As in the Amman Aviation case of a few years ago, which related to surveillance of the north coast and which finished in a shambles, the Department went into the matter with negotiators who probably should have been in third grade rather than in first grade when dealing with the money of the Commonwealth of Australia, which is the taxpayers' money.

—Senator McMullan mentioned that the figure I used in the early debates on this matter was $80m. That was the figure that was circulating on the rumour mill. More information has come to hand. As Senator McMullan refused to tell us the value of the building, I have talked to people, such as Senator Panizza and others who are knowledgeable about yields on buildings, and their estimate is that a yield in the vicinity of 8 per cent—which is perhaps better than some would hope in the circumstances of the `recession that we had to have'—would place the value of the building in the vicinity of $20m to $23m for the cost of developing the site.

PARA.TAB: There are a few other questions that we have to settle. Firstly, the date of the agreement to lease is 23 April 1992. This whole negotiation commenced in 1990. I want to know the precise date on which the first sod was turned in the development of the site known to the Audit Office as the `Lend Lease site yet to be named'—I suspect this was after the agreement to lease was signed.
Secondly, once one has such a lease, with an annual income of $1.92m per year and with a 9 per cent increment over 20 years—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 10.5 per cent until completion.

—Exactly. It is 10.5 per cent, as Senator Parer says, until completion. We are talking about an enormous sum of money. Just multiplying $1.92m by 15 years without adding in any of the increments, we get nearly $30m. Once one has an agreement like that—
—All into the Labor Party pockets.

—It all goes into the Labor Party pockets, because what one now has is a bankable document. Senator McMullan and his ilk—Mr Hogg, Senator Faulkner, who was good enough to declare what we have called pecuniary interests, and all of those sitting opposite—have an interest and it will all pay for their campaign.

PARA.TAB: We know that Senator Loosley bought a building for $3.8m and it is now worth only $1.6m; and that the New South Wales Labor Party has debts of $9m. We know that they are in trouble. But here we have a bankable document. The Labor Party can go to the bank and borrow money. If it has borrowed the money from Lend Lease—and I do not know whether it has borrowed the money from Lend Lease to build the building—it can service that borrowing out of the $1.92m annual rental and still have money left over to repay any money which it borrows from the bank for the purposes of running elections.

All of that is a nice commercial transaction which is not caught under any of the legislation which would require disclosure. If the amending legislation that the Government proposes to bring into this chamber gives it open slather until 30 June, it will not have to disclose this at all because it will have it all sown up before 30 June. For the Parliamentary Secretary to sit there and say that we are in fairytale land when we say that there is something very smelly about this deal is for him simply to deny reality. It stinks; it really stinks.

As I said before, there is evidence in all the documents given to us by the Government that the Audit Office did not know that the Labor Party was the landlord and that it would be its next-door neighbour in the same building until such time as the Audit Office was committed to the building. I do not know that the Department of Finance ever knew. The Parliamentary Secretary has told us that Mr Willis knew on 3 February. But what about his Department?

TALK.START.PARA: —Who do you think told him?

—I do not know; I really do not know. I want impartial evidence that is contemporaneous with that event—not a minute like the one of Mr Ireland's which was done yesterday or today or whenever it was. I want proper evidence that that in fact occurred, because I am afraid that just the Parliamentary Secretary's say-so is not credible. We have had lots of `say-sos' from Senator Evans; we have had lots of `say-sos' from Senator Richardson; we have had Ros Kelly down in the other place saying, `I didn't—

PARA.TAB: So now we have an anonymous note—not backed up by any contemporaneous notes—which the Parliamentary Secretary says came from the Department of Finance, that somehow the Department of Finance was told at some mysterious meeting that it knew the landlord was the ALP. Nothing was said about this whenever there was an opportunity to talk about the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I query the deal that was made. I ask for some reconciliation between the deal made to locate the Audit Office in ALP House and other similar arrangements made in adjacent areas in Barton. I will touch very briefly on the ALP lease. The lease between the Audit Office and John Curtin Limited is to run for 15 years. The cost of $280 per square metre is retrospective to 1 January 1991 and is able to escalate at the rate of 10.5 per cent until completion and thereafter at the rate of 9 per cent for the balance of 15 years. In addition, the owner, John Curtin Ltd, has the right, I think at the end of five years—I do not have the papers with me—to go to market price and the rent then applicable would be the highest of the market price or the escalatable figure. I think Senator Panizza raised the point: is this a good deal or is it a normal commercial transaction with a query on it?

PARA.TAB: In Barton there is another place called Tourism House. That building was recently let to the newly created Environment Protection Agency. This organisation has taken up three of the floors covering an area of about 3,850 square metres compared with, say, the 6,000 square metres for John Curtin Ltd. I would just like the view of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) on the comparison between the two. ALP-John Curtin Ltd has a lease of $280 per square metre, plus outgoings of $45,325; Tourism House has a gross rental of $306 per square metre. The escalation rate of rent at Tourism House is 3 per cent in line with the CPI compared with 10.5 per cent until completion and then 9 per cent for balance of the 15 years. Tourism House has two-yearly reviews to market—which is what I understood has always been the norm in the renting of premises by the Federal Government. Also, tenants are not responsible for all outgoings, as is the case with John Curtin, but for increases in rates of taxes over the base year.

Apart from the point I raised late last night about the propriety of an incumbent government even allowing government departments to go into premises owned by their own political Party—and that is a different matter which I hope will be the subject of further discussion later—was this a special deal or a normal commercial deal? I have pointed out here that we have two quite distinct leases, both of them involving government departments—one of them involving the Audit Office going into premises owned by the Australian Labor Party and the other one going into premises of which I do not know the owner.

I do not think the rentals themselves are a major problem. It is the escalation factors that apply over such a long period of time which can blow out the rentals to such an extent that, if inflation keeps down the way we all hope it does over the next five to 10 years, if we can entrench low inflation in this country, the Auditor-General or the Australian National Audit Office will pay rentals far in excess of that which everyone else pays in the city of Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to support the remarks of my colleague Senator Parer, could I ask very specifically of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) the following questions relating to the so-called meeting held on 25 June 1991. PARA.TAB: Who are the directors and shareholders of John Curtin House Ltd? It would be most interesting to see whether the terms and conditions are similar to those for the Australian National Audit Office.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one final question on that. I will accept Senator McMullan seeking this information and providing it to me. He did mention that he thought Tourism House was not a new building. I remind him that Tourism House was completed in December 1991, which is really not so long ago; it is less than six months old. Why do we have a building which, on the face of it, appears to be more than generous—15 years and all those other things, which I will not go over again now—and then very close by premises which are somewhat similar although smaller in space? SPEECH.PARA: Veterans' Affairs—Additional Estimates Committee of the Whole
Program 1—Determining System

Mr Hawker, when asked whether the Department had looked at fundamental reforms of the determining system, replied that this was something which constantly occupied the Department's attention but so far it had been unable to come up with reform which it considers would be acceptable to the ex-service community.
Does this mean that reform initiatives have been considered and developed to some extent but dropped because it was thought they could not satisfy the ex-service community?
If this is the case can you outline the nature of some of these initiatives?
If not, does this mean that despite the occupation of its attention, the Department has not even got to first base in considering how the determining system could be reformed?
Mr Hawker also highlighted a consultants report on evaluation documents. Have each of the recommendations been responded to? If not all, which ones?
In discussing some of the things the Department is currently doing with respect to the claims system the Compensation Claims Processing System was briefly referred to.
Mr Hawker indicated it would be installed later this year.
Where will it be installed and will there be a trial period before wider application?
What improvements in quality of decisions and processing time could veterans expect from this System?
Has a cost-benefit analysis been done for the System?
Has there been any assessment of the impact it will have on application numbers and success rates?
How much has so far been spent on developing the system? How much more money will be required before it is completed?
How does the new System address the fundamental problem of providing all available information at the first level?
Over time and with wider applications of knowledge-based systems such as the CCPS, will the National Computer Centre be made redundant?
Is it true that the CCPS offers the potential to distribute the processing of claims outside the DVA office environment?
Has the Department considered, for instance, bringing the System to ex-service organisation locations and allowing ex-service welfare officers to operate the system?
What implications would this have for quality control? Would this mean that the RSL, for instance, could act as gatekeepers to pension assessment for its own members?

Can I finish my questions on the determining system by asking for a clarification of an answer to a question I put on notice concerning staff in the income support and compensation branches required for first level determinations. As well as the total I was hoping to obtain the numbers for each branch, and wonder if this could be provided?
Program 2—Integration

During Estimates last November I was provided with a State by State breakdown of the number of private hospitals (and their bed capacity) with which the Department had a contract as at September 1991.
Is a more up to date list available?
If it is could I please be provided with the list, and could I also have the total number of private hospitals in each State, as well as those with which the Department has an arrangement?
What is the present situation with respect to the transfer of RGH Concord?
Is it not the case that the Government was expecting to announce in principle agreement before now?
Does the Government still have a target date of 1st October for the transfer?
What will be the nature of the consultations engaged in by Brian Howe in order to smooth the troubled political waters in NSW?
What role will the Minister for Veterans' Affairs have in these consultations?

Can the Minister confirm that the Commonwealth is offering funding to the New South Wales Government for the treatment of veterans following integration of $135 million in 1992/93, $180 million in 1993/94, $165 million in 1994/95, $149 million in 1995/96 and $137.5 million in 1996/97?
Is the Commonwealth seeking an undertaking from the State to provide 340,000 bed days for veterans in NSW?
Has this been achieved, and does this mean that these bed days will be private bed days in public hospitals effectively paid for over the next five years by the amounts I have just quoted?
Is it true that as late as last month negotiations between the NSW Government and the Commonwealth had not resolved the future size and activity levels at Concord?
Is it true that arrangements surrounding the number of staff to be transferred were, as at last month, still not finalised?
Have each of these since been finalised?
Will payments made by the Commonwealth associated with integration be quarantined from the Grants Commission process?
Has the Government received a response from the Premier of Tasmania to its representations on the transfer of Hobart RGH following the election of the Groom Government?
Can the Minister advise of the amounts to be paid to the Tasmanian Government, the period over which payments will be made, and how many bed days have been paid for veterans and war widows?
I refer to an answer to a question on notice concerning prior approval and the costs associated with its removal following integration.
The answer states that it would be expensive during the transitional phase because the Commonwealth would be paying twice—to the States via transitional funding and to the private sector.

Would it be possible, if prior approval were removed, to adjust grants to the States under the Grants Commission arrangements to reflect such removal and so avoid the Commonwealth paying twice in the transitional phase?
Program 3—War Graves

During questioning on the cost of work completed at the Rookwood Garden of Remembrance I asked Mr Heggen the final cost. First of all it was given as $6.468 million. It was stated that this included a $2.68 million management charge for the Australian Construction Services.

A little later on, however, Mr Heggen quoted further figures. He said the original contract awarded to Girvan was $3.09 million and the additional cost of re-letting the contract was $3.11 million, making the total cost some $6.2 million. However, this time he said the ACS management charge should be added to this.
Which version is correct, since, if the latter is true, the total cost has been blown out by a further $2.68 million?
Program 4—Military Compensation Scheme
Can you tell me how many members of operational peace-keeping forces, non-operational peacekeeping forces and members of the Defence Forces are currently provided compensation under the VEA?
What is the present number of each who could be provided protection under the VEA?
On what basis, in the written answer provided, is the assertion made that "a separate Military Compensation Scheme would have a relatively minor impact on DVA in the short term"?
What is considered to be the "short term"?
What is a "relatively minor" impact?
What are the cost savings expected for the Department in the long term from a separate Military Compensation Scheme?

Mr Lyon at the Committee referred to the question of whether a new Military Compensation Scheme should allow for the continuation of existing arrangements under the VEA or whether personnel should be taken up totally in the context of a new Military Compensation Scheme. What advice has DVA presented to Defence in this regard?
Mr Lyon also indicated that estimates had been provided to Defence on questions relating to the Military Compensation Scheme. What were these questions and what has been the advice provided?
What does the Department consider to be the pros and cons for each of the options relating to a compensation scheme for defence personnel?
For the questions taken on notice today could I have the Minister's assurance that he will ensure that those answers are not "Yes Minister" ones this time?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee will move to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. Are there any questions on program 1, health advancement?
—I have a general question that relates to division 330 in Appropriation Bill (No. 3).

—It does not come into the reservations but it does impinge on both Estimates Committee E and Estimates Committee F. For that reason, I seek leave to raise this question at this point in time.
—You can seek leave, but it is not in accordance with the general way that we approach the Estimates.

—I realise that. It relates directly to a line item in the Bill, specifically division 330, administrative; at No. 4, health advancement; item 04, health research. Therefore it is not peripheral to the Bill but directly concerns specific figures in the Bill.
—Is this the matter in which you may wish to move for a request?
—That is correct.

—This is the first time this has occurred. It is important that I get some words down to explain my approach—which will be quite satisfactory to you, Senator Tierney, I am sure, but it is necessary that it be on the record. I understand that Senator Tierney may move for a request for an amendment to the Bill which does not arise from any of the matters recommended for further consideration in the report of the Estimates committees.

PARA.TAB: The order under which the Senate is currently operating in relation to Appropriation Bills provides that debate in Committee of the Whole must be confined to such matters recommended for further consideration in Estimates committee reports. The order also provides, however, that this limitation on debate does not prevent the moving of any amendment or request. On a strict interpretation of the order, an amendment or request which does not arise from a matter recommended for further consideration in an Estimates committee report may not be debated. This, however, whilst in accordance with the relevant order, would prevent an honourable senator explaining any amendment or request which he or she wishes to move.

I consider that the best solution is to permit debate on the request, but I ask senators speaking to it to confine their remarks strictly to the purpose of the request. I point out to honourable senators that the problem which arises here would be overcome if the Senate were to adopt changes to procedures as recently recommended by the Committee on Procedure. The situation, Senator Tierney, is that you probably want to ask some questions before you consider whether you are actually going to move for the request. In a similar vein, I would ask you to do that now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I think all senators will wish to have a look at your ruling, which I naturally accept has been made with all your learning obviously in an attempt to encourage the proper working of this chamber. Nevertheless, it seems to me that we are reaching a situation where, if a senator has not made a reservation, he or she can get around that particular situation by then making a request and somehow fall within the Chair's grace in terms of being permitted to put questions and deal with matters which were not the subject of reservation. It seems to me that we are getting into a way of operating these Estimates committees whereby we are moving well outside the intention of those who tried—in order to save time and to give fair notice—to confine the Committee of the Whole to those matters which were unresolved in the Estimates committee meeting and which needed some further elaboration or proper answers to be given. That proposal came forward from the Committee on Procedure, of which the President was the Chair, in order to try to hasten the passage of the Appropriation Bills through the Committee of the Whole. Naturally, Mr Chairman, I accept your ruling, but I put in that cautionary note. Senators and Ministers will certainly want to look at the ruling and perhaps reserve the right to reflect on it—without reflecting on you—at a later date.

—I think it will emerge that the reason for a request in this instance has some substance and basis to it. I think the matter you have raised, Mr Chairman, and the way you have dealt with it is something that should be looked at by the Standing Committee on Procedure, and, if appropriate, I will move that the matter be looked at by that Committee at its next meeting.

—Basically, if I can put it in lay terms, under the procedures under which we are working, we normally look at matters in the reports or matters which are subject to reservation, but that does not mean that a senator cannot move for a request to go to the House of Representatives in relation to the actual Bill. This is not covered properly in the Standing Orders. I am suggesting that, after we have looked at the procedure report that is currently before this chamber, and which I believe will be looked at on the first sitting day in August, if the recommendation in it is accepted, this matter will not occur again.

PARA.TAB: Senator Reid, I do not mind sending things off to the Procedure Committee—I quite often do it myself—but it might be better to wait until after the Senate considers the Procedure Committee's report which is front of us. If that is accepted, there will be no need to send the matter off. I can assure the Minister that I have seen a copy of the proposed request. I am not sure at this stage whether Senator Tierney will move it or not, but the request would be in order. The procedures that I have suggested for this afternoon would cover that completely. I will make a copy of my statement available.

TALK.START.PARA: —The circumstance in which I move this is unusual. Senator Tate is expressing the fear that this might become a new procedure in the chamber. The reason why it comes up at this time relates to a rather unusual circumstance in public administration, where funding from one particular department—which normally comes out of one allocation—is being switched to another department. For that reason, the money has moved across to the Estimates committees. It is a very unusual circumstance and it raises some very serious questions. Therefore, as the item of funding is located in this Bill, I would like to raise questions at this point. I will also be raising questions later with the Department of Employment, Education and Training, which is the other department affected by this allocation of money.

—My question is a general question and relates to division 330 of Appropriation Bill (No. 3). I seek your guidance, Mr Chairman, because we need a fairly specific answer on a fairly technical matter. Do you wish for this matter to be left until the advisers arrive in about 10 minutes time? If so, I would seek leave to continue my remarks at that point.

—The problem that we will face is that not only might the Minister not know, but also the advisers might not know because the correct advisers may not be here. —I think that is a sound indication of what we should do. We should at least try to get the questions on the record now and we might have time to think about them. —Would you like to wait until the advisers arrive?
—No. Let us hear the questions.

—I note the Minister's remarks. It was not a matter of discourtesy; it was a matter that, because these appropriations did cover two departments, I was unaware—being on the DEET committee—where the money should have been allocated which was being allocated through this particular appropriation. TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Walters's observation—which lies behind her raising this—that matters which are designed for an Australian audience ought to be culturally appropriate. It may well be that, whilst the statement is factually correct, an element—I am speaking as a lay person—of the incidence of death from AIDS of females under 35 in New York city can probably be attributed at least in some part to the use of needles rather than heterosexual activity. In that situation, one would wonder whether it was a totally transferable image to the Australian cultural and social situation. To that extent, the point raised by Senator Walters is valid and ought to be taken into account in the preparation of these educational videos, though it would be true to say that the statement itself is factually correct.

—I am not querying whether the statement is factual, even though the Minister has just indicated that it is. In the other video there is a similar statement that over 60 per cent of all HIV infections worldwide have been acquired by heterosexual intercourse. In Australia we have no figures for this. We have debated in our committee many times that we have no figures on heterosexual vaginal intercourse in Australia—that is, leaving out heterosexual anal intercourse. Knowing the figures for anal intercourse, it could not possibly fit in with the 60 per cent. What on earth is the purpose of the Department putting out these sorts of statements that have nothing to do with women contracting AIDS through heterosexual intercourse in Australia?

PARA.TAB: These two videos were entirely on the use of condoms. The videos involved women persuading their partners to use condoms for safe sex. As we commented in our report, there was never any indication in both those videos that condoms may be fallible. Again, I query the videos put out by the Department to women in Australia. I see no bearing in the comments in the videos on the Australian situation.

For heaven's sake, if the Department does not want to lose credibility, it should talk about the incidence of these events in Australia. Let us explain to the women of Australia what sorts of risks they run without exaggeration, because they will know if the facts are exaggerated and the Department will lose all credibility.
