TALK.START.PARA: —The officers with me say that there is some contractual arrangement with somebody to put material into what are euphemistically called `conveniences'. The officers do not immediately recognise the name of the organisation. Could Senator Walters tell us again?
—It is called Conveniences Advertising (Aust) Pty Ltd, 2nd Floor, 15 Niagara Lane, Melbourne. The phone number is (03) 670 3141. If the Minister wants its fax number, I have that too.

—We will see whether that is the organisation with which the Department contracts in order to ensure that the material is placed in these conveniences. We will take the question on notice and give Senator Walters a full reply.
—I would appreciate that. I have a few questions arising from that. I would like to know the cost of the contract to those people.
—If you put them on notice we will answer them for you.

—I do not want to write them down; I will ask them now, if I may. I would like to know the cost of the contract and to whom they go. I believe that it also sends out a quarterly or half-yearly amount of money to these conveniences—whatever they happen to be—to enable them to hang notices of what is being produced on the wall. These conveniences are paid a fair amount of money every quarter to hang these pictures or words on the wall.
—Are they well hung, Senator?

—I think we had better cut that out. My imagination is going a bit too far. Could the Minister advise as to what this advertising company is meant to be doing, the cost of it to the Government and over what period of time it has been contracted. The company seems to be sending out these amounts to all of these conveniences so that they can re-hang the pictures and messages quarterly. It is unbelievable stuff—you have to see it to believe it.
—I don't visit them.

—I know the Minister does not; I do not either. I am sent some stuff every now and then. I am sure that the Minister would have seen the magazine entitled Information Exchange. What is the cost of producing it? It is very flashy. What was the cost of sending it out?
—I thought `convenience' was a euphemism for a public toilet. It is convenience stores.
—The Minister used the word `convenience'; I just named the business—Conveniences Advertising.
—We will find out the cost of that publication for Senator Walters and provide her with an answer.

—I would also like to know how many copies of the magazine were sent out and the total cost of that. I refer also to the pamphlets for teachers and youth workers which the Department has sent me. One is entitled, `Homosexuality: a pamphlet series for teachers and youth workers'. What was the cost of that?
—I understand that that was put out by the Tasmanian group; it was not funded by the Department.
—So there was no funding by the Commonwealth at all?
—It came out of the matched funding moneys, but it is not something for which the Department is specifically responsible.
—So Richard Hale, for the pamphlet producers, has nothing to do with it?
—No.
—We will move to program 6.1, on which Senator Walters has a reservation.

—I asked for copies of letters which had been sent to the health Ministers of various States regarding patient election. Mr Chairman, for your information, I am referring to when a patient goes to a public hospital. People should be able to elect whether they go in as a private patient or, if they do not have private insurance, as a public patient. Whether they have insurance or not, they ought to be able to go in as they choose. I have been sent only two letters from the ministerial side of that. Could the Department let me know why I have been sent only two letters?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —On page E221 of the Hansard of Estimates Committee E, Senator Walters states:

SPEECH.PARA: I particularly asked for a copy of the correspondence with the States and Territories at departmental level in February 1989, at ministerial level in March 1989 . . .

I think that has been provided to Senator Walters. That is the one common letter, if I can put it that way. There was also one from the Tasmanian counterpart in July 1990 which has been provided to Senator Walters. Senator Walters finished by asking, `Could I have a copy of the correspondence?'. I think the Department took that to be what she was asking for, in that some other dates are mentioned in the relevant paragraph on page E221. I think some examination could be undertaken of those dates, but it would take some time. I think it is a fair reading of that request that Senator Walters asked for those particular items of correspondence which have been provided. In other words, it was not a different letter sent to every Minister; the same letter was sent. Senator Walters received a master copy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter I received—the letter from the Department to Mr Groom in Tasmania—was the master copy that was sent to all Ministers of the Territories and other States.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that one is a departmental letter and the other is the ministerial letter, so you have them both. They were sent to each of the departments or Ministers concerned in the same format.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The departmental letter says:

SPEECH.PARA: The States' proposal is accepted and the clause under contention has been removed from the draft.

What was that clause that was under contention? The Minister must have known that I would ask that question because that was in the departmental letter. I cannot believe that the Minister could send me that and not expect me to ask a question on it. The Minister certainly would.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was anticipating it, but I am afraid that the officials have been taken by surprise. No doubt, they can find out over the dinner break.

—I thank the Minister. There was also a specific letter to the Hon. J.C. White when he was Minister for health. I have not received the letter that Mr White sent the Department, but in answer to that letter the Department says:

SPEECH.PARA: Your recent letter regarding the impasse reached between Tasmania and the Health Benefits Council (HBC) recommended that I write a firmly worded letter to certain Tasmanian health insurance funds threatening them with the exercise of certain of my powers under Part VI A of the National Health Act 1953.
Whilst I acknowledge that the conduct of HBC members may not be entirely exemplary, I consider the use of Part VI A procedures to be an over-reaction.
He means an over-reaction by Mr White. The letter continues:

This is particularly so as those funds could rightly point to Tasmania's rather less than exemplary performance of its obligations under the Hospital Funding Agreement made pursuant to section 23F of the Health Insurance Act 1973 . . .
Then it goes on to say:

Clause 4.3(c) of the Medicare Agreement requires Tasmania to ensure both that a patient is made aware of his right to be a public patient and that he makes an election to be either a public or private patient.
I am reading only parts of the letter. It goes on:

I am informed that the most blatant practice seems to be that of handing patients the proforma statement whilst asking them if they are privately insured. If they say they are insured, they are admitted as private patients without an election being obtained.
He says that he is advised that this is being undertaken in Tasmanian hospitals. That is the gist of it. The letter continues:

Under the Medicare Agreement, the penalty for Tasmania's failure to fulfil its obligations under clause 4.3(c) is a reduction of its base grant equal to the benefits accruing to Tasmania . . . In the present case, I assume that would be a substantial part of those $300,000 you mention in your letter.
In all the circumstances, I am of the opinion that in the interests of patients and contributors, this matter is best settled by negotiation between Tasmania and the HBC.

It seems to me that Tasmania was breaking the law in the way it was handling patients' elections as they went into public hospitals. The Minister will remember that I gave him my personal experience of going to hospital as an accident patient and not being given any opportunity to say how I wanted to be admitted into that hospital. When I said that I was privately insured I was automatically admitted as a private patient. Could the Minister tell me whether any action was taken against Tasmania in this incidence because it was breaking the law?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —We can get a definitive answer over the dinner break as to whether any action was taken other than an administrative reminder of the need to abide by the law. As Senator Walters would appreciate, not all maladministration or failure to perform according to a required standard requires the full panoply of prosecution in these things. It is a matter of trying to remedy the situation. It may have been that administrative measures were taken or suggested. I recall that they were the subject of considerable and enlightening discussion at the committee. I think it was quite a useful exchange on that matter of the necessity of those who are responsible for taking patients into a public hospital to alert them to their right to be admitted in one category or another. As to Senator Walters's specific question, we will try to find an answer.
—Were any similar letters written to any other States?

—We do not know of any recent ones. There may have been in the past, but we will try to establish that as well. That may take a bit of a search; we may not be able to get it during the dinner break. We will take it on notice.

—I know that there have been the same accusations in other States and there has been a problem with other funds making the same accusations. Could the Minister give me the date of that letter? I cannot read it.
—All we can say is that it is July 1990; we cannot pick the actual day.
—That is near enough. Does the Minister have any evidence of a statistical link between bulk billing and the increase in the number of services ordered by pathologists?
—Is that the only question?
—No, that is the main one. Do the officers have that information?
—Not in the next 40 seconds but we will try to get Senator Walters an answer.

—Order! The Committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991-92 and the motion moved by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, for the report of Estimates Committee E to be adopted. When the Bill was last considered, the Committee was considering program 6 of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. We are currently on program 6.1. The question is that the motion be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a Department of Finance officer drafting something for me to answer Senator Tierney, which I think will be satisfactory. Obviously, I prefer him to complete that draft before I launch out on a reply. So perhaps we might return to some of Senator Walters's questions, to some of which an answer can be advanced; others require more information to be obtained.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the evidence of a statistical link between bulkbilling and the level of pathology services, I am advised that the Department does not have evidence of such a link. Dr Deeble's analysis for the national health strategy, contained in his background paper on pathology, shows that there is no relationship. The Department is currently undertaking further analysis in conjunction with the Australian Association of Pathology Practices on this matter under specifications agreed with the Australian Association of Pathology Practices. The preliminary analysis shows that there is no relationship. The report of this work should be published in about one month.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Minister. And the Department is sure of that?

—That is the advice I have. As to patient election, letters to State counterparts, et cetera, 3 February, 1989, Senator Walters first asked about details of the clause removed, which is referred to on page 2 of the letter. I understand that the person with the corporate memory of this matter could not be contacted tonight. I understand that his children say that he is out to dinner or something. The division head has undertaken to provide the answer to the honourable senator before lunch tomorrow.

PARA.TAB: As to the letter relating to the Hon. John White, July 1990, and what follow-up action was taken, given the breach or apparent breach of the agreement by Tasmania, the officer could not be contacted—I think it was the same officer—but we understand that no penalty has been imposed. Once again, the division head has undertaken to provide Senator Walters with an answer by lunchtime tomorrow. That is as much as we can do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also asked whether any other State Minister for Health had received a similar letter.

—Yes. I am indicating that we will get a whole bundle of answers for Senator Walters by lunchtime tomorrow. I am just advised that the search for the letters to other States might take a little longer than lunchtime tomorrow but we will do our best. Certainly in relation to the John White letter and the question of whether a penalty was imposed, we will be able to provide the honourable senator with an answer by lunch time tomorrow.

—It makes it a bit difficult, as the Minister can well imagine, for me to ask any questions if we have not got that information. But I guess that debate on the Appropriation Bills could still be going, could it not, by lunchtime tomorrow?
—No. It will be finished, I am quite confident, by about 11 o'clock tonight. But we are happy to provide you with that information, Senator.
—Fine, and Senator Tate will let me ask him questions, will he not?

—Mr Chairman, just so there is no misunderstanding, I do not give an undertaking to unnecessarily prolong the agony of the Committee of the Whole, but I will certainly respond on notice to any of Senator Walters's questions which are left unanswered.
—Thank you very much.
—It is not a matter of whether the Minister will let you ask any questions.
—He would give me permission.
—Yes, he may, but the Chair may not.

—I have in front of me some Health Insurance Commission claims data on pathology episodes and bulkbilling. The data says that the number of services per episode in the fourth quarter, 1990, totalled 1.728. Per bulkbilled episode, the figure was 1.8; per private episode, it was 1.624. Perhaps departmental officers could write these figures down. For the first quarter, 1991, the figures were, in the same order: 1.730—so there was a slight increase—per bulkbilled episode it was 1.804, an increase; and per private episode it was 1.612, a reduction.

PARA.TAB: For the second quarter, 1991, the figures were, again in the same order: 1.715—so there was a reduction in the last two quarters—per bulkbilled episode it went up again, to 1.812; and per private episode it went down still further, to 1.561. So the bulkbilled episode content went up in the fourth quarter of 1990 by 10.85 per cent, then to 11.93 per cent and then to 16.08 per cent. Does the Department have these figures, and, if it does have them—as I should imagine it would—does it not think that it perhaps shows that there is some statistical link between the number of bulkbilled pathology episodes and the increased number of pathology services?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite sure that the Department would have had access to those sheets of statistics. I have indicated the latest paper available to the Department trying to draw valid conclusions from such raw statistics as those of Dr Deeble, which did not find the relationship which might at first appear to be the case. I cannot say—I do not know whether the officers can—whether the figures he was using were those relating to the years that Senator Walters has enumerated to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that an analysis is being undertaken by the Department in conjunction with the Australian Association of Pathology Practices. I would imagine that the sort of intuitive inference which Senator Walters has drawn from those statistics would also be immediately apparent to them and ought to be taken into account when they produce their report, which I have indicated ought to be available in about one month's time. I think what Senator Walters is pointing to would appear on the surface to have some validity, but I guess it is best left to an assessment of the report for us to check whether what appears to be the case is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not ask about a survey or anything like that. I did not ask about Dr Deeble's survey or anything else. My question was pretty precise. I asked whether the Department had any evidence of a statistical link between bulkbilling and the increased number of services ordered for pathology. It is a very simple question. It has nothing to do with Dr Deeble, nothing to do with surveys, nothing to do with anything that the Department is undertaking at the moment. I asked whether the Department presently has any evidence of a statistical link between bulkbilling and the increased number of services ordered for pathology. I have just cited to the Minister, Health Insurance Commission figures. I would have been surprised if the Department did not cite those figures to me.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can do is ask the Department to review those particular correlations to see whether, in fact, they would provide a secure foundation to answer Senator Walters's question in the affirmative. It may be that the particular correlations could be affected by other factors. I do not know whether there is a profile of those who are most likely to be patients of those doctors who do bulkbill, and whether there might be some link with the high proportion of the elderly who require more pathology services. I do not know the full context, but I will ask the Department to review any material it is currently holding, quite independent of any discussions or survey analysis it is undertaking with the Australian Association of Pathology Practices, and see whether it can hazard a fuller answer than it has over the dinner break.

—I gather from that that none of the public servants present could answer as to whether the Department has any evidence that counteracts those figures. Is that right? The Minister would have to get that from elsewhere.
—There is no official present who could counter the ordinary inference to be drawn from those figures.

—I turn to another situation. The Minister will remember that I have referred to Medibank Private and the Public Sector Union which came to an arrangement whereby the Public Service had special reductions for Medibank Private. I was told that that was available to everyone. I questioned whether it would be really applicable to the aged, as there were so many areas that the aged would use that were excluded under this particular Medibank Private and Public Sector Union agreement.

PARA.TAB: I was told that this table is freely available to anyone who asks for it. I think there is a requirement in the Act that the table be set out. It says that the organisation will include details of all tables of benefits in a brochure which shall be freely available and on display at any of its offices or outlets to any contributor, or to any member of the public who is eligible to become a contributor. I see the public servants nodding. That Public Sector Union deal done with Medibank Private is also included in the general brochure. Is that correct?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that that information is not within one single brochure. It is a brochure separately available in all the outlets of Medibank Private.

—As I read it, the Act says that the organisation will include details of all tables. I understood exactly the answer the Minister gave me. I understand that that has occurred and it is, as I understand it, totally illegal. A condition of registration under the relevant section of the National Health Act states that the organisation will include details of all tables—not some in separate pamphlets, but all tables—of benefits in a brochure which will be freely available and on display at any of its offices and outlets to any contributor, or to any member of the public who is eligible to become a contributor.

PARA.TAB: So if I went into Medibank Private and picked up a brochure, according to the Act, I should have every available table in that brochure. I believe that the answer the Minister gave me was that the Public Service deal is in a different brochure. That is against the Act. Could the Minister tell me whether I am correct in that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to offer a legal opinion but I would undertake to ensure that the Health Insurance Commission is advised of this particular exchange. I will insist, of course, that the Health Insurance Commission—I think I can say this on behalf of the Minister for Health—conforms with the law as it is properly advised that that law requires any particular form of publication of its tables in the one single brochure, if that is a fair, adequate and proper reading of the requirement of that section. I think, quite clearly, the attention of the managers of Medibank Private needs to be drawn to that provision. They ought to seek a legal opinion as to whether, in fact, their publication of brochures conforms with that particular section. If it does not, they ought to ensure that their publication, which would then be in the singular, does conform.
—Could I have copies of both those brochures tabled?
—We will have them made available.
—Can I have them tonight?
—If we can break into a Medibank Private office somewhere.

—I am sure the Department does not have to do that. Bearing that in mind, does Medibank Private make a point of not having all its tables in the one brochure? Are there other tables that are not included in the one brochure or is this the only one?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there is no brochure detailing tables other than those in the more or less single ordinary brochure put out by Medibank Private. I am advised that the problem has arisen because the PSU undertook the publicity of the arrangement which is in the separate table to which Senator Walters is referring. That, clearly, is not satisfactory in terms of a first reading of the provision that she has outlined in the Act. As I say, it will be drawn to the attention of the Medibank Private management overnight.

—So that I can have questions for the debate tomorrow, could I have those pamphlets and the cost of the production of the second pamphlet that will now obviously have to be changed if Medibank Private is going to abide by the Act? Could I also have an explanation as to why the Public Sector Union would have been given permission to do the advertising for Medibank Private, and how on earth it ever came about that the Government would do a deal with the Public Sector Union and get it to do the advertising, get it to produce for Medibank Private, I presume, a special pamphlet against the conditions of the act of registration of that private insurance?
—We will find out what we can.
—I thank the Minister for that and ask him to provide anything else which he believes I would think would be relevant to the issue.
—To put myself in Senator Walters's skull is a great challenge, but I will do my best.

—Is there any further matter in relation to program 6.1? There being nothing further, I would like to go through programs 7 and 9 before coming back to the matter raised by Senator Tierney. Are there any questions on programs 7 or 9? There being no questions, apart from Senator Tierney's question, that concludes Estimates Committee E. I think that Senator Tierney asked a question and the Minister might have been going to find an answer to it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner Senator Tierney asked—I think this is a fair summary of his question—whether there was any double counting in the Appropriation Bills as funding for the John Curtin School of Medical Research was originally provided under subdivision 271.1, the Australian National University, and an amount was included in the general health research item, item 04 of division 330.4, to finance payments to the John Curtin School of Medical Research.

PARA.TAB: I am advised as follows: there was no double counting. While there was no declared saving for subdivision 271.1, the increase in appropriation for the Australian National University in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) was lower than it would otherwise have been to the extent of the supplementation to be given to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services to fund payments to the John Curtin School of Medical Research. DEET officials, who will be in attendance later this evening, will be able to give a breakdown of the increase in the estimate for subdivision 271.1, including this offset, if required.

I mention by way of background that since the announcement on 17 December that funding for the John Curtin School was to be transferred from DEET to the present Department, payments to the John Curtin School have been made from the general health research item, item 330.4.04, and additional appropriation is being sought to cover the transfer in the Additional Estimates. As a result of these payments to the John Curtin School, there were insufficient funds in the health research item to fund the final quarterly payments for a range of research projects, including the John Curtin School of Medical Research, and as the payments met the criteria for funding from the Advance to the Minister for Finance, funding from the Advance was granted on 14 April pending passage of the Additional Estimates.

Finally, as the funding for the John Curtin School of Medical Research has now been completed for the financial year, blocking or amending Appropriation Bill (No.3) will have no bearing on the funding of that body as it would merely leave the payment for the health research item as a final charge on the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

I have to say to Senator Tierney that I have no idea of the import or meaning of what I have just read. If Senator Tierney is satisfied, perhaps he could indicate; if not, perhaps the best course would be to defer his motion—unless it is absolutely related to this particular Estimates Committee—and discuss the matter with the official from the Department of Finance. Perhaps he can better explain the nuances than I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the Minister, I am rather curious about this matter, particularly the offset figures. The Appropriation Bill shows that there is another $8m in the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. If we go back to the original funding of the Department, we find that the figure in last year's Budget papers is $194.9m. When we come to the Bill now before us and the areas covered by the appropriations under Estimates Committee F, we find that the figure on page 32 is still $194.9m. In other words, there has been no adjustment from the end of last year to this year to the DEET figure, yet there is an adjustment of plus $8m in the health budget, being the half-yearly financing of the John Curtin School.

PARA.TAB: I am at a loss, and I can assure the Minister that the bursar of the ANU is also at a loss—the Minister himself seems to be at a loss—to understand how this funding is working. I was hoping that the Minister's explanation tonight would show the actual mechanism by which the funding is moving from the Department of Finance to eventually end up in the John Curtin School. I think the Minister's explanation has clouded the matter more than clarified it. Could the Minister table the advice to which he has just referred?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be very happy to do that. This is just the hand-written version which was provided by the departmental officer over the dinner break. I am happy for that to be tabled but, as I have read it, it will appear in Hansard.

—I wonder whether the Minister, having consulted his advisers, has anything to add to what he has just said to clarify the matter? Obviously, the funding starts in the Department of Finance and ends up in the John Curtin School. Exactly by what route does that money go? The explanation has not clarified that at all.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the second half of this financial year the money flows from this Department's appropriation. At the moment, the John Curtin School of Medical Research is funded from the money appropriated to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.

—Indeed, that is what shows up in the Bill—that there is another $8m—but where is the adjustment for DEET? When the Director of the John Curtin School of Medical Research found out that in this half year he was going to receive $8m from Health, Housing and Community Services and also $8m from DEET, he was absolutely ecstatic. He was going to appoint more professors and add to the research team because he was going to get double funding. But I assume that that is not the case. We are wondering why the adjustment has not been made in the Bill under the appropriations of DEET. If the Minister cannot explain it at this stage of consideration of the Estimates, we will certainly ask him later tonight when we get to that part of the appropriations that deals with DEET.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed by a Department of Finance officer that $8m, or roughly that amount, was notionally taken off DEET but that other factors increased the allocation to the ANU through DEET by an amount roughly coincidental with, or very close to, the $8m, or whatever it is.
—Sort of exactly coincidental.
—It was very close, apparently. It is one of those matters the chaos theory is full of—and that is not a bad description of this Estimates Committee.

—Senator Tierney, I am not trying to stifle your contribution but I remind you that the Minister said that you might be able to speak to the representative of the Department of Finance yourself in the interval between consideration of the report of this Estimates Committee and the next. That is an option that you have.

—Mr Chairman, I think the Committee should take advantage of your very wise counsel. I am happy to make the officer available to Senator Tierney and perhaps to Senator Short right now to hold discussions of a more technical nature than I am capable of assisting with at the moment.

—I thank the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) for his offer, but I think the answer to this point in time has raised more questions than it has answered. I find it absolutely incredible that the funding of the ANU has magically risen by the exact amount which has come out from Health. I ask the Minister two questions: firstly, why therefore does this not appear in the appropriations for the Department of Employment, Education and Training under an additional fund of $8m to DEET if that is the case; and, secondly, what on earth is this item that exactly matches the funding that evidently has been subtracted from Health?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that DEET officers will also be available in some sort of interim. I do not deny the validity of the questions. It is a curiosity which needs to be unravelled. I think it can best be done perhaps informally. Then the questions can be put in a formal way here in the chamber and a much better answer given.

—I would just remind honourable senators that we are doing something which is quite unusual. I did indicate earlier that the easiest way around the unusual event that we have in front of us was to allow for debate, but I would be hopeful that the debate is getting somewhere.

—I have a further piece of information. I am told the reason that no mention is made in the program performance statements in DEET—and we are now trespassing into DEET territory—is that, although there is a potential saving of approximately $8m in 1991-92 for ANU recurrent costs, there are additional requirements in respect of the amalgamation of the Canberra School of the Arts with the ANU, which was plus $2.4m; additional funding in respect of research, $4m; supplementation, $1m; and other minor requirements, such as Comcare charges, which altogether total approximately $8m. The Department of Finance has advised that it is not necessary to provide comment in the PPSs where the net effect of plus and minus adjustments to an appropriation item results in no additional estimates being sought under that item.

PARA.TAB: I suppose the short comment on that from the point of view of senators in Estimates committees is that, whilst that may be technically correct—and I think Senator Short being something of an expert in these matters would agree that technically that may be right—it does not help to explain or expose to honourable senators what has been happening. That seems to be a reasonable explanation, but I can table that document if Senator Tierney would like.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. As he proceeds on this, he raises more and more questions. Did the funding subtracted exactly equal the funding added; if not, what was the exact difference in the total and why were the items not referred to in the estimates concerning the Department of Employment, Education and Training?
—We do have a little difficulty here in that we are going from one department to another and from one Estimates committee to another.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, may I suggest that with your concurrence—I am sure you will give a proper direction in this respect—we might conclude the estimates for the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, as we have explained the situation as far as it is concerned, and allow this matter to be dealt with when the Committee of the Whole considers the Department of Employment, Education and Training. In light of the answers, it seems now that that is where the focus of further questioning should lie. Senator Tierney would then be free, having regard to your previous comment, Mr Chairman, to move his motion. He can do it at any stage of the Committee of the Whole, but he could do it then if he so wished.
—I think that this might be a better option, unless honourable senators feel otherwise. Senator Short, you feel otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel slightly otherwise, Mr Chairman. I support the degree of confusion felt about this by my colleague Senator Tierney. In stating that confusion, I read from a submission to the Secretary of the Department of Finance from the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services—which is the Department we are concerned with here—signed by Mr Scammell, with the contact officer being Mr Wally Saar. It was a memo to the Secretary of the Department of Finance, dated 7 April. It was tabled here in the Senate under the explanatory note to the Advance to the Minister for Finance a month or so ago where $8.204m was sought for the purposes that we are now discussing. It was an application for funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance. The explanation of it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: AMF of $8.204m is urgently required pending the enactment of Appropriation Bill 3 in order that the final quarter payment into the Medical Research Endowment Fund (MREF) Trust Account can be made. Whilst the budget allocation provided for this payment, transfer of the John Curtin School of Medical Research (JCSMR) from DEET to HHCS, under this item, required utilisation of all available moneys from the item's total provision for JCSMR payments pending the transfer of resources through Appropriation Act 3.

The payment for MREF is to be made immediately and given that claims on hand to June 1992 total $11,835,000 with only $3,632,723 funds available, including MREF Trust Account money, AMF of $8,204,000 is now necessary.
The requirement is both urgent and unforeseen as the claims are due for payment and the need for additional funds was unknown at the time of preparation of the Budget Estimates.
Your approval of $8.204m as an advance from the Minister for Finance would therefore be appreciated as soon as possible.

That was the application from the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services to the Department of Finance. That was approved and included in the AMF details for April tabled here subsequently. I do not, with the benefit of hindsight, really understand what that means. I understand that the Department was looking for $8.2m and that it was granted over the Advance to the Minister for Finance, but I do not understand how that goes towards answering Senator Tierney's earlier and essential question—I accept that this is more in DEET—of where the offset is to that, unless the Minister is saying that the total amount being spent on the two areas collectively will go up by $8.204m.

PARA.TAB: If it is the case that the Government is proposing to increase the total appropriations in this area by $8.2m, then we would appreciate confirmation of that and an explanation of why. If that is not the case, if the net figure between the two Departments is to remain essentially unchanged, then where is the offset? I accept that we might have to come to that in DEET, but there is no suggestion in the figures that we have that there is an offset. So Senator Tierney and I, quite understandably, share considerable confusion here—I hazard a guess that we share it with Senator Tate—and we would appreciate an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Tate does answer, I think that really the time has come to go to DEET.

—What I read out to the Senate just a moment ago was an application to the Department of Finance under the AMF from the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, which is now before us. So I think before we move to DEET, with due respect, we are justified in seeking some further explanation from this Department.
—I was not suggesting to the Minister that he not answer the question, but I am not convinced that it is not now the time to go to DEET.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said that I believed that, whilst technically correct, the way in which the Department of Finance advised the Department of Employment, Education and Training as to how it should present its program performance statement did mask the fact that, whilst there was a potential saving of some $8m to DEET because of the transfer of the funding of the John Curtin School of Medical Research to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, for which $8.2m was required out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance—which is the burden of the letter which Senator Short has read to the Senate—at the same time it was found that additional requirements arose for funding the ANU out of the DEET appropriation. I will just recall what they were: the amalgamation of the Canberra School of the Arts with the ANU required an extra $2.4m; additional funding in respect of research required $4m; supplementation required $1m. There were other minor requirements, such as Comcare charges, which I am told totalled approximately $8m.
—Did you say $8m?
—Yes, $8m. The total of $2.4m plus $4m plus $1m, on the face of it, is $7.4m. I have mentioned other minor requirements, such as Comcare charges and other matters.
—Did you just say Comcare charges were an additional $8m?

—Altogether it totalled $8m. The total of $2.4m, $4m and $1m is $7.4m; then there are some Comcare charges and other matters which bring the total up to approximately $8m. I was not saying that Comcare charges were $8m. So, without being arithmetically identical, the amounts balance. That is the explanation, though I agree that it would have been better for the purposes of our Estimates Committee process had that been exposed and made clear. But apparently it is a Department of Finance opinion that, where the net effect of plus and minus adjustments to an appropriation item results in no additional estimates being sought under the item, it does not have to be explained in the way which obviously would have better satisfied Senator Tierney and Senator Short—and myself for that matter.

—I thank the Minister for that explanation. I must say that I find it a trifle strange that the figures that the Minister has just read out happen to add pretty roughly to the $8.2m that we are talking about. If what he is saying is accurate—and I am not questioning his integrity at all on this—I think that exposes some very considerable questions in the whole of the Estimates and financing and accounting processes because that, to my knowledge, is the first time we have heard of those figures. They are not insignificant; indeed, in some instances they are very significant figures, particularly for the institutions and agencies involved. It really does smack of, for want of a better word, creative accounting. I think that this Senate requires a more considered and detailed explanation of all of this than Senator Tate, very understandably, has been able to give us. He has been caught on the hop, just as we have been. I do not think that is good enough, either from his point of view or from ours.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tierney may be going to move into this area, so I will not say any more, but I think that some further explanation is required, particularly so far as this aspect is concerned. It appears that, under cloak of the ability not to have to disclose as much information as I think the Senate rightfully expects should be available to it, the net result of all of this is that there is an increase in the appropriations of $8.2m, when the explanation given in the performance statements for Estimates E is that the $8.2m is simply a transfer from one part of the accounts to the other. From what we are hearing from Senator Tate, that is not true and the actual fact is that there is to be, as a result of all of this creative accounting, an increase in the total appropriation of $8.2m. If that is the case, I would have to say on behalf of the coalition that I find that extraordinary and very unsatisfactory.

In terms of that totality, I request of Senator Tate a much fuller explanation than we have had. I will give way now to Senator Tierney, in terms of the aspects that he is mainly concerned with. But I think that what the Minister has raised tonight is a very serious and very unsatisfactory state of affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Short summed it up very nicely when he called it creative accounting. As a former senior lecturer and senior administrator in a university, I know something about these sorts of figures. Amalgamation costs are very variable; certainly research costs are; and supplementation certainly would be. I find it curious that the Minister's residual item of Comcare comes to $0.8m, which seems extremely high. What I would request of the Department is that we have a precise breakdown on each of those items.
—We cannot do it in this Department; we will have to do it in the next one.

—I feel, therefore, that we should defer this matter until the Minister can come back with more information, and possibly after we have heard from DEET. If the Minister is prepared to do that, I think we should move on with this program.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Tierney's invitation to move off health is the correct strategy. I think we should conclude consideration in the Committee of the Whole of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. I am very happy to indicate that whoever the Minister is who takes DEET will be prepared to answer fully Senator Tierney's questions in that respect.

PARA.TAB: I might foreshadow that I feel that Senator Tierney will not have to move his motion—this is just my opinion; in terms of trying to move money around there is an explanation—because I have already asked the Assistant Clerk at the table to consider drafting an opinion of the Committee that the Department of Finance approach which I have outlined needs to be reviewed and reconsidered in light of the requirement to provide senators with the fullest explanation of changes in the way in which money is allocated. We do need some more time but, if we can finish the Department of Health, the DEET officials, who are here, will perhaps be able to give further information. I have just foreshadowed perhaps an alternative approach at the end.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the report of Estimates Committee E be adopted.

—Admittedly we can obtain information from DEET, but I find the whole situation totally unsatisfactory. I think it really highlights the inadequacy and the inappropriateness of the way in which this funding change has taken place. Therefore, I intend to move the amendment circulated in my name.

—I wish to speak briefly in support of the amendment which Senator Tierney has circulated. As I understand it, the bottom line of his amendment is that we do not close off this item until we have received a satisfactory explanation stemming from the discussions on the next item in relation to DEET.

—The position is that Senator Tierney's amendment is not an amendment to a particular Estimates committee report; it is an amendment to the Bill. If it is the wish of the Committee, Estimates Committee E can be deferred, but we have already gone through that business with one committee and it created a tremendous amount of trouble.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a suggestion. I understand now that Senator Tierney has foreshadowed that he will be moving a motion which, it is true, can be moved at any time in the Committee of the Whole. Nevertheless, if ever implemented, it would take $8m off the appropriation for the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. Therefore, it would be sensible not to formally conclude the consideration of the Department of Health appropriation at this time. To take $8m out of the budget, if it is truly required by the John Curtin School of Medical Research, would, of course, not be Senator Tierney's intention.

PARA.TAB: It may be that we can come to an agreement as to an expression of opinion at the end of the Committee which would put that Department of Finance guideline for departments under proper review in light of the need to inform Senate Estimates committees, in the fullest possible way, of changes in the allocation of moneys, even if at the end of the day there is no plus or minus effect in the item. Perhaps Senator Short and I could work on that whilst the other Minister is answering Senator Tierney's questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to get clarification. Senator Tierney's amendment is to be moved to the motion that the report of Estimates Committee E be adopted and to add to that, `subject to the following requests for amendment. . . '. I will be guided by you, Mr Chairman, but it seems to me that we cannot at this stage have a conclusion of the motion that the report of Estimates Committee E be adopted. In other words, should we not hold that open until a later date?

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That consideration of Estimates Committee E be deferred.

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE F

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the report of Estimates Committee F be adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that Senator Cook is on his way to the chamber. It may be that he could take questions from the running sheet. Perhaps it would be possible for Senator Short and I to get together, if Senator Tierney is otherwise occupied, to have a look at the way in which this previous matter might be resolved before we bring it back on for discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first department to be considered is the Department of Employment, Education and Training. We will proceed according to the running sheet. Is there anything before program 1, schools?

—I have a series of general questions before we get into some of the specific items. I ask the Minister to explain the apparent anomaly that we have just uncovered in the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. Under the Bill for the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services there is $8.204m for funding the John Curtin School of Medical Research for the six months of the 1991-92 financial year, yet under Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1991 the Department of Employment, Education and Training received full funding for 12 months for the John Curtin School. Will the Minister explain what appears to be a double appropriation of funds for the John Curtin School of Medical Research?

PARA.TAB: If this is not the case, why has there not been a corresponding decrease in the appropriation of DEET to counter the fact that there are no longer funds to the John Curtin School of Medical Research? Given the answer that we have just received from the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, could the Minister explain the fairly neat balancing act that has occurred where this decrease in funding of $8.2m has been presumably exactly matched by another $8.2m, made up of an amalgamation of $2.4m; research, $4m; supplementation, $1m; and Comcare, $1.8m? Can the Minister also explain why, in addition to this neat balancing act, the specific amounts were not in any way indicated in notes of explanation for the Bill and explain this rather peculiar accounting procedure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot guarantee that I can answer all of those questions, because it is a comprehensive list of questions and Senator Tierney has the advantage of having been through the estimates of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. I do have advice on the subject, and if I may I will refer to that and it may clarify the issue. It is my understanding that at least parts of this advice have been provided by Senator Tate to the Senate and that the note from which I am about to quote has been provided to Senator Short.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that on 17 December the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) and the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) in a joint statement announced the transfer of funding for the John Curtin School from ANU to the National Health and Medical Research Council with effect from 1 January 1992. Accordingly, provision for the transfer of $8.204m—that is, half-year funding for John Curtin from DEET to DHHCS—was included in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) at subdivision 330-4-04.

I am further advised that no consequential decrease was made in the operating expenses of the ANU, appropriation 271-1, as a result of other variations. An amount of $2.4m, the transfer of the Canberra Institute of the Arts to the ANU, was included in a savings document for CITA, and there was a $4m allocation of research funding to ANU from the Higher Education Funding Act, part of the annual ARC grants. The remaining difference of $1.8m was not shown in the savings document. This variation will be made to ANU's allocation for the second half of the 1992 funding year and reflected in the Budget Bills. Further funding adjustments, including a reduction for the remainder of the John Curtin School transfer, will also be included in the Budget Bills. I do not know whether that answers all of the honourable senator's questions, but I am advised that that answer goes to the meat of the question. I hope I have assisted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has indicated a number of figures which make up this $8.2m. Could the Minister supply details or have details supplied of the breakdown of each of those figures for the items of amalgamation, research, supplementation and Comcare? I find it absolutely amazing that the figure adds up and exactly balances the figure for the John Curtin School of Medical Research.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a reasonable request. We can and will supply the honourable senator with those figures. It is my understanding that it will not be a perfect offset, but there will be an adjustment in the Higher Education Funding Act.

—From the point of view of accountability of public funds, I wonder if the Minister could explain, when this whole exercise was about the transfer of funding from one department to another for the control of the John Curtin School, why all of a sudden there has been another $8.2m of taxpayers' money expended without any explanation in any of the Budget papers that this was happening and what it was actually spent on. The net effect is plus $8.2m. I know the items have been listed, but unless we had asked these questions tonight we all would have been ignorant of that fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be quite happy to provide the honourable senator with an answer to that question. I can tell him that the information I have supplied is the current information and is consistent with the guidelines laid down by the Department of Finance. As I understand it, the honourable senator's question seeks some wider explanation than that, and I would be quite happy to ensure that he is supplied with an answer and that his reasonable inquiry is properly dealt with.

—I have a number of other general questions that relate to the matters raised during the Estimates hearing. During the Estimates Committee back in April I asked the Department about the turnover of staff, as it seemed to be an underlying reason why the Department was having problems year after year implementing the recommendations of the Australian National Audit Office. It was stated in the Estimates hearings that devolution and training was necessary, particularly with regard to accounting systems, and that high staff turnover hindered this training. At that time I was quoted figures of approximately 30 to 40 per cent of annual turnover.

PARA.TAB: The written reply which was received after Mr Hartigan agreed to take my question on notice only gives staff turnover for the Commonwealth Employment Service, and the national turnover of the Commonwealth Employment Service as indicated by him is 4.1 per cent. That was not what I originally asked; I asked for the full DEET figure. Will the Minister provide the staff turnover figures for the whole Department as originally requested, and will he explain the effect of staff turnover on the implementation of the Auditor-General's recommendations?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of water has flowed under the bridge since April and I have only a vague recollection of this, and probably a very unreliable one. As I recall, the discussion then could reasonably have been assumed to have focused on the Commonwealth Employment Service part of the inquiry and that may well be why the answer has been given as it has. The honourable senator has now asked for a wider answer to the question or the question to be taken on a wider purview. That can and will be done.

—I asked the question I had originally asked, which was for the whole of the DEET figure. It was provided orally as 30 per cent to 40 per cent at the meeting. The figure then turned up as 4.1 per cent, but just for the CES. So we are still in the dark as to what it is for the whole of DEET. That is the figure I want.
—My memory is certainly defective. Thank you for that correction; we will get you an answer.
—There being nothing further on those general matters, we will move to subprogram 1.1—Participation, Retention and General Competencies.

—I want to ask a very simple, straightforward question that relates to the kit that was sent out last week by Minister Kelly. I want to know whether the Department of Employment, Education and Training had any input into the production of this kit.
—What kit is this?
—This is the Kelly kit that was withdrawn. Did the Department of Employment, Education and Training have any input into the production of that kit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Crane styles the `Kelly kit' is a colloquial reference with a political overtone to the kit on the environment that was to be issued by DASET. The Department of Employment, Education and Training had no input into that.
—If it had no input, was there any consultation with the Department of Employment, Education and Training?
—No, senator.
—I want to make a very short, simple comment in terms of educational material being sent out.
—If it is in line with subprogram 1.1, you will be in order. If it is not, you are not.
—It is.
—I am not sure that it is, but keep going until I find out that it is not. You might be finished by then.

—It is absolutely deplorable that educational material is being sent to schools in Australia about which there is no consultation with the responsible department. I hope that, in future, consideration will be given by Ministers in other portfolios to consultation with the Department of Employment, Education and Training.
—You got through before I found out. I cannot make a ruling because I have not found out.

—I refer to some questions taken on notice during the Committee hearing. I ask the Minister to explain why a reply has not yet been received from the Department when it is over a month since the questions were asked. I ask the Minister to provide the answer to these questions now. The questions are: firstly, can the Department provide the Committee with information concerning the infrastructure capital requirements on the government and non-government schools system over this decade; and, secondly, what is the current status of the review of the capital requirements of non-government schools?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the latest figures that are available were given to Senator Tierney. However, I see his quizzical look and I note his shaking of the head. That would seem to suggest that, if they were provided, he did not receive them or they were mislaid in some way, in which case we will provide again what we thought we provided before.

PARA.TAB: There has been a review and a report recently on these matters, which is in part, I suppose, an explanation for some delay in this. One would want to reply as fully and in as much detail to Senator Tierney's question as possible. To this extent, if the wheel was spinning due to a review, it would be reasonable for the Department to want to wait so that it could have that review completed. We can make available to Senator Tierney an extract of the report which will cover the questions that he has asked.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Burns)—There being nothing further on subprogram 1.1, we will move to subprogram 2.1, higher education system.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another question to which we still have not received an answer. The question was: will the Department make available to the Committee any information it has concerning the total revenue accrued by institutions which charge fees for postgraduate award courses and for which institutions are permitted to charge fees?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister Baldwin has just recently widened the definition of how institutions may charge fees. It is expected that at the end of the financial year there will be a complete tally under the new definition rules. It may meet Senator Tierney's purpose if I suggest that, perhaps when the financial year comes to a conclusion, the Department, under the new definition as widened by the Minister, answers his question based on that change. If that would be acceptable, we would proceed in that way.

—On 30 March 1992, it was reported in the Australian by Natasha Bita that DEET had produced a document that provides estimates of the cost of HECS loan arrangements for fee paying students and for those who will in time be required to pay fees above the level of the voucher. The document cites estimates, which are attributed to DEET, that a simple HECS arrangement to cover such students would cost the Budget $240m in the first year rising to $260m and $280m in the subsequent two years.

PARA.TAB: In questions on notice lodged at the Senate Estimates hearing on 2 April 1992, I asked whether the Department had undertaken any costing of the additional Commonwealth obligations under HECS which would be incurred if HECS were extended to allow fee deferral for full fee paying Australian students. The answer to the question given by the Department at this time was no. In the light of this obvious conflict between the answer and the article referring to DEET estimates on this very issue, does the Minister stand by the Department's answer to my question?

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that, yes, the Department stands by that answer.

—Is the Minister saying that these figures referred to in the newspaper article were not DEET figures and that the article is incorrect? Can the Minister enlighten the Senate as to the possible source of those figures?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot speculate on the possible source of those figures. They are not authorised figures and, therefore, they are not owned by the Department. I am frequently as mystified as the ordinary person in the street about where some figures that find their way into print at the hands of journalists come from. That is not to say that all figures are wrong, but sometimes the occasional roughie gets through. DEET does not own these figures; they are DEET figures and they are not authorised. As Senator Tierney asked me before, the Department does stand by its original answer.

—According to an answer provided by DEET, an inter-departmental committee has considered the Industry Commission report on the export of educational services. When will that assessment be released and when will we receive a Government response to the Industry Commission report?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the inter-departmental committee to which Senator Tierney has referred is currently before the Ministers for consideration. When the Ministers have given that consideration, there will be an announcement or a report. I am not at all sure at this stage when we can expect that to happen. This is a matter to which I know the Ministers have turned their attention with some expedition. So I would expect that their consideration of it and their response will be fairly prompt.

—It seems as though the Department has not made any estimates of the likely increase in university revenue if universities were free to vary HECS charges or to increase charges for courses. I am just questioning why this has not happened.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Essentially, there has been no need to look at figures. I think that is reasonable, given the way in which the Government responded to the Wran report on this matter. In all of those circumstances, it is not obvious to the Government that there is a need to do as Senator Tierney has suggested.

—It is not obvious to the Government, Minister. If I can move on: I believe that the Department does not have complete information on the income received by institutions from fee-paying postgraduate students for 1991. Does that mean that the Department cannot provide the total revenue accrued by the institutions and the breakdown by institution? If so, why not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department does not have access to this data because it is subject to the new financial reporting arrangements which are currently under consideration and being put in place. So it is not in a position to have access to the data and to provide the information in that form.
—Why are there not any statistics kept on overcrowding by institution? Is the Department endeavouring to obtain such information so that critical areas can be identified?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Overcrowding is like beauty—it is a subjective assessment; it is in the eye of the beholder. The Department's assessment does not include a definition of what constitutes overcrowding. The Department looks at the floor space and the load factor. I am not sure whether it makes assessments on that basis, but those are the two relevant factors. The issue of overcrowding is subjective.
—Given that the Department has that information, would that not enable it to make some sort of estimate of the degree of overcrowding in a university?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that overcrowding—if we can accept that as shorthand for floor space and the load factor—is something which is more typical of first year lectures. But there might be, if you like, under-crowding in later year lectures in the same lecture theatre or floor space. It seems to me that a reasonable comeback by Senator Tierney might well be, `Well, what is the evidence for overcrowding in the first year and is there overcrowding in terms of space available for first year students?'. The Department does not have any hard evidence on that. There is a lot of anecdotal evidence which points to a fairly patchy picture. It is very difficult to make a general statement.

—Then it would also be very difficult to project future capital requirements for universities if the Department does not know what the overall overcrowding is and, therefore, what precise facilities are needed across faculties and across years. Can the Minister comment of that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: QUESTIONS ON NOTICE FOR SENATE ESTIMATES HEARING
Senator Tierney (Hansard, page F80-81) asked:
Questions:

(1)In relation to JOBTRAIN, the ANAO found that tenders had not been called for a course valued in excess of $200,000. What was this course and where was it performed? Who was given the job to conduct the course? Why were tenders not called for a course of that value?

(2)The ANAO noted that documentation relating to JOBTRAIN courses was not being kept at the locations where courses were being offered and that the records were not being properly approved, completed or filed. The Department has stated that procedures have been introduced to correct this. What procedures have been implemented to ensure that these things are being properly documented?
(Answers)

(1)The course in question was a station hand course conducted on Villadale Station, Richmond, Queensland. The training provider is recorded as W & M Torenbeck. No contract was actually entered into with the provider for the conduct of the course.

Course places under the JOBTRAIN program are obtained by either contracting for the provision of entire courses or purchasing existing course places from TAFE and other training providers. Where existing course places are purchased these are approved on an individual placement basis consistent with the Government's purchasing guidelines.

Although there were multiple placements on this particular course, each placement was processed individually, resulting in the purchase of individual course places, rather than a bulk purchase which would have required the calling of tenders. This treatment was based on the interpretation of the JOBTRAIN guidelines at the local level.

In response to the ANAO comments on this process the Department acknowledged that it was inappropriate in the circumstances and remedial action was taken. The Area concerned has been given strict instructions in relation to the negotiation of training agreements and adherence to tendering guidelines.

Revised JOBTRAIN and tendering guidelines have been issued to all Areas to promote proper tendering practice. In addition, extensive staff training covering the seeking of quotes and tenders and appropriate documentation has been carried out.

(2)Revised guidelines on both JOBTRAIN and tendering, which form part of the CES manual, were reissued in 1991 in conjunction with extensive training in all States. The tendering guidelines place specific emphasis on achieving value for money and ensuring that purchasing practices are beyond reproach and consistent with Department of Administrative Services Procurement guidelines.

The need to maintain full documentation in relation to the evaluation and awarding of tenders and provider performance is addressed in these guidelines. There is specific emphasis on the need for Area and Regional Offices to maintain records of prior performance of providers for future assessment of tenders.

The guidelines also contain a reference to the responsibility of State and Territory offices to monitor the fairness and equity of local decisions by random audit. These measures should ensure that all decisions are properly approved, documented and filed and that the records are located in the appropriate office.

TALK.START.PARA: —While it is true that the service providers provide the report, the Department has reason to be as satisfied as it reasonably can be in the circumstances—satisfied from the point of view of accepting accountability for it. On the basis that line managers are in a position to oversee and make a reasonable assessment based on those reports, this system is regarded as working effectively for its operational purpose.
—I follow up that question by asking the Minister to explain how the Department satisfies itself that that is actually the case, given the mechanism that it has adopted?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Basically, the line managers through which the service providers make their reports are the ones in the position of scrutinising and providing the checks necessary to satisfy the Department.

—I have been told by the Department that, to ensure that it has implemented the recommendations suggested by the ANAO, the ANAO would undertake a follow-up audit in April. Has that been carried out and, if so, can the Committee have the results?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, there will be a follow-up audit. It has not occurred yet. When it has—and I understand that it will be done soon—we will make a copy available to Senator Tierney.
—Could I ask the Minister also that a copy be tabled in the Senate?
—Subject to checking by the Auditor-General, yes, it can be tabled.
—Have the internal auditors looked at the payments of the subprogram since the ANAO's review of the annual report, and if so, can the Committee have the results of that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The report has not been completed yet; I think it is being done by Peat Marwick. When it is completed, obviously the Department will then be in receipt of it. Senator Tierney's question, however, asks whether it can be made available by tabling in the Senate. I am not quite sure what the procedure is with respect to that and, if I may, I would like to refer that question to the Minister and obtain an answer from him rather than answer it here.
—There being no further matters relating to subprogram 6.1, we will turn to subprogram 7.2 Management Services.

—In reply to a question asked in the Estimates Committee, I was informed that the average staffing level of DEET's internal audit was 44; that 104 audits had taken place in 12 months since 31 March, 1992; and that at least 1,000 recommendations had been made with an audit committee overseeing the implementation of these recommendations. How is it that the ANAO can make comments on the Department's financial administration such as, `a failure to ensure that rigorous standards are maintained in the accounting of public moneys' and `there is inadequate information supporting the processing of payments'? Can it be deduced from this that the Department's internal auditors are failing to do their job?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this question is meant to put me on the spot. As to its implications, DEET is an extremely large department. It has a huge number of programs serving different needs with different qualifications, a different client base and, in many cases, complex administration. I think the overall budget for the Department of Employment, Education and Training is in the order of $10 billion—which is not to be sneezed at in anyone's currency and, in this case, is quite a huge amount of money. I think too, as I understand it, that the Auditor-General himself is sympathetic to the difficulties such a large and complex department has.

PARA.TAB: None of that is taken to mean that the Department is not serious about maintaining the highest level of internal audit management. But in an organisation as big as this, with such complexity and such a wide range of subprograms and programs, those observations made by the Auditor-General who meticulously reviews performance under each, while not treated in any trivial way, nonetheless, I think, are not to be regarded as exceptional. If we aggregated several departments we would probably be able to say the same thing about any one of them at any one time under any administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am curious that the Minister says the Auditor-General is sympathetic. The Auditor-General undertook what I think was an unprecedented step of briefing senators before we went into Estimates hearings. I would be curious to know how many other mega-departments had that sort of treatment and also how many other audit reports on other mega-departments had serious qualifications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I really cannot answer that question because I am not familiar with what the Auditor-General has said about all the other departments. My remark about the Auditor-General being sympathetic is based on the Department's understanding that an auditor has to be meticulous—and there is no getting away from that—but this is a very large and complex department and I guess I can just rest my remarks on that.

—The ANAO states that it understands there are programming errors in the program administration's past statistical system. On questioning the Department, officers stated that the ANAO did not identify any programming problems associated with the past system. Does the Minister stand by this answer of the Department? Does this mean that the ANAO got it wrong? If so, how was the ANAO given such a false impression?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is reasonable to say someone got it wrong in this sense. The principal problem—and I think the Auditor-General has identified this, as I understand it—has been not that the computer system is wrong, but that there has been a problem with the input data. Some of it has been, I think the technical term is, `corrupt data'. It is as a consequence of that that the Auditor-General can make those remarks.
