It is as a consequence of the fact that the Department is progressively identifying and cleaning up this corrupt data and perfecting the system, that the Department can make its remarks. On that understanding, I think it would cause a nil all draw; both are right in their own way and the changes that are being made give the Department, as I am advised, the confidence to stand by the remarks that it has made.

—According to an answer given by the Department, the cost of manually reconciling the financial ledger system of the Department's FINEST system was $56,000. Does the Minister agree that it is amazing that such a sum had to be spent on such a basic accounting task that should have been calculated automatically and regularly throughout the year? Will the Minister give assurances that the FINEST system is operating as it should and that such expenditure will not be warranted in the future?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that initially the Department purchased an automatic system to sort this out. The automatic system did not function effectively or properly. The bugs in that system have now been ironed out, but in the interim other steps have to be taken to correct it. That accounts for the problem that Senator Tierney has identified.

—I was assured by Ms Kestevan in the Estimates Committee that the FINEST system was operating properly, as Senator Cook indicates, and I was promised the latest audit report. This report was promised on 2 April and it still has not arrived. I was wondering whether the Minister could table that document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the report has arrived and has been tabled in the Senate. I am trying to ascertain a time for that, but it was a little earlier this year. I do have a copy of the report. Although it has gone down on the table in the Senate, I can make a copy of it available. I just want to make sure that this is not the only copy accessible to me in case Senator Tierney has other questions on it. I can make this copy available to him this evening if he wishes.

—In reply to a question raised with the Department on consultants and their remuneration, I was informed that consultant No. 2 was paid $133,120 and consultant No. 3 was paid $141,440. Both of these consultants worked on a project entitled `Data Line Network (Security)'. Would the Minister elaborate on precisely what this project involved, how much time was spent on the project and what the project achieved? Given the lateness of the hour and the complexity of the question, if he wants to take it on notice, I would be quite happy to receive the answer that way.
—I cannot resist that invitation; I will take it on notice.

—In the Estimates Committee I asked the Department to provide details of staff training courses that are provided to the Department by the private sector. I was informed that data was not available until the 1992-93 financial year, that DEET was highly decentralised and too big and complex to obtain such information easily. Does this mean that the Department has no record of these training programs and that up until now it never has?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Employment, Education and Training in this respect is a bit like other departments. It does have estimates of aggregate expenditure on training, but it cannot provide the detailed break-up that I think Senator Tierney is looking for.

—I find that curious, but I will not pursue it at this hour. I will probably pursue it in the Budget Estimates. I was informed that there would be a national management information system that would allow the information I requested to be obtained easily in 1992-93. Has the system been implemented, given that we are now only one month away from the start of the financial year? If not, why not, and when will it be implemented?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I have anyone accessible to me to provide the specific answer that Senator Tierney seeks. May I take that on notice and see that the answer is provided.
—That completes the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That further consideration of the report of Estimates Committee F be deferred until after the further consideration of the report of Estimates Committee E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the chair is that the report of Estimates Committee E be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We return to where we left our consideration of Estimates Committee E with the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. We had left that on the basis that we would look at the question of the funding for the John Curtin School after we had gone through the matters we have just gone through in relation to education. My colleague Senator Tierney had foreshadowed an amendment which has been circulated. The amendment was to add to the motion that the report of Estimates Committee E be adopted the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: ", subject to the following request for amendment to the House of Representatives: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment to the bill. . .

That amendment was to omit the amount of $8.2m—which is contained on page 43 for the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, division 330, subdivision 4—for health research, including payments to the Medical Research Endowment Fund under the Medical Research Endowment Act 1937.

PARA.TAB: In light of the discussions that have been held since that foreshadowed amendment was circulated—and in particular the discussion we had here an hour or so ago—the Opposition will not go ahead with formally moving that amendment. As we understand it, the net effect of the successful passage of that amendment would be to reduce the $8.2m funding for the ANU. The reason for that is that, whereas we had believed that the request for the additional appropriation of $8.2m was to be offset by a corresponding reduction in the funding appropriation required for the ANU of $194.4m or thereabouts, contrary to that expectation on our part, the $8.2m which is now being transferred, so-called, to the Department of Health for the purpose of funding the John Curtin School has in fact been picked up in other ways, namely, as was said earlier, through additional requirements in respect of the amalgamation of the Canberra School of the Arts with the ANU. That is, an additional $2.4m; additional funding in respect of research, $4m; supplementation, $1m; and other minor requirements, such as Comcare charges, which altogether total approximately $8m—roughly the amount that was the subject of Senator Tierney's foreshadowed amendment.

I would have to say that I find it, as does Senator Tierney and indeed all members of the Opposition, quite extraordinary that we have a situation now whereby under the system of presenting Additional Estimates such a so-called transfer could be made whilst at the same time there is no corresponding offset within the appropriations for the department from which the transfer is being made.
Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The net effect of what has happened here is that there is an additional $8m for the ANU which has not been the subject of advice to the Senate in the Additional Estimates procedures. That is an extraordinary state of affairs. The Department of Finance has advised that this is all legitimate under the existing arrangements:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Finance . . . has advised that it is not necessary to provide comment in the PPSs—
the Additional Estimates of performance statement explanations—
where the net effect of plus and minus adjustments to an Appropriation item result in no Additional Estimates being sought under that item.

In other words, theoretically we could transfer from one department to another a figure of, say, $100m, but provided that we had additional expenditure in the department from which that transfer was being made then we would not have to report that additional expenditure provided the pluses and minuses netted out. That is obviously a major deficiency in the accounting procedures and the budgetary requirement procedures of the Parliament and of the Commonwealth. I believe that is a totally unacceptable situation. I am surprised that it has not been detected before this. I do not know how long this situation has existed. Not only does the Opposition consider this to be a situation that cannot persist, but also so does the Government, from my discussions with Senator Tate earlier tonight. Following those discussions I move:

PARA.TAB: At end of that motion add—

TAB.TAB: "but that the Committee is of the opinion that, in future, program performance statements should reflect the details and the effects of plus and minus adjustments to an appropriation item, even where the result is that no Additional Estimates are being sought under that item.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress again our amazement and concern at the existing situation. It is a major loophole which needs to be closed as a matter of urgency. The Government supports that view. I hope that amendment will have the unanimous support of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Short has said, this matter was discussed with Senator Tate. I am advised that what Senator Short has said is an accurate reflection of those discussions. The issues he has mentioned touch on a rightful concern about the process and the loophole that he has identified. The Government will vote for the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE F

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will move to Estimates Committee F and the Department of Industrial Relations. We will proceed according to the running sheet. Are there any matters before program 1 on the running sheet is mentioned?

—During Estimates committee hearings the Minister outlined the problem with regard to New Zealand shearers. At that particular time I asked whether, in terms of the public announcement the Minister had made, actual evidence had been taken that shearers or shearing teams were undercutting the award. The Minister at that time said that he had no evidence. Mr Marshman said that the Department had not investigated any cases. Since the Estimates hearings, have any cases been investigated by the Department? Is there any hard evidence now that shearing teams are undercutting the award? If there is, have they been prosecuted?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot recall the precise language that was used in the discussion, although I have a very clear recollection of the matter being raised by Senator Crane. I would be a bit surprised if my answer and Mr Marshman's answer were as categorical as Senator Crane has said. No doubt the record will reveal that.

PARA.TAB: The first comment I make is that, as was the case when the Estimates Committee met, so is the case now. There is a picket or an encampment, or whatever one might call it, of shearers protesting at what they refer to as New Zealand shearers coming into Australia and working below the rates in the pastoral award as contractors. They cite that the exchange rate difference between the New Zealand dollar and the Australian dollar means that they can still earn a reasonable income by New Zealand standards but work below the Australian award standards and thus there is an incentive for New Zealand based shearers to come here and do that. That was the situation back then.

The second point is that to actually detect the number of people involved in this type of operation is difficult. One can look at the trans-Tasman immigration traffic and the growth in it. One can try to inspect each shed but that means that one has to be aware of when each shed is shearing and one has to be able to get there and check the time and wages book. It also means that in some cases more than one time and wages book is kept—one for the inspector and one for the worker—and there is a difference. So this is a practice for which it is very hard to gather provable evidence to secure a conviction. But I understand my Department, through its industrial inspectors, has inspected for compliance with superannuation payments fairly extensively around Australia, and it has done that in conjunction with the activities of State government inspectorates. In the course of that they have inspected rural areas to uncover any breaches of the pastoral award.

I am not quite sure what the results of that have been. I have it in my memory—I am not sure of how accurate this is—that there was a case uncovered which was rectified by the contractor or the farmer at the time it was established and thus did not go to court for prosecution. Frequently, when this sort of thing occurs it does not necessarily go the gamut of the legal process. Such matters can well be settled at the time. I am also aware of some actions taken by the AWU in inspecting for compliance with the award. I cannot be sure what the outcome of those actions are.

The fourth point I would make is that I think the anecdotal evidence is sufficient to establish a justifiable case. While there are fewer shearers because of a reduction in the flock and while graziers and family members sometimes do their own shearing because of the price of wool, nonetheless there has been a much greater reduction in the use of Australian shearers than one would expect because of those factors. When that is put alongside the anecdotal evidence, we are satisfied that there is a problem here. Whilst the dimensions are hard to define, it is nonetheless a real and significant problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer. I would remind the Minister that he and Mr Marshman were very categorical in what they said during the Estimates hearings. I will quote from the hearings. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I understand you to say that you had not had any requests to investigate any particular circumstances as far as shearing was concerned. Did I hear that right?
Mr Marshman came back with an answer which is in the Hansard record. In part, he said:
To date, we have not had those complaints to be able to investigate them.
Once again I raised the issue with the Minister. On page 4 of the Hansard record the Minister replied:
I do not have any evidence that respondents to the national award are doing that.

I raise this matter because of the difficult position which currently exists in the Australian wool industry. Fortunately, it is not as difficult as it was 12 months ago and we can look forward to it improving once again this year. This is good news.

PARA.TAB: Figures have been quoted in the press that up to 42 per cent of the sheep shorn in Australia were shorn by New Zealand shearers. The only State about which I have been able to get information that I would regard as reliable is Victoria where the figure was 5 per cent and not 42 per cent. I think it is absolutely despicable, particularly in view of the answers I was given, that this matter has not been followed through further if this practice is as widespread as it is supposed to be.

As the Minister knows—and I declare an interest in this—the wool industry is a principal part of the operation of my family's farm, which is now run by my son. Some of the public utterances that have been made in recent times do not help the situation as far as the Australian wool industry is concerned. This is moving slightly off the mark, but a statement was made today that the Federal Labor Caucus has called on the Government to cancel arrangements which will allow New Zealanders to work freely in Australia. Once again, I find that situation alarming.

There is a CER agreement between Australia and New Zealand. There have been some winners and some losers under that agreement. However, the bottom line is—and I think the Minister would have to agree—that Australia is better off because of that agreement. In my view, in recent years New Zealand shearers have made a very worthwhile contribution to the Australian shearing industry. Likewise, Australian shearers have made a very useful contribution to the New Zealand shearing industry.

These sorts of claims are not backed up by any hard evidence. They are backed by a Minister of the Crown, which gives them a public legitimacy but not a factual legitimacy. I can come very close to home on this—my son is currently working in New Zealand. A lot of Australians are actually working in New Zealand. I repeat that this attack has no hard evidence behind it.

I do not personally have any argument with the situation outlined by the Minister in regard to complying with the occupational superannuation requirements. I do have some problems with occupational superannuation per se, but that is a different matter. It is in the award and is part of the system. In any event, I do not have any problem with that part of the award being upheld.

However, if there is a problem with the award, I would request that the Minister and his Department should go out and investigate this matter properly. In fact, they should get hard evidence about what is occurring. I will not say that this practice is not occurring, but I can say that I have been unable to find any evidence of it, nor have I been given any information in that respect. I said at the last Estimates hearing that I had had contact with the National Farmers Federation and its affiliates with regard to whether or not they had been promoting this activity. I checked with the NFF—I did not go to the affiliates on this occasion. I was informed by the industrial officer of the NFF that the Federation had not been promoting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we go any further, I mention that this matter is listed as a reservation in Senator Crane's list of two reservations. The fact that a reservation is there does not necessarily mean that it is in order. In fact, I do not think it is in order. I mention that so that honourable senators will know that we should not spend too much time on this item.

—I wish to address a point that I saw Senator Cook make while I was watching him on the television monitor. I heard him say halfway through a sentence or paragraph that New Zealand shearers come to Australia and shear for less than Australians.

—Perhaps I can assist in order to speed up the proceedings. I did not say that. I was saying that it is contended that New Zealand shearers come here and, because of the exchange rate, they can earn above their going rate in New Zealand but still work below the Australian rate. That was the point. I was indicating the contention which provides the financial incentive for this practice to occur.

—I thank the Minister for that explanation. He is technically correct that in some cases New Zealand shearers come here and are willing to shear for less than Australians. But that does not mean that they are shearing for less than the Australian award. There is no concrete evidence around that I or anyone else can find—unless the Minister can put it forward here—that they shear for less than the award. It is just as well that we had an influx of New Zealand shearers a few years ago to help us get over our shearing problems. The industry was having a problem getting the wool off the sheep at a time when it was producing over 1,000 million kilos a year.

PARA.TAB: Let us get it quite straight: to my knowledge and to most people's knowledge, the New Zealand shearers are not shearing for less than the Australian award. The point is that they may be shearing for less than that which Australians want to shear. I believe that the New Zealand shearers have also introduced flexibility into shearing hours. If half a week, a couple of days or even a Friday is lost, I cannot see any reason why a shearer should not shear on the weekend to make up for it. New Zealand shearing teams also have no tendency to declare sheep wet that are dry. It is a good practice, especially about Friday lunchtime when there has been no rain for three weeks, to all of a sudden declare the sheep wet. The tendency of New Zealand shearers is not to do that. I am not saying that the majority of Australian shearers would do that, but quite a few would.

There could be many Australians shearing in New Zealand for part of the year. The Australian shearing season gets bogged down towards the autumn. It started spreading out the year round when sheep numbers were up around the 200 million mark and we were producing one million tonnes of wool. However, now that the numbers have been cut back, there is an Australian season and a New Zealand season, and shearers tend to flow backwards and forwards.

I suppose it is going overboard to say that there are just as many Australians in New Zealand as there are New Zealanders here. If the Department checked before it made any recommendation to cut out work visas for New Zealanders in Australia, it would be surprised to find how many Australians are working in New Zealand.

New Zealand shearers have been blamed for the introduction of the wide comb into Australia. To many experienced shearers and experienced shearing contractors, if they do not already know, a good shearer does not shear with a wide comb any more. Senator Crane is an experienced shearer. He sheared for much longer than I did. He is also younger than me. He would have used the wide comb whereas I have not. More sheep cannot be sheared with a wide comb but can be sheared more easily.

A good Australian shearer or a good Kiwi shearer is only interested in shearing 200 sheep a day, and that is about it. The easier he can do that 200, the better it is for his health—and, for that matter, the sheep's health. The wide comb and the wider blows do it a lot easier. It has nothing to do with greedy shearers trying to do more than anyone else. Having listened to all these arguments on wide combs for about the last ten years, I thought I should put that on the record.

I saw the Australian shearers protesting out the front of Parliament House yesterday. Senator Cook and others in this place say that they are cutting out work in Australia. I believe that they should come in here with definite figures of how much they are taking off, how much is in Australia and all those sort of things before they make all those wild allegations. I thank you, Mr Chairman, for the opportunity of putting those points once and forever into the record. Hopefully, we will get back to quoting exact figures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I note your observation about the relevance of all this. I do not propose to join in the political debate here, save to say that even though Senator Panizza has made remarks about weekend work and wet sheep—
—And flexibility.

—And flexibility. I hope and, for the sake of this discussion, believe that his remarks are not meant to encourage or incite people to try to work below the conditions and provisions of an award of either the State or Commonwealth jurisdictions, because that would be inciting people to break the law.
—Flexibility is now in the award.

—As long it is done within the award and there is no contracting below the standards of the award, that is fine. In relation to the other point that has been raised here, my Department has made no recommendations about immigration. However, I make the observation that, given the exchange rate, the idea that New Zealand shearers can come here and work below Australian rates and still be above the New Zealand rates in income and go back across the Tasman and escape taxation provisions is, in all reasonableness, some clue to the financial incentives for this practice.

PARA.TAB: The other debate has been about how widespread it is and why more of them have not been prosecuted. I will not join in that debate. I never made the allegations that Senator Panizza has picked me up on about the figure of 65 per cent. I am not sure of the figures myself, but there is a picket line or a demonstration encampment at the front of this Parliament House of Australian shearers supporting Australian workers doing jobs that are normally held open for Australians. I do not think that they are phantoms or ghosts arguing about a phantom or ghost issue; they are real Australians concerned about a genuine issue that affects their livelihoods.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage it might be better to move to program 1 and subprogram 1.2—Industrial Relations Development.

—In the Estimates, I raised the matter of Goninan and best practice grants. I thank the Minister for his answer. I also acknowledge the fact that I have received a letter from Mr Chris Higgins, the General Manager of Goninan. I asked some questions at the Estimates because there was an industrial dispute on at that time after the best practices grant had been awarded. It was brought to my attention that some pressure could have been applied to Goninan with regard to the continuation of that grant as a result of some comments by Mr Higgins before the Arbitration Commission. I also acknowledge the fact that Mr Marshman rang me with regard to this matter. Firstly, what processes does a company have to go through to obtain a best practices grant? In particular, in the current situation, does it have to sign an agreement that it will agree to accept accord mark VI?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Two questions were asked: what processes and does a company have to sign an agreement to accept accord mark VI. It does not have to sign any agreement about accord mark VI, V, IV, III, II, I or VII, VIII, IX or X. It is an interesting question from Senator Crane because he is an avid student of industrial relations, albeit from a conservative, some would say reactionary, point of view. It is a bit late in the night so I will not get heated about it. That he should ask me a question about how one qualifies for a best practice grant is revealing in terms of his studentship of this subject.

PARA.TAB: A best practice grant is awarded to an Australian company that has demonstrated to the satisfaction of a commercially oriented independent panel that it represents international best practice in its management, in the involvement of its work forces in the management of the company and in the achievement of its corporate and strategic goals. It succeeds upon a recommendation by this independent commercially orientated panel to me; it succeeds in a competitive bidding arrangement.

From memory, the procedures are these: we advertise that the grants are available and we invite bids. Bids are made setting out the industrial relations program of the company; how its workers are involved in the goal setting for the company; what arrangements it has to establish a productivity ethos within the company; and what arrangements there are to share the rewards of higher productivity between the customers of the company, the owners of the company and the workers who help create the wealth and productivity of the company.

A set of criteria is published which I can make available to Senator Crane. Each of these bids is assessed and analysed by a commercially orientated panel which is chaired by John Prescott, the Chief Executive Officer of BHP. The panel then makes recommendations to me. There are usually—this is expected—vastly more applicants than there are grants available. We wish to encourage a degree of competition in the achievement of recognition of best. If everyone was best, best would be devalued coinage; if a few are best and there is competition to achieve it, it is rare and exclusive coinage—it is genuinely best. It is a competitive bidding process. There are always many more bids than there are grants.

To get through the assessment filters one has to be an Australian company which is a pacesetter and a trailblazer in improving the workplace culture—the relations between employers and employees in the workplace. As I have said, there are guidelines and I can make them available to Senator Crane.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note Senator Cook's comments. I think he used the word `reactionary'. It certainly was not my intention to be reactionary, but if he would like me to be, I will be, and I do not think I would be the only one in this chamber in that category.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the Goninan situation and the fact that there is an acknowledgment that officers of the Department spoke to the management of Goninan with respect to the grant. What is the process for officers speaking to a company such as Goninan? Of course, this could also apply to other companies. Is the Minister made aware of that? Does he endorse it formally in the sense of signing a document or anything of that nature which authorises that that approach should be made? Or is it something which the Department does internally?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is something which the Department does internally, but it does it with my approval. In the usual course of events, it would be indicated for my attention that this may have been done. With respect to Goninan, it is my understanding that Goninan has written to Senator Crane providing a full explanation of the circumstances from its point of view.
—I have acknowledged that.

—Senator Crane also acknowledged that Deputy Secretary Marshman of my Department telephoned him from a departmental point of view. Senator Crane omitted to acknowledge that I also wrote to him. We do that because these companies are assessed by a commercially orientated panel as examples of best practice. They sign a contract to enable their best practice to be broadcast and disseminated through the commercial and industrial world so that other companies can be aware of where best practice has been identified, look at the case study and learn from what occurs. Where they wish, other companies can emulate the success of a best practice company.

PARA.TAB: I think Goninan was the company about which there was some argument before the Industrial Relations Commission which, on the face of it, may have been taken to contradict part of the submission upon which the expert panel made its assessment. Where that apparent contradiction arises it is entirely appropriate, as this company is in receipt of public moneys, that the officers of my Department would speak to the company about that, ascertain the truth of the matter and advise me accordingly. There is nothing exceptional about that. Senator Crane, this Parliament and the people of Australia would expect that we would husband public moneys—which are, after all, taxpayers' moneys—in an appropriately frugal and responsible way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one more question with respect to Goninan. I make the point that I acknowledged in my opening comments that I had received a letter from Senator Cook and one from Mr Higgins and that Mr Marshman had telephoned me. I refer to the letter of instruction which was presented to Senator Cook with respect to Goninan's position. Is Senator Cook prepared to table that letter?
—Is Senator Crane asking me to table any reports which my Department may have given me about its interview with Goninan?

—No, I am asking the Minister whether an inquiry was made by his Department and whether he was made aware of it. I gather from Senator Cook's answer that he would have been shown a minute with regard to that and that the Department would have acted on it after it had informed him. I am asking whether Senator Cook would be prepared to table that written advice from his Department which he authorised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am puzzled because I do not recall—I would have to go back and look at the record—that I issued any direction to my Department to talk to Goninan with respect to

SPEECH.PARA: the apparent contradiction between its submission to the best practice board and its submission to the Industrial Relations Commission. I think the Department did that routinely and furnished a report to me about that. I do not recall directing my Department in any way to do that, but I would expect it to do that, I would be disappointed if it did not do that and it has lived up to my expectations in that it did do it.

PARA.TAB: Is Senator Crane asking me to make available to him what the confidential advice from my Department to me was after its interview? If Senator Crane wants that document, I would have to look at it to make sure that there were no matters of commercial-in-confidence involved. I would not want to be party to revealing those in a public way. I am sure that Senator Crane understands and appreciates that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do understand that. I was asking for the minute, not after the event, but prior to the event—the information that was given to Senator Cook. I took it from Senator Cook's letter that that would have been given to him in writing and that he would have looked at it. That is how I interpreted Senator Cook's answer. That is what I am asking for—the information which was given to Senator Cook before the discussions were held with Mr Chris Higgins of Goninan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there was no documentation before the discussions were held. My Department provided me with a report following those discussions. The other party that has an interest is the panel that adjudicates upon the best practice submissions. It would have a reasonable question in the circumstances that applied here. I cannot account for, nor am I in a position to really know, what the panel, acting independently of me, may have done in the case of Goninan.

—The Minister has said that he is not aware of any documentation. If it happens to turn up and there is no confidentiality about it, those parts can be deleted. I would certainly appreciate a copy of it.

PARA.TAB: The next point that I want to raise with the Minister relates to the workplace reform program and, in particular, the workplace reform centres. I understand from the previous Estimates that it was considered that the workplace reform centres would be profitable or self-funding before 30 June this year—in fact, I believe it was by March. That being the case, could the Minister advise whether it is correct that another $500,000 has been budgeted to be put into the workplace reform centres in the coming year?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two parts to Senator Crane's question. First, if there is any information that I can provide Senator Crane with that is not commercial in confidence—to fuel his interest in the best practice program and this particular company—I will provide him with it and I will be happy to do so.
—Are you insinuating I shouldn't have an interest?
—No, I am saying to fuel it—that is, to encourage and fan it.
—A very strange use of words.

—I would have thought that it was not. I certainly want to encourage Senator Crane's interest in best practice. If there is any material that I can provide him with in this case, I will, as long as it does not breach commercial-in-confidence principles.

PARA.TAB: The second part of the question related to workplace reform. I am not entirely sure whether the transition has been made yet, but each of the workplace reform centres was established as a freestanding independent workplace reform centre and had to reach self-sufficiency within a given period. It is my understanding that the Sydney centre had to do that by 30 June but the other centres, which started later, had to achieve self-sufficiency by their later dates, so they do not all uniformly come up to 30 June for self-sufficiency purposes.

The boards of these centres make their own corporate decisions, and these boards have agreed among themselves to aggregate each of the centres and form a national centre—rather than have regional centres in each of the capital cities, plus the Hunter Valley—to obtain economies of scale, standardisation of training for their officers and a standardisation of service provision for their clients. In doing that, we have made provision for $500,000 which, as I understand it, just about sees out the appropriation that was made for all of the centres, if we took them altogether, in seeing through the terms of their original contract to complete self-sufficiency by their relevant dates.

It may be—I have to check this fact; I will obtain this information in half a tick—that we have added in a bit more in order to complete the transition from freestanding capital city based centres to one national centre, because I see real advantages in that economy of scale being achieved and we may have had to grease the rails a little in order to achieve that. I am sorry, I am wrong about that. The $500,000 is right on track for the funding. I had it in mind that I would seek further appropriations, but I am advised that that was not necessary, so I did not. I am pleased to know that that worked out efficiently in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the fact that there was a move to a national centre, could the Minister advise of the assets which exist in various workplace reform centres? Will they remain the property of the various centres, or will they be amalgamated into the one set of assets? Who actually owns those assets at this time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —They have merged all of their assets into one united group of assets. That was the decision of all of the boards. As I say, the boards are not in the position of receiving direction from me. The boards are responsible for their own decisions and they have to take commercial responsibility for that. Some of their asset base, which relates to contracts with clients, involves commercial-in-confidence dealings, so I cannot report on those. The combined national centre will issue annual reports which set out the proceedings of the centre, as the centres did when they were capital city based. Who owns the assets? The assets are owned by the national workplace resource centre—I think it has just coined a new name for itself, but it is a similar title. It is owned by that corporate entity.

—I understand from the previous answer that some of the centres were, in fact, operating within the self-funding guidelines, but a number were not. Are there any liabilities in terms of those that are not, and if so, who will be picking up those liabilities? Will they be picked up by the Government?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is that there are these workplace resource centres in capital cities around Australia, and one in the Hunter. Each started life at a different time on the calendar. The first off the blocks was the Sydney one, and I think the last off the blocks was the Hobart one. They all started at different times, but they needed the same time—I think it was three years—to reach self-sufficiency.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, the Sydney centre is self-sufficient and will meet the terms of its original agreement in time—or would have done had it not gone national. I think the same is true of the Hunter centre. The others were at various stages of moving towards self-sufficiency, and our commitment was to support them for that three-year period, but to end support after it. We got them started. When they are all rolled together, there are assets and liabilities. The net result is that as a Government we will not be picking up any more than what we committed to when they were the disparate parts of what is now the whole. There will be no additional expenditure above that expenditure that we provided for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would it be possible for the Minister's Department to supply copies of all contracts that have been completed to date by each of the centres? Also, is there a program of future contracts which could be supplied to us?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat that all of the centres, when they were free standing, State based centres and now, as the national centre, are corporate entities in their own right. The board is responsible for their activities. I have no power of direction over them. They issue reports in the proper way. I cannot therefore ask them for—nor am I in a position of having available to me—the information the honourable senator now seeks. Much of that information about contracts between them and its clients are matters of commercial in confidence that would not be able to be revealed at any time. So I am not able to comply with the honourable senator's request.

—My question relates to the board that will be running this new mega national resource centre, for want of a better term. Could the Minister outline to us—he may wish to take this on notice—who the board members will be, how they were chosen and whether there were any qualifications required in the choosing of the various board members. I guess one might also ask what size the board is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I can take that on notice and supply the honourable senator with the information. I do not have to hand a document setting out the board members' qualifications and the method of appointing them. If I can put it in these terms, the national board reflects in a macrocosm what the independent, free standing, capital city based centres that formerly existed reflected in microcosm. Therefore, the board is tripartite in nature. There are union representatives and company representatives on those boards and people appointed by me to those boards to represent me. Once they are on those boards they do not represent me; they are, under the articles of the company, responsible to the company.
—Who are you trying to fool?
—They do not represent me. Nor can I command them to. They have obligations as directors of that company.

—I thank the Minister for offering to provide that information. When he gets that information for us, could he inform us what the term of each of the members of the board will be, the method by which they will roll over and the various aspects of how the board will be run into the future? In addition—and the Minister may be able to answer this now—with regard to the various State centres or free standing centres, to use the Minister's words, will there continue to be a board running them under the national board or will those boards disappear? What is the status of the structure which will run the various boards?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will supply the information the honourable senator has asked for, but I point out that it is publicly available in the articles of the company. The former boards that applied in the States—I think it is true that some switches in personnel may occur when you make a transition like this—by and large are now constituted as regional advisory boards. It is my understanding that the intention of establishing a national rather than a State based structure was that many of the industries in which they operate are national in character. The transport industry, the rail industry, the metal manufacturing industry and so on are national industries. They are not industries that are necessarily peculiar to one location or State, although there may be a predominance of them in some locations.

PARA.TAB: However, it was thought that while the national character of industry structure in Australia should be addressed by a national company, nonetheless—Senator Crane and I as Western Australians are keenly aware of this—the regional requirements are sometimes not accurately weighted into the mix. Therefore, the regional boards were incorporated in the national structure to provide regional balance to the national focus of the new centre. The old State boards have been incorporated for that purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that answer. The Minister has referred to these things being available in the articles of the company. At each Estimates I have asked questions with regard to these resource centres and tonight is the first we have heard of the matter. From the position the Minister is in and the information I have gleaned over the last couple of days that there might be something in the wind, I find it very strange, in view of the questions that were asked at the Additional Estimates, that no reference was made to this changed circumstance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, back then the changed circumstance was, as I recall, a gleam in people's eyes but not a fact. Secondly, I do not think any of the questions went to that. Thirdly, if Senator Crane is chastising me—if I can put it in those words—for not saying that this information was available in a publicly ascertainable way in the past, I ask him to please believe me when I say that I thought that was implicit in the circumstances and that he would have known that anyway.

—There being no further questions in relation to subprogram 1.2, we move to program 2, subprogram 2.1, Australian Public Service Pay and Structures. I have looked at this item and I do not think the reservation has anything to do with what was in the Additional Estimates, but it is too late in the night to argue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pursue some matters which were raised in the Additional Estimates and ask some subsequent questions on that topic. In the Estimates Committee on 2 April, an officer of the Minister's Department said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission—
that is, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission—

in its test case on redundancy, basically said that if a person were in receipt of an employer-financed benefit, that service should not be counted for subsequent redundancy purposes. The Government's policy is entirely consistent with that.

The officer concerned is the division head responsible for redundancy policy for government business enterprises. Subsequent inquiries from this officer revealed that he was referring to the termination, change and redundancy case, the decision in which was handed down on 2 August 1984. I have studied that case very carefully and found that it enunciated no such principle as stated before the Committee. I put it to the Minister that the policy advice which has been given to him and to previous Ministers has been based on a false premise. Will the Minister now instruct his Department to conduct a review of the effects of the present policy on redundancy on former Australian Defence Force employees of the Commonwealth, which it appears his Department has striven so hard to avoid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman is probably well ahead of me in that she has had the advantage of studying the 1984 redundancy decision of the Full Bench of what was then the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I am not familiar, on recollection, with all the findings in that case. Senator Newman has put to me that I was not advised accurately, based on a reading of the judgment in that case, and that this affects the redundancy provisions made for the armed forces. I certainly will treat that matter with due gravity and responsibility. I will obtain a report from my Department and look at it from the point of view of the questions the honourable senator has raised. If there is a need to make some changes, naturally I will make them, and I will keep the honourable senator informed.

—I thank the Minister because, as he would realise, it is a very important issue to the individuals concerned. If I am correct, it clearly means to me that the policy should be looked at afresh. I also draw it to the Minister's attention that, on or about 6 May this year, the Commonwealth and Defence Force Ombudsman advised the Department of Industrial Relations that there were gross inequities in the policy we are now discussing. Is the Minister aware that the Ombudsman has in fact taken an interest in this policy and has advised the Minister's Department of his concerns about it? The Minister has said that he will look again at the policy but I ask him to look at it not only from the point of view of my concerns but also in relation to the Ombudsman's concerns. Is the Minister aware that the Ombudsman has been in touch with his Department on this policy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I recall, I had been routinely advised by my Department, but I thank Senator Newman for drawing it to my attention because I do not want to omit any observations or expressions of view made by the Ombudsman if I am going to look at what Senator Newman has raised fully and properly and deal with it in a proper way.

—If the revision of the redundancy policy affecting these employees results in a decision that the policy must be changed, and given that the Commonwealth's attention was drawn to these inequities as early as July 1991, I ask the Minister whether he will consider—I would prefer him to ensure it but I suppose he will say only that he will consider it—backdating the benefits of the revised policy to 1 July 1991 in terms of equity and justice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will always act in terms of equity and justice, and if there is an error we will treat that in the appropriate way. I should also say that, on these matters, my Department does not act alone. My Department acts in consultation with the Department of Finance and, if there is an error that requires rectification, a joint decision made between me and the relevant Minister will be required.

—I thank the Minister. Finally, the official concerned who gave me that answer in the Estimates hearings spoke to my office afterwards. He undertook to look into the matter further and said that he would get back to my office. He was asked to explain why he claimed that defence personnel would in fact end up better off. He was asked to send a table of comparisons between a Defence employee and a Public Service employee in a comparable redundancy situation. That officer said that he would send that to my office but it has never come. I wonder whether the Minister would mind seeing whether he could give that a push along.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be delighted to. I would be delighted to go further, too, because I know of Senator Newman's interest in these matters. If I might make this observation, I am glad that a senator in the Opposition takes a direct interest in the remuneration, conditions and standards for the defence forces and has an articulate knowledge of that and is able to present it in this chamber and elsewhere. I think it is very valuable for the defence forces and a very valuable scrutiny of Government actions.

PARA.TAB: When I am going through this process I would be happy to have a talk to Senator Newman about her concerns and considerations on a face-to-face basis and deal with this in a way in which, even if in the end she does not agree with the decision we make, at least her input will have gone into it and she will understand the basis of the Government's actions. Of course, she may agree with the decision, and that would be a happy outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for those kind words, but I trust that his decision will be such that I will agree with it joyfully.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —There being no further questions on the Department of Industrial Relations, we will proceed to consideration of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Are there any questions on the estimates for that Department? There being no questions, that concludes the consideration of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. I therefore put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the report of Estimates Committee F be adopted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.PARA: That, in relation to the report of Estimates Committee C, the Committee consider the departments in the following order:
That the report of Estimates Committee C be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any questions on the running sheet in relation to the Department of Social Security? There being no questions, we will proceed to the Department of Transport and Communications. Are there any questions on program 1, Aviation?

—I would like to ask some questions in relation to Senator Macdonald's reservation with the TAAATS program. By way of introduction, I point out that TAAATS started off with the requirement for a proven off-the-shelf system with a minimum life cycle cost, to be supplied by a proven supplier of an air traffic control system. Those criteria were detailed in the ROI and repeated ad nauseam in the industry briefs that followed it.

PARA.TAB: My concern relates to the unusual procedure that was followed for the selection of the preferred tenderer and the changes that took place along the way, because it seems that we ended up with the highest priced offer, the offer with the lowest Australian content based on a DITAC assessment, the only offering without a proven man-machine interface using current generation raster display technology. Based on the vendor's information that was supplied to the Public Works Committee on 21 May, we have accepted a new system, the EUROCAT 2000, which has not been commissioned anywhere. In justification for all of this we heard that the CAA management has asserted that it has selected the new system from Thomson over the recommendations of its selection panel of engineers and air traffic controllers because it represented lower risk. There are some questions that flow from that that I would like answered.

One of the characteristics of the contract is the criticism that has come from the unsuccessful tenderers. The previous Minister for Shipping and Aviation said that there are always losers and losers always whinge, or words to that effect. I have been around here for a number of years and when contracts that were very much bigger—a whole magnitude beyond this $200m to $300m contract—were awarded. There was intense competition and there were some very disappointed losers. However, I have never heard the criticism that we are hearing now, both from within the industry and from the tenderers themselves who missed out. I draw attention to the series of letters which were written by the chairman of Siemens-Plessey when that company was eliminated in the early part of the contract selection procedure on grounds that are yet to be justified.

Hughes, a finalist in the program and a major company—a world giant with 63,000 employees—took the most unusual step of sending one of its senior vice-presidents, Mr Snyder, out here to appear before a Public Works Committee hearing. If one reads the transcripts of the Public Works Committee hearings, as I have, one comes to no other conclusion than that Hughes believed that it had been treated unfairly, and probably dishonestly, by the assessment process.

As a consequence of the appearance by Mr Snyder before the Public Works Committee, a letter was written to Mr Butcher—a seven-page technical letter which I have in my possession—listing the shortcomings and difficulties in the program proposed by the successful tenderer. It is most unusual for contractors of the stature of Hughes and Siemens-Plessey to protest; but it is far worse than that because the chairman of Hughes in America, Mr Armstrong, actually wrote to the Prime Minister calling for an independent technical assessment of the tender bids. It is known that one of the three finalists, IBM, although it made no public protest, also had major reservations and protested to the CAA, both during the selection process and after it was over.

I ask: why was Siemens Plessey eliminated in the early part of the tender selection process considering that it made a bid of $103m, which was later reduced to $95m, and taking into account the technological expertise it possessed as a world leader in air traffic control systems?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am now the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I have been sworn in in this portfolio for less than a week. In that time I have not had a chance to be briefed on the full part of the portfolio. I know that this is a matter that Senator MacGibbon is keenly interested in. His interest is shared by a number of other senators and members in both Houses and of all political persuasions. This is a matter that I have sought to obtain some information on.

PARA.TAB: Senator MacGibbon has asked: why was Siemens Plessey eliminated in, as I understand it, the pre-qualifying phase of the tender process? I can give him reasons that were offered by the CAA which, in this case, is a sovereign power unto itself about the process. I have received some departmental advice. I am not sure whether it answers the honourable senator's question in the way in which he has put it, but I will just read this advice into the record:

SPEECH.PARA: Following the evaluation of offers, the CAA advised Siemens Plessey that it did not wish to proceed with its offer and the remaining three companies—IBM, Hughes and Thomson—were invited to submit refined offers by 22 November 1991 with a view to the CAA selecting a preferred contractor and a runner-up by the end of that year.
Siemens Plessey were fully debriefed on 9 October as to the reasons for the CAA decision.

In brief, Siemens Plessey were advised that there was no single concern which caused their rejection but a set of concerns which, when put together, represented a risk that the CAA was not prepared to take.
The concerns advised were: flight data processing (FDP) development requirements and schedule; project management; systems design; elements of a technical systems offer; civil works.

Siemens Plessey made strong representations to the CAA expressing concern at the process and requested the project be cancelled. In essence, Siemens argued that the registration of interest procedure lacked any clear definition of the requirements involved and that the CAA should have used a `proper' tendering mechanism with a defined set of requirements.
Following a complete review of the evaluation process by a legal adviser to the CAA, the CAA board reconfirmed its decision to exclude Siemens from the process.
That is the advice that I have been given and I offer it as an answer to Senator MacGibbon's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the central points was the flight data processing and the risk involved with that. It was the McDonnell Detweiler system that is being used by Hughes in the Canadian air traffic control contract. If it were not acceptable for Siemens Plessey to be used as a flight data processing system, why was Hughes allowed to remain in with exactly the same program—a McDonnell Detweiler flight data processing system?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision is a decision of the CAA, and I am not sure I am in a position to answer for the CAA about the judgments it makes on technical detail. For the record, I reiterate that the flight data processing is an element of a set of five different criteria, which I have read into the record, that the CAA took into account. The concerns that the CAA had were not confined to just one of those issues—the one mentioned by Senator MacGibbon—they ranged across four others.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the internal evaluation and consideration in the minds of members of the CAA board about this element of the question which was raised, I am not in a position at this point to give any more information. If this procedure is acceptable to Senator MacGibbon, I would be prepared to take his question on notice and obtain an answer, if the CAA is in a position to offer an answer to that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his generosity. I would hope that the CAA is in a position, having made a decision, to be able to justify it fully and completely, so I look forward to a response on that.

PARA.TAB: I will approach this in a different way. Surely, if the Minister was an experienced negotiator in contracting and had a tender from someone whose credentials are impeccable, in the way that Siemens-Plessey's are, at providing off the shelf, state of the art, air traffic control technology; and that company came in with a bid, as has happened, of $95m for the program; and the Minister had been publicly saying that the contract price he expected to receive was $300m—and the actual price he did receive from Thomson was somewhere around twice the bid of Siemens—would it not be prudent to keep Siemens-Plessey in the negotiations so that there was a financial benchmark against which to judge other tenderers? It seems to me to be the height of absurdity. Here was a bona fide tender from a company with all the credentials needed to fulfil the contract, which came in at a very competitive price. Why was that company not kept in just to keep the other tenderers honest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon makes a compelling case in the way he formulates the question. I mean no disrespect to him when I say—and I mean it sincerely—that I have no way of knowing whether the case he has just made is, in fact, a fair representation of all the considerations that ought to have been taken into account. As I said, I will approach the CAA to obtain a written answer to his question. I do not wish to engage in any speculation because he seeks hard information. I think it is best that I obtain that.

—I want to move on to the tender prices for the other contractors. As I said in the Senate here on 5 May, the initial bid from Hughes was $190m and that from Thomson was $280m. In November 1991 Hughes came down to $140m and Thomson to $185m. In March 1992 the Hughes bid was around $150m and the Thomson bid was around $160m or $165m. I ask the Minister whether the orders of magnitude of those tender prices are correct?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have sought advice on that matter on the basis that the answer to this question is either yes or no—or is there some other qualification? The advice I have received is that I or other Ministers do not know the answer to the question for the reason that the prices are confidential.

—I am not asking Senator Cook for the absolute figures; I am asking him whether the magnitude of the prices I have given him are correct and whether the ratios and the relativities between the bids are correct. He would be aware, as well as everyone else in this chamber, that commercial-in-confidence has no standing before this Parliament and, furthermore, that the CAA, whatever powers and graces it might take unto itself, is answerable to this Parliament for the expenditure of funds. That is why the CAA appeared before the Public Works Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can say only that I am advised at the present time that the figures are confidential, and I do not have access to them. But I do not think that is Senator MacGibbon's question; his question essentially is whether the figures he has given this chamber are in the ballpark of the actual tender price. That is my understanding of his question.
—I asked whether it was of that magnitude and whether the relativities were correct.

—I think it follows that if I do not know what the tenders were I cannot answer the question about magnitude; and I cannot at this point. I do not know whether it is possible for me to find the magnitude without knowing the figures, but I will direct that question to the CAA. I think that answers the specific question. I think Senator MacGibbon made some other observations, but I am not sure whether they were questions.

—The reason I phrased it that way was that I anticipated that the CAA might take the same attitude to the Senate as it took to the Public Works Committee; that is, to maintain this fiction of commercial-in-confidence which, as I say, has no standing at all. If the CAA persists with this nonsense, it will be brought before the Parliament to answer. But to save that happening tonight, I asked Senator Cook about the relativities. I think it would be quite possible for him to ask his advisers—I do not know any of them; I have never seen any of them before—to confirm or deny that, because I have other questions that lead on from this that will have to be answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface the answer I will give by saying that I respect Senator MacGibbon's interest in this matter and his knowledge of this subject. Therefore, I treat his inquiries with more than the usual respect that I would accord such questions from an ordinary senator.

PARA.TAB: Senator Vanstone interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, but I think Senator MacGibbon has demonstrated that this is an area of expertise that he possesses and, therefore, in answering things on a technical base one has to be technically correct about those answers to the nth degree, whereas most of us might be satisfied with a little less deep scope penetration into the detail.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the Civil Aviation Authority has told the Public Works Committee that it will make available the figures on the Thomson bid but cannot make available the figures on the other bids because it is in negotiation with the other bidders and is not in a position, therefore, to release their prices. That would harm those negotiations. But, in any case, in this procedure of negotiation it is bound by contract at this point not to reveal those figures. Based on that advice, I have to say—I am a novice at this and Senator MacGibbon is not, so I respect his position here—that that seems to me to be a fair enough reply. Nonetheless, if he has further questions, I will do my best to answer them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an interest in this because at a Public Works Committee hearing on 11 May this year a Dr Edwards, when asked to comment on these figures, said that the comments made were inaccurate. I have done a great deal of research on them and I am assured that my figures are accurate. Can the Minister affirm that Dr Edwards was telling the truth when he said the figures were inaccurate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Dr Edwards is present in the advisers box. I have not had a chance to consult him at any length on his views. However, I can say that I am not advised of the figures and, as I said in answer to a question a moment ago—this is the advice I have received—nor can I be. In that case I do not think I can answer the question that Senator MacGibbon has now put about Dr Edwards's judgment on those figures. I am not in a position to answer that.

—As Dr Edwards is here, perhaps he will advise the Committee whether he is fencing with words when he says the figures are inaccurate. Does he mean that they are inaccurate and, if so, to what extent are they inaccurate? When I say `fencing with words', does he say that if a band of prices were quoted against a number of options that is what he meant by the figures being inaccurate? In other words, if a tender price were put in for $140m or something like that and if other options were exercised and it went up by $5m or even $10m, is that what he is talking about as being inaccurate? Or does he mean that the figures as they appear on 5 May are wrong? If so, where are they wrong?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator MacGibbon's forensic skills in posing these questions. I have no comment to make on what Dr Edwards may or may not have said to the relevant committee. I must say that, since I am not advised—nor can I be—of the bid figures, I do not know that I can help the honourable senator on ballpark indications or otherwise. But I can say this—I hope it will be received constructively as it is meant that way—in essence, negotiations with the other parties are going on. As is always the case in such a dynamic situation, should there be reason the CAA could move across to another bidder from Thomson if the price and all other circumstances were better. In certain circumstances that may be a reasonable thing to do. But those negotiations are going on at the moment and the matter is unsettled. So in those circumstances we cannot be definitive about these things—certainly I cannot.
—I will come back to this dynamic situation that the Minister is talking about in a few minutes time.
—That is my term. It may not be an accurate description.

—I think that `dynamic situation' is a correct description in the sense that it is used in physics. This goes to the heart of the whole matter. There are no fixed specifications against which the tenderer is being assessed and this is where the concern is in the industry. It is a gross departure from the systems that have been used in this country for about 30 years. Later we will explore why this was necessary. Will the Minister ask his advisers to confirm that the Hughes bid was lower than the Thomson bid, the final bid, and will he ask them to confirm that the IBM bid was similarly lower than the Thomson bid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have confirmed the position, as I understand it, that the figures are confidential. Senator MacGibbon is asking me to obtain advice about those figures which would go to how one might differentiate or weight them. The figures are confidential for the reason that they are confidential and should remain confidential because this is a commercial transaction at a stage that is not closed off. In that circumstance, I do not think I can answer Senator MacGibbon's question because he is asking me, in another way, to answer a similar sort of question to that which he posed to me a minute ago and the answer to that was the same: the figures are confidential. That leaves me in the position of saying that on the basis of that I cannot answer what Senator MacGibbon is now putting.

—I appreciate the difficulty in which the Minister is being put but, quite frankly, if I were a Minister I would not tolerate that for one second from my advisers because they are in contempt of Parliament. We will settle this matter in due course. I am not asking the Minister to reveal a confidential price; I am just asking him to confirm what is public knowledge—that the Hughes bid was lower than the Thomson bid and that the IBM bid was very close to the Hughes bid and was similarly below the Thomson bid. That does not breach any confidentiality at all about the magnitude of costs. It does not ascribe a dollar value to it. It is simply a statement of fact that one bid was lower than the other. That is all I am asking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —My dilemma is that I do not know what the bids are and because I do not know what the bids are I cannot answer the question.

—This matter will be solved and it will be solved to the satisfaction of the Parliament. For those people who have misguided views as to where their public obligations and accountabilities to the Australian Parliament lie, they are about to learn. I want to turn to the second part of it since we cannot get anywhere on the monetary side. Why was the EUROCAT 2000 system accepted from Thomson when it is a system that has not been implemented in any country in the world? It is not up and running anywhere. It is a developmental system with a very high risk and a very weak FDP component.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —There were two parts to Senator MacGibbon's last intervention. The first part was Senator MacGibbon posting his interest in this matter and his intention to pursue it further. As I have tried to intimate in my earlier answers, I appreciate, understand and respect Senator MacGibbon's interest and standing in this matter. I treat with due gravity and seriousness the observations which Senator MacGibbon makes. While I have not yet dealt with this matter, I promise Senator MacGibbon that I will deal with it expeditiously and, I would hope, in a way in which all parties can say, whatever the outcome, the matter has been treated by the Government and by me in particular in the appropriate and proper way. At this stage I have not made any decisions and will not make any decisions, but I give Senator MacGibbon that assurance.

PARA.TAB: On the EUROCAT system, my advice is that it is the next in line of a series of systems developments by Thomson. This is within the family and the illusion one could conjure up in this sense is that this is the latest version of the Ford Falcon.
