In that way it is not unproven or new technology; it is evolving technology based on earlier proven technology. Three of these systems will be delivered to different parts of the world before one is delivered to Australia. We will not be the first recipient of such a system. The FDP is based on a seventh generation Thomson FDP system, and again is evolving technology but evolving from a proven operational base.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no doubt as to the Minister's integrity and his intention to maintain the responsibilities of his office at a very high standard. However, I cannot excuse him for not asking the advisers in attendance here, such as they are, as to why the EUROCAT 2000 system was chosen. All of the documentation that came out from the CAA said that it had to be a proven off-the-shelf system, not a generation ahead or anything like that. It had to be off-the-shelf. In layman's terms, off-the-shelf means that it is up and running and is in use in other parts of the world.

PARA.TAB: The Minister has just spent quite a while telling us that both the core part of the EUROCAT system and the FDP are developments of previous generations of Thomson air traffic software. It simply cannot be an off-the-shelf system. The Minister's first question to the advisers who are present should be: why did they depart from one of their principal stipulations that it be a proven off-the-shelf system?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —We may have a semantic difference here, although I am not sure that we do. My understanding now is that the qualification was that the equipment would be based on systems as far as possible proven elsewhere. If I am right about that, we would not want to tie ourselves to a system that was an old model. We would want to be sure that we had a good, new model system, a system which was largely proven and developed and operational elsewhere. That is my understanding of that criteria. I will just ascertain whether my somewhat less than technical expression of the terms, nonetheless, conveys the true impression. I have just received a nod from an adviser who is sitting in the box; therefore, that is my advice, and I offer it to you as the explanation as to why the acceptance of the Thomson system was based on evolving technology but, nonetheless, a proven technological base.

—If it is evolving technology and the interpretation of a proven off-the-shelf system in the Minister's mind is technology that is evolving from something that is up and running, I accept that. Did all the other tenderers know that that definition pertained to proven off-the-shelf systems? Were they made aware of that clearly and unambiguously?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator MacGibbon's question is yes, they were.

—We now come to the business of risk, because the CAA has made great play of how it wishes to minimise risk. It is a well-known fact in the aviation world that Thomson-CSF is the worst writer of software programs in the air traffic control world. The Minister has seen that in this country with the problems we had in Melbourne and the ones we are having at the present time in Cairns, and I do not doubt that we will have problems in other Thomson systems when they are installed.

PARA.TAB: Why do we move to an evolutionary system, which means a considerable increase in the amount of software, when it is coming from a supplier with a proven poor record of being able to write air traffic control software? Why do we classify that as low risk?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a decision that the CAA board takes, of course. I must say that there are similarities between the nonsense that Senator MacGibbon has run consistently in this debate. I heard some quite hilarious and amazing stuff from Senator MacGibbon about colour raster screens and how it was going to take Thomson 10 years to develop them.
—You would not know what a colour raster system was.

—I have actually seen the systems operational, and they are all supplied by Sony. The Sony screen is used with the Hughes system and the Sony colour screen is also used with the Thomson system. I hope that I will actually have the opportunity of rebutting the nonsense that Senator MacGibbon has delivered ridiculous point by ridiculous point. Of course, as Senator Schacht and I both know, we sat on the pilots dispute committee and listened—
—That is right.

—As Senator Schacht will testify, we sat and listened to Senator MacGibbon coming in with this pseudo air of authority that he has on these matters and delivering the same undiluted garbage day after day.

—I raise a point of order. We were discussing in the Committee stage of the Appropriation Bills matters of importance to the Senate in relation to the Bill. An abusive Minister has now come in and made a personal attack on me. I ask you, Madam Temporary Chairman, to instruct the Minister to shut up or get out.
—On the point of order, the Minister is someone I have admired from this side of the chamber at times for the way he has handled—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Senator Brownhill has the floor on a point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the way he attacked Senator MacGibbon did not do the Minister a lot of justice. The Minister should go back to answering the questions and getting on with the Estimates so that we can all get home to bed.

—It would be helpful if the Minister would withdraw the reference to Senator MacGibbon's contribution being—I think the term was—`unadulterated garbage'. That is an offensive remark, and I ask the Minister to withdraw it and continue with the debate.

—I withdraw, but I wish to make the point that I walked into this chamber—and the Hansard will show it—just in time to hear Senator MacGibbon do something that he is famous for. You would have heard it, Madam Temporary Chairman, and I do object to it. They were derogatory, insulting remarks and personal reflections on the advisers `such as they are' who are sitting in this box and have no opportunity of replying to this personal abuse across the chamber. That got my back up. It is reasonable that if Senator MacGibbon wants to abuse people, he should at least abuse the senators in this chamber, who can reply.

—The Minister has withdrawn the offensive remark. If someone at the appropriate time wants to make a remark about something Senator MacGibbon said and reply to that in an appropriate manner, it is up to that senator to do so at the time. But in the meantime, it would be helpful if at this hour of the night the debate could be conducted in an orderly manner.
—We all have!
—I remind senators on my right that if they want to interject, they might choose to do so from their seats.

—The question of risk is always considered to be a valid judgment, and one only has to look at the General Accounting Office reports of the United States to see how important that is. A lot of nonsense has been delivered in this debate about Thomson. I have been to New Zealand recently and seen the system which Senator O'Chee described as being an `outrageous disaster' operating absolutely glitch free to the satisfaction of everybody, technicians and government. He should have a talk to his National Party colleague. I was talking to Minister Storey only a week ago, and the New Zealand Government is delighted with the Thomson system. The question of risk raised by Senator MacGibbon is important.

PARA.TAB: Senator Calvert interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the honourable senator been there? Has he had a look at the system?
—I have heard some reports about it.

—Who told you; was it Senator MacGibbon? I have heard a lot of nonsense about the question of risk. One piece of nonsense was the assertion made by Senator MacGibbon—which has been picked up by journalists and run as fact—that Hughes adopted this incredibly unusual procedure of protesting when it lost a $300m contract. I read that stuff. This is no reflection on Hughes—it is a very fine company—but I thought, `That's got to be nonsense. A big, aggressive, successful American company never complaining about losing anything?'.

PARA.TAB: So I had a look at precedent. I did not have to go back very far; I have the judgment in my office. In 1988 Hughes lost a contract to do with air traffic control systems to IBM in the United States. It took the FAA to court over that and lost. What did the FAA decide? The parallels are quite extraordinary. It decided that in fact the Hughes system was technically either as good as, or superior to, the IBM product—there was a marginal difference. But, at the end of the day, the FAA decided that, on the question of developmental risk, it was safer to go with IBM than Hughes. Hughes lost the contract and the court upheld that decision. I simply use that 1988 case to illustrate that the question of developmental risk is an informed judgment. It is not a technical judgment; it is an informed judgment.

I want to get one thing absolutely clear. The officers of the CAA have been constantly vilified and defamed in print. I think it is outrageous that Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards were named in a newspaper the other day as having hijacked this matter and made decisions about it. They did nothing of the sort. The decision was taken by the Board of the CAA. Honourable senators should look at the composition of the CAA Board and at the CVs of the people who constitute it. In terms of their commercial expertise and background, they are a long way from being dribbling idiots.

The Board made the decision; not the management. This is the fundamental point I want to make here tonight: it made a decision to continue a tender process which, to this point in time, has not yet been completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister explain what capacity the CAA has in this 18-week negotiating period to write the precise details of the contract using its own resources, without reference to Thomson?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is a nonsense. The 18-week period is there to go through the detailed specifications of delivering this system. As the CAA Chairman—apart from the chief executive—has made clear again and again: there was no decision. The very process is in fact designed for no decision to be made as to who the successful tenderer will be. If Thomson fails to come up with this detailed specification, as I have said again and again in the Senate, it could well be—I think this is the great difficulty we are all placed in with regard to this matter—that Hughes is the successful tenderer.

—Given the non-cooperative attitude of the Minister and the advisers from the CAA, I do not see much point in pursuing this issue at the present time. But I say to the Minister: had we followed the accepted procedures for the tendering and selection of contractors that have been set up by this Parliament over 30 years, the arguments we are now having about this would never have arisen. Even if we had gone down the unusual path that we did go down, if there had been any cooperation from the CAA—if it had said how it had arrived at the decision and justified it—we would never have been in the situation that we are in tonight.

PARA.TAB: Believe me, this is not over. We will get accountability from the CAA as to how it arrived at that decision. We will go through all of its papers—by one process or another—because we are not satisfied that it can account to the Australian public for what it is proposing to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing needs to be made very clear, and I will make it clear again. This is not, and should not be, some sort of a game of headline hunting or point scoring. At the end of the day the object of this exercise—an exercise which I hope Senator MacGibbon and Senator O'Chee would support—is to fulfil a very urgent need, which is to provide a new national air traffic control system for Australia. We urgently need to replace the hopelessly outdated systems in Brisbane, Sydney and Canberra, and we need to do it very quickly.

PARA.TAB: There has never been any suggestion—and I say this on the record now—that anybody is trying to hide anything. In fact, I want to read into the record the process, of which the Committee has been advised a million times. It is:

SPEECH.PARA: The CAA have advised that the process used to select the TAAATS contract was devised with the assistance of two independent international consultants, the Mitre Corporation USA and RATNER associates.
I should not have to tell Senator MacGibbon about the reputation that both those organisations enjoy in the aviation community in respect of air traffic control systems. It continues:
The ROI process was designed to overcome the problems of selection of a contractor based on an operational requirement driven specification.

I support that process. It will yield very beneficial results here as it did in New Zealand. This is a different process from `traditional tendering processes' and was stated to be so from the outset. Therefore, it was well documented. All the selected companies, including Hughes, were advised of the methodology and the likely processes that would be used in the evaluation prior to their participation.

PARA.TAB: A number of claims have been made about irregularities, some of them quite extraordinary and defamatory, in aspects of the process followed by the CAA in relation to this project. There is no evidence to support any of these claims. The CAA commissioned three separate independent audits of the processes followed up to the point where the board made its decision to select Thomson as the preferred contractor.

I understand the need to provide parliamentary committees with all the information that they rightly require—I have been a member of those committees long enough to respect the need to do that—but I also have to face the reality that we are at the beginning of a tender process which has a fair way to run with two contracts. I have some feeling for Hughes in this respect. At this stage, neither the two contractors nor the CAA know at the end of this 18 weeks who will be the successful bidder. Some degree of sensitivity is attached to this, because we do not want this process derailed at the same time as providing this accountability.

In conclusion, I am happy to continue to provide Senator MacGibbon, and indeed all honourable senators in this chamber, with the maximum amount of information that I can. However, I stress that we have an urgent need to provide this country very quickly with a new air traffic control system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to enter into this debate because I have had my opportunity of participating through the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. I have been absent for some time. I was interested to hear what the Minister said about certain people vilifying Mr Edwards and Mr Baldwin. Firstly, I want to know who has done that publicly. Secondly, who did the Minister originally prefer as a tenderer for the—
—Me?
—Yes. What is his particular leaning? He has already said that—
—IBM.
—Exactly. Could the Minister state publicly who the people who are supposed to use these systems, the air traffic controllers, prefer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Calvert for canvassing what he was concerned about and concluding, because now we both know where we stand on this. It will be pursued in the Senate. There is not much point in dealing with it at this hour of the morning, and I am sorry that I have to keep going and respond, but I do want to respond to that.

PARA.TAB: I do not have an involvement ministerially in the selection of this tenderer. As I have pointed out in the Senate before, the people who suggest that I should have some degree of political control would be the first to censure me in here if I did. What I have said, and I am quite happy to repeat here again, is that from my perspective, my concern—I have made it quite open that I have written to the board twice and addressed it personally on the issue—and the great concern of the Australian Government is about the maximum participation of Australian industry in whichever tenderer was successful.

What I said about IBM was that I would have been delighted if on that criterion the CAA had selected IBM because it employs 4,600 Australians. I consider it to be an Australian company; it has been here for 60 years. But the CAA did not select it on technical grounds and for reasons that I do not think even Senator MacGibbon would dispute. That is the question of my so-called preference. I do not have an axe to grind with any of them. All I want to see is a good air traffic control system.

Senator Calvert said by way of interjection that things were terrible in New Zealand and then had to admit—and it will be in the Hansard—that he had been told that; he did not know that. I will tell the honourable senator a bit of background to all this stuff that is being thrown around. Senator O'Chee described in a committee—it is on the Hansard record—the New Zealand system of air traffic control as being—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Chairman. I did not suggest—
—That is not a point of order.
—Order! Senator Calvert, that is not a point of order and you know it is not a point of order. If you wish to make a comment—
—Well, Senator Collins just made an accusation that I said something which I do not believe is what I said.

—Senator Calvert, you know it is not a point of order. From the work that you do in this chamber you know that it is not a point of order. If you wish to make a comment, you can certainly do so after the speaker has finished his contribution.

—I will not attribute it to Senator Calvert. Senator O'Chee made some quite extraordinary statements about the New Zealand air traffic control system. I have been in some dialogue with the New Zealand National Party Minister for Transport, Mr Storey, a person for whom I have great regard. I have found him to be a very reasonable person. He seemed to be very satisfied with the system that he is in charge of. It astonished me when the New Zealand air traffic control system was described as a `horrendous disaster' by Senator O'Chee.

PARA.TAB: I went to New Zealand, had a look at it, and talked to every air traffic controller and technician that I wanted to talk to. They told me in some detail about the glitches that had occurred in the system when it was being commissioned and described them to me in detail. They said that they were delighted with the service Thomson had given. I think they said they had eight engineers present 24 hours a day while the system was being bedded in. Every problem that they had with the software—and no air traffic control system in the world does not have problems with the complicated software when these things are commissioned—was repaired. The controllers expressed themselves totally satisfied with the system. I was told that it had run glitch free for three months.

I went to the Cairns tower. I spoke to the controllers at Cairns and the technicians at the Cairns tower. As I advised the Senate a few weeks ago, because of the tape recording equipment, they captured these incidents. They have analysed the data. They have in fact now prepared new software. All of the testing indicates—and it has been tested now for some three weeks—that they have actually fixed the problem. The new software is now in use in Cairns. It is not operational yet because it has got two more weeks of scrupulous testing to go before it is commissioned, but to this point in time I am happy to advise the Senate that it appears that the problem at Cairns has been fixed, as the controllers and technicians, I might add, told me they were confident it would be.

While I was in Cairns I spoke to the controllers and said, `Look, I have heard all these horrendous stories about problems in New Zealand. I have just been there. If I am being snowed, do the country a service. Go over there and talk to your own colleagues about the system and come back and tell me, please, if there is a problem, because I will chase it up'. They did. Civil Air paid for one of its officers to go to New Zealand. Civil Air representatives came back to me three weeks ago, had a formal meeting with me, which was a meeting of record with departmental officers, and said, whilst expressing their continued personal preference for Hughes, `We went to New Zealand and what you were told is correct: the system is operating excellently; the controllers are happy with it; it is providing a very good air traffic control system for New Zealand'. All I am saying, with respect, is that that is a long way from the `horrendous disaster' that Senator O'Chee was quite happy to describe the New Zealand air traffic control system as being. It is nothing of the sort.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we all want to go to bed, but I cannot let that last comment about the New Zealand system pass without comment. The New Zealand system is working and it is working well. However, the New Zealand system is old-fashioned and very small. It deals with a small geographic area. If one flies 60 miles in a light aircraft in New Zealand one goes a hell of a long way, and one flies at 3,000 feet. In Australia we have hundreds of light aircraft flying for four hours and six hours a day, getting up to 9,000 and 10,000 feet. The whole magnitude of what is involved in New Zealand is several times less than what is involved in Australia. The Minister should put it into perspective. If he is genuinely concerned about getting an air traffic control system into Australia in a hurry, why did he not select Hughes, Raytheon or Siemens Plessey—which would have come in years ahead of Thomson?
—As honourable senators probably realise, Senator Collins was confused between Senator O'Chee and me.
—Goodness me!

—I am sorry. He talked about `horrendous disasters' and other things which I was supposed to have said—which I did not. I made only one point by way of interjection. When Senator Collins said that New Zealand was working well and was glitch free, I interjected, `That is not true'.
—Senator MacGibbon just confirmed it.

—That is not true. That is not the evidence that I heard from people who have been involved. I return to the question that I asked Senator Collins originally. He said that Mr Edwards and Mr Baldwin had been vilified in the press. I asked: by whom? He has not answered that question. I would like to know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I would be quite happy to get the newspaper article—
—Don't you know?
—There have been a very large number and it is very early in the morning. I will get it.
—Why don't you know?

—Will you let me answer the bloody question? I regret to say that I have been involved in three defamation actions in the 15 years that I have been in politics. Unfortunately, defamation law is something I know more about than I want to.
—It might have something to do with your attitude.
—My godfather! I will be brief if I am allowed to be brief.
—Have you ever been defamed, Shirley?
—No, not in 17 years.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, you are not helping—nor is Senator Walters.

—I am perfectly happy to provide Senator Calvert with the newspaper article which named both of the officers and, in fact, misspelt one of their names. In my view, the article was defamatory. I would be very surprised—I have not spoken to them about it—if they have not taken legal advice on it. I am happy to provide Senator Calvert with a copy of the newspaper article.
—Are you saying that they were vilified by the media?
—Yes, I said that.

—Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. I did not interrupt the Minister when he was speaking, but he used the word `bloody'. I know that it is in the English dictionary as a part which goes through our body. Senator Collins used it as a profanity in the chamber. He should withdraw that remark.
—Considering it was applied to Senator Walters, it was very restrained.
—Order! I heard the comment but I deliberately ignored it because that meant it would not go in the Hansard. Now that it has been raised, it will be in the Hansard.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, that sort of comment does not help at all. We had been having a great time from 8.00 o'clock until about half an hour ago.
—Mr Chairman, I am deeply sorry that Senator Brownhill went into a faint at my use of that word. I withdraw it.

—I think it is appropriate at this stage to get something very clear. Senator Collins is trying to tell the Committee that air traffic controllers in New Zealand are perfectly happy with the system that they have. That is the impression that Senator Collins is trying to give us. I think Senator Calvert is clearly under a very different impression as a result of the inquiries which have been undertaken by the Joint Committee on Public Works. Senator Calvert says that the Minister claimed that it was glitch free. That is certainly not the case.

PARA.TAB: The air traffic controllers in New Zealand may be pleased to have a radar based air traffic control system as opposed to an air traffic control system based on procedural separation, but that clearly does not mean that they are totally happy with the Thomson system. It certainly does not mean that they are delighted—I think that was a word that I heard the Minister say when I was in my office—with the Thomson system. All it means is that they are happier to have some sort of radar system than to have to use procedural separation.

But the argument that Senator MacGibbon has been so aptly and clearly making this evening ad infinitum, because it seems to be almost impossible to get it through the Minister's skull, is that, whilst a radar system is better than no radar system, we are seeking to have the best radar system. All Senator MacGibbon has been doing through the course of this very difficult debate, because the Minister has been deliberately uncooperative, is trying to get the best possible radar system. This Minister on the other side of the chamber is not interested in that. He wants to try to snow the Senate. Either he is trying to snow the Senate or he has been snowed. In either case, it does the Minister no justice at all, and maybe the Minister ought to start being a little more deliberate with the truth.

—It was late. It didn't work.

—The system was delivered on time, on budget and, as the controllers themselves told me, it has worked without a problem for three months. Senator MacGibbon in fact confirmed it. But Senator O'Chee has just compounded his problem. That is why I have risen again. He has come in here absolutely clothed in ignorance on this subject, and he has just thrown another piece of nonsense into the wind here tonight. He said that the air traffic controllers in New Zealand—
—You are looking very silly. If something is clothed in ignorance—
—Order!

—Calm down, Chicken Little. The sky is going to fall in on Senator O'Chee right now. The statement made by Senator O'Chee, this self-appointed expert on air traffic control systems, that the national air traffic control system in New Zealand is an horrendous disaster is such a total piece of nonsense that I commend to him that he consult with his National Party colleague the New Zealand Minister for Transport, who is in charge of that system, and ask him what the New Zealand National Party Government thinks of that system.

PARA.TAB: But that was not a bad enough piece of nonsense. Senator O'Chee delivered an unbelievable piece a minute ago. He said that the New Zealand air traffic controllers were very glad to have any kind of air traffic control system so they did not have to use the procedural separation that they had had to use before it arrived, unlike Australia. I have to tell Senator O'Chee, in terms of his statement that procedural control was used in New Zealand before the Thomson system, that New Zealand had radar air traffic control in 1959, before Australia had it.

TALK.START.PARA: —If anybody is going to get clothed in ignorance, Senator Collins is a prime candidate. He needs more ignorance to clothe him than anybody on this side of the chamber. But we are getting a little sick and tired of the way the Minister always likes to skirt around the issue and use personal vilification. Everybody on this side of the chamber has been pursuing this for a long period with considerable exasperation.

PARA.TAB: While we have some officers of the CAA here, let us get this very clear. Whilst Dr Edwards has made considerable efforts to answer some of the matters raised at our briefing, I remind the officers of the CAA that I have not had complete answers to my requests. For example, all of the information that Mr Roser promised me in relation to the operational guidelines in force at Cairns and all of the operational guidelines in relation to the use of radar for procedural separation and so on, which were promised to me weeks and weeks ago—and I have been very patient—have not been forthcoming. I notice Dr Edwards is over there. Dr Edwards and Mr Baldwin know that the matter is on tape in my office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you mind addressing your remarks to me, Senator. It is more courteous.
—Through the chair.

—I am not actually talking to the officers. Perhaps Senator Faulkner is incapable of understanding that. I am making a point that these officers know about the matter. Perhaps if Senator Faulkner concentrated more on the debate and less on trying to interject, we might actually get on a little faster. I am saying very clearly that these are the facts. There are points which the officers have not dealt with that we on this side of the chamber have been unwilling to use to hinder the Appropriations, but these are matters which we still want answered. That is a perfectly reasonable request.

PARA.TAB: Mr Chairman, you were there that night. You participated in the briefing, as did Senator Reynolds, out of the same genuine sense of concern at what was happening. It is not unreasonable to expect that those requests would be answered. That was the undertaking. I am again relying on the good grace of the officers to do so. I do not intend to hold up the Appropriations until the material gets delivered in the middle of the night and have never had any intention of doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —If not, why not?

—If I was as obstreperous as some of the honourable senators on the Government side, perhaps I would be so inclined. Unfortunately, we on this side are sometimes too good for our own benefit. We are interested in getting the best that we possibly can for the people who use the air system of this nation. That is why we will not be delaying the Committee any further tonight. Let us make it perfectly clear that we would like those questions answered.

—I make a plea to both sides of the chamber to be less provocative, because if we are provocative we will still be on program 1 in another half an hour. If we are finished with program 1, we now move onto general questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret the lateness of the hour. I welcome the opportunity afforded to me by Senator Knowles in her adjournment speech of last evening to respond to some of her concerns regarding the document I tabled on 27 May. I would first like to remind Senator Knowles of the context in which I tabled that document. My speech was supporting the ministerial motion on the occasion of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the referendum in which Aboriginal people gained the nominal rights of citizenship. I expressed a deep concern that 25 years have not achieved great progress for Aboriginal people. The racist basis on which this country was founded, namely, that of white supremacy and ownership of land regardless of the sovereignty of its indigenous people, has certainly not been eradicated from the attitudes and actions of our society to date.

PARA.TAB: The extremely serious problem of racist violence is still disturbingly active. I believe that racism is institutionalised in our society. It is reflected in our over-imprisonment of Aboriginal people; in the denial of adequate services in relation to health, housing and clothing; and, above all, in the failure to grant them rights of ownership over their own land.

The responsibility for this does not lie at the doorstep of any one individual; each one of us must evaluate whether our actions contribute towards or attempt to challenge that institutionalised racism. In this context, I address the small component of this dysfunction in our community: the influence of talkback radio. The report Gambling on the First Race: A Comment on Racism and Talk-Back Radio—6PR, the TAB and the WA Government was written by Steve Mickler, a PhD student at Murdoch University who has 10 years of involvement with Aboriginal affairs, both in Western Australia and the Northern Territory, and the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.

The study, which was done in conjunction with research associates Dr John Hartley, Dr Alec McHoul, Dr Alan Mansfield and Dr Tom O'Regan, emanated from the Centre for Research in Culture and Communication at Murdoch University. It was commissioned, published and paid for entirely by the Louis St John Johnson Memorial Trust Fund, set up by Mr Bill Johnson, whose son Louis was tragically killed in an act of racist violence. It has not taken one cent of taxpayers' money, which was a point about which Senator Knowles expressed concern last night.

Mr Mickler's report is a credible and legitimate critique of Howard Sattler's broadcasting style. It expresses in a clear and objective way the techniques and style of Mr Sattler's media performance, which have succeeded in alienating many Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal listeners. It is inappropriate for Mr Sattler to be outraged at his lack of right of reply when he has public access three hours per day, five days per week and a newspaper column.

In tabling the report, I believe I was fulfilling my democratic right to give voice to people's concerns and to endeavour to ensure Mr Sattler gives those views the attention they deserve. The fact that he is upset is a gratifying indication that he realises the seriousness of the criticisms. Mr Sattler's distress that, in his view he was being misunderstood, may give him an inkling of how many people who have been on the receiving end of his interviewing techniques have felt. In my opinion, the more positive attempts he makes to disprove accusations of inciting racism, the better it will be for public broadcasting.

My radio interview on Howard Sattler's program on Friday, 28 May, which I believe Senator Knowles heard, represented a cameo performance which encapsulated all the criticisms contained in the Mickler report. Howard Sattler attempted to discredit me personally and devalue my views before, during and after my interview. References to the `unelected senator—nobody you voted for' need to be questioned not on their accuracy but on their motivation.

A selective approach to the issues under discussion and an attempt to defend his own views led to a failure to listen or give a fair hearing to my opposing view. Cutting through and overplaying—the technology of having a separate channel so that he could interrupt halfway through my sentences—is also a technique that has been referred to in Mr Mickler's report; as was his continual interruption and arguing with me, in contrast to the non-interruption and positive feedback to callers with whom he usually does agree. Finally, he incited his supporters to ring my office and provided phone numbers for their benefit such that the phones rang constantly for a couple of hours. A tally of the calls revealed that 40 per cent of the callers he incited actually rang up in support of my position and to state a position for the people who could not otherwise be heard on his program.

One of the problems of both racism and sexism is that very few people are consciously or deliberately racist or sexist. A common sign of racism or sexism is an angry, defensive response which refuses to acknowledge any validity to the criticism or to be concerned at any damage that may have occurred as a result of expressed views and behaviours.

The notorious comment `Good riddance to bad rubbish' on the death of three young car thieves deserves some mention here. It is personally irrelevant to me whether Howard Sattler knew the race of the children or not. I find it outrageous that people speak that way of any human being, regardless of race. The Mickler report points out that it is a red herring for Howard Sattler to plead that he did not know that the race of the car thieves he referred to as `bad rubbish' was Aboriginal, for, according to Mickler, in Perth at this period the image of three kids in a stolen Commodore presumes them to be Aboriginal unless otherwise stated.

Even if Howard Sattler did not understand it, the people in the public domain certainly did. A meeting of over 100 Aboriginal people two days later called on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to suspend Sattler from broadcasting and to carry out an inquiry into his comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the result of that?

—I am proceeding to that report and I would like to refer first to the complaints that were written in. These comments have distressed and outraged a great many Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people in our community. Some have commented that it is the worst breach of journalistic ethics ever, not to mention the callous absence of common decency. Apart from the enormous pain that these sort of statements caused family and friends of the children who died, they have the effect of inciting racial hatred, given that people in Perth were becoming aware that those who died were Aboriginal.

PARA.TAB: The reference to people as `bad rubbish' is strikingly similar to language used by racists to describe the ethnic minorities that are the objects of their hatred. For example, the Nazis called the Jews vermin. Although Howard Sattler did not identify the race of the children involved in the tragedy, the intent of his comments is no less deplorable and the effects no less dangerous and distressing.

Thirty-one out of 40 complaints to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal between 1987 and 1991 concerned Sattler. None of these were upheld as breaching program standards. Mr Sattler may take refuge in these findings; nevertheless, the alternative view may also be expressed: that the test applied was at too high a level. I would like to quote from page 35 of this report. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal states:

SPEECH.PARA: We find that each of the broadcasts in question was tasteless and likely to have been highly offensive to a significant number of listeners and, in particular, Aboriginal listeners. After careful consideration of the material available to us however, we find that the broadcasts do not satisfy the high test which we believe the word vilification imposes. Having found this, it was not necessary for us to consider the question of whether the vilification was gratuitous.
The report continues—
It appears to us that Mr Sattler has a controversial style of broadcasting which accounts for the regularity and frequency of the complaints elicited by the Sattler file.

Sattler is not the only Perth radio broadcaster to have attracted criticism for treatment of issues involving Aboriginal people. Peter Newman of 6PR, Eoin Cameron, Gary Shannon, John K. Watts and Barry Martin have also been the subjects of either complaints to the ABT or of critical analysis. Nor is the print media exempt. The West Australian was unsuccessfully reported to the Press Council for the gang story mentioned earlier in this chapter. The report again states:

In my opinion, Sattler's comments were clearly made as part of a long history of widespread anti-Aboriginal media pressure against which the regulatory authorities have proved to be completely powerless.

I have no wish to cite many examples of concerns expressed in the Mickler report. Instead, I urge people to read and critique this document's validity for themselves. There is a need for the highest accountability possible in public broadcasting. Any attempt to offer a critique needs to be accepted in the spirit of freedom of speech and democracy, to which Senator Knowles made such frequent reference in her speech. Freedom of speech should weigh up the good of the community against the good of a few. Freedom of speech should not threaten the reality of a cohesive community. One should weigh up how divisive and how hurtful something is and whether it is an incitement to racial hatred. There are many examples in this report of how hurtful Mr Sattler's comments and style have been to members of our community.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I wish to state that there are other broadcasters who also receive criticism in this report. There are also those who have been commended, who have demonstrated greater objectivity and respect for diverse opinions. A 1984 study is cited on the different styles of the ABC's Des Guilfoyle and 6KY's Eoin Cameron. There are also broadcasters who do not receive a mention—some from 6PR, Mr Sattler's own station—who have actively tried to present a fair and compassionate hearing to their listeners. Two who are known to me and respected by me are Mr Graham Mabury and Miss Stephanie Woods.

The aim of the report and of my raising it in this Parliament is to encourage people with such a high responsibility of public broadcasting to ensure that their standards are at the highest possible level. For Senator Knowles to consider that a request for a non-racist, non-discriminatory policy in broadcasting constitutes a crude demand for political censorship is absolutely astounding to me. I make no apology to Howard Sattler, to 6PR or to Senator Knowles. If Howard Sattler and Senator Knowles have the right to express strong opinions, so do I and so do the people who find Howard Sattler's style highly objectionable and inciting fearfulness and racist attitudes. I am flattered that all the contents of the report are being attributed to me just because I agree with it and find it useful. The report speaks for itself and should be regarded as a valuable addition to a debate on constructive community attitudes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let Senator Chamarette's further attack on freedom of speech go unanswered tonight. I cannot believe that Senator Chamarette can come in here and make a double-barrelled attack after the lack of foundation that she displayed last week when she admitted that she had never even listened to Mr Sattler's program. How can she be a judge of what he does or does not do? I would question Senator Chamarette's ability to judge a lot of things. She is a good judge about making the whole Senate sit here late at night—unfortunately she is not listening.

PARA.TAB: We should recall last Thursday evening when Senator Chamarette—again, she is not listening—voted at 10.32 p.m. for the whole of the Senate to remain in session and then promptly went home. She decided that she was going to absent herself from the Senate. There were four divisions—one at 12.04 a.m., one at 12.32 a.m., one at 1.08 a.m. and one at 1.36 a.m. Where was Senator Chamarette? She was tucked up in her cot at home, having voted for the Senate to remain here in session. If Senator Chamarette believes that that is a responsible attitude for a person who, as Mr Sattler quite rightly said last Friday, is an unelected senator in this chamber, then I'll go he.

Again, we have to look at Senator Chamarette's performance today. Given what she said last week in relation to the whole issue of racism, Radio 6PR and Mr Sattler and about wanting a clean and above-board structure on everything, it is interesting to look at the way she voted today—or yesterday afternoon, as it is now 1.15 a.m.—when there was a vote for a judicial inquiry into the Marshall Islands affair. An inquiry would get the whole thing out in the open so that the whole of Australia would know what happened in the Marshall Islands affair—the involvement of Senator Richardson, the involvement of Senator Evans, the involvement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and anybody else who might have been involved. What happened? We had a division. Where was Senator Chamarette? She lined up against the judicial inquiry because she does not want the truth to be exposed.

Senator Chamarette came in here again tonight and said, `We've got to enforce morality'—her kind of morality, whatever kind that is; I do not know and it is not up to me to judge. But what I do know is that her attack on a person who has the right to freedom of speech is just untenable. Yes, Mr Sattler does have a right of reply. Senator Chamarette has been here for only five minutes plus 30 seconds, in real terms; maybe she will find out one day that people who are attacked in this chamber have a right of reply and that maybe Mr Sattler will exercise that right of reply.

However, I just want to put a few other things on the record because I alluded to them in general terms last night. I think it is important that the radio station in question is defended from the point of view of what it has done for Aboriginal people. These are but some of the things that Senator Chamarette has chosen willingly and intentionally to ignore, even though Mr Sattler pointed them out to her in the interview, the tape of which I had the misfortune to hear on Saturday. Radio 6PR's views on Aboriginal issues, I think, have been very high.

First and foremost, for the past 12 months 6PR has been conducting talks with the Western Australian Aboriginal Media Association, following its offer to that Association to train three of its cadets in year-long traineeships on all aspects of commercial radio. Following more recent negotiations, also involving the Department of Employment, Education and Training, this plan looks like coming to fruition within the next few weeks. This will mean that three Aboriginal media cadets will spend a year at the station learning all aspects of its operation. What a strange position for a racist radio station to take!

Secondly, 6PR was recently made aware of a young Aboriginal footballer, attached to one of the local Western Australian National Football League clubs, who cannot read or write. The station, after being approached by the club involved, agreed to assist with the young man's special education program. What a strange reaction for a radio station that Senator Chamarette alleges to be racist!

Thirdly, Victor Patrick, a disabled Aboriginal health worker, was recently invited to attend a health conference in Canada for indigenous people, but was unable to gain funding from any Aboriginal body he approached for assistance. He then telephoned the Sattler File. Within four hours the required funding of $2,000 had been raised to enable Victor to travel to Canada. What a strange reaction from a racist radio station and a racist broadcaster! In four hours of Mr Sattler's program, he had raised the money to enable Victor go to Canada.

Fourthly, ongoing discussions have taken place with Phillip Moncrieff, Director of the Western Australian Aboriginal Media Association, regarding the possibility of setting up a group of Aboriginal spokespersons on whom 6PR's programs could call for informed comment when various Aboriginal issues were raised on air. Phillip has almost completed establishing a group of six spokespersons who would be prepared to participate, and a get-together with them is planned shortly. What a strange reaction for a racist radio station!

There are many other examples of what radio 6PR and Mr Sattler have been doing for the Aboriginal communities. What people like Senator Chamarette do is discredit the Aboriginal communities, which, as I said last night, do not associate themselves with the nonsense that Senator Chamarette has been going on about; they want to stand up and be counted and want to be judged for their own actions. They do not want some do-gooder saying, `Oh, because they did that and they are Aboriginal they must be forgiven'. The Aboriginal communities themselves do not want that sort of attitude. They want to be held responsible for their own actions.

The continued attack on both 6PR and Mr Sattler is amazing. Senator Chamarette said that it was amazing that Mr Sattler was upset. I think I would be pretty upset too if I were doing the things that Mr Sattler and Radio 6PR are doing and Senator Chamarette in the Senate under parliamentary privilege twice gave me a bagging for doing them and on neither occasion recognised the work that I was doing.

I think that is quite despicable. There was an opportunity tonight, if that had been overlooked by Senator Chamarette, for her to have recognised some of that good work, but she deliberately chose not to yet again.

Senator Chamarette then said that, in the way in which Mr Sattler interviewed her on Friday, he attempted to discredit her; that he called her an unelected senator; and so forth and so on. That is quite right; that is just stating the fact. If there is something offensive about stating fact, if the honourable senator once again wants to gag freedom of speech by saying that he should not for some reason say she is unelected because she finds that hurtful or offensive, why not say so? It is absolutely amazing. Senator Chamarette felt she was not given a fair go on Friday. Is it any wonder? The evidence was actually stacked up against the nonsense she had spoken earlier in the week.

Senator Chamarette fell into the trap yet again when referring to the `good riddance to bad rubbish' statement that Mr Sattler made. Of course, Senator Chamarette had to go one stage further tonight by saying it was irrelevant that Mr Sattler did not know at the time of making that statement that the people were Aboriginal. I do not think that that is irrelevant at all when subsequently Senator Chamarette and others have accused him of being racist by making the statement in the first place. Senator Chamarette knows that that was not known to Mr Sattler when he made that comment, yet once again tonight she has accused him of doing that.

She then said that everyone presumed them to be Aboriginal. Obviously, Senator Chamarette's crystal ball is still in good working order because I cannot tell, and I do not believe anyone else can tell, what was in the minds of the people in radio land who listened to that comment as to whether they presumed that they were Aboriginal. I find that extraordinary.

To substantiate that, Senator Chamarette said that there was a meeting of 100 Aboriginals the next day to protest at the fact that the statement was obviously directed towards Aboriginals. Of course, Senator Chamarette does not say that not long after that there was a meeting in Western Australia of not 100 citizens but 30,000 citizens who marched on the State Parliament House asking for tougher penalties for juvenile offenders. Whether they be black, white, blue or brindle mattered not. But here we have Senator Chamarette saying, `But 100 Aboriginals protested about the statement that Mr Sattler made because everyone presumed that he was referring to Aboriginals'. Senator Chamarette said that someone had said that Mr Sattler's comments were tasteless and perhaps were highly offensive—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

—It might say that, Senator Chamarette might say that, I might say that, and a whole lot of other people might say that; but if they all believe that, they will go flick with the switch and turn him off. But they have not: he is still very much a high rating broadcaster in Western Australia. If all those people think the way Senator Chamarette thinks, I do not know why he is still on air.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette could not resist the temptation to go on and name a few other broadcasters she would like to gag. Of course, one broadcaster I would like to defend up hill and down dale is a very good friend—Eoin Cameron, who is anything but a racist. Having known Eoin Cameron for many years, I know for a fact that he is not a racist. We have a whole lot of other names such as Peter Newman and Gary Shannon. I could not write fast enough to get all the names down. They have all been drawn into the net. I suppose Senator Chamarette will turn around and say, `I do not listen to Eoin Cameron either' or `I do not listen to Gary Shannon either'. I suppose that is the reality of it. Because Senator Chamarette is told that someone has made a racial comment, she immediately has them categorised as racist.

I think that what we really have to do with this whole thing is look at the whole allegations of racism, look at the whole desire to gag people and the abolition of freedom of speech—unless it is Senator Chamarette's freedom of speech under parliamentary privilege—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or yours.

—I am quite happy to go outside and say the things that I am saying, but I will bet London to a brick on that she is not prepared to go outside and say a lot of the things that she has said in this place.
—I have been saying it for 10 years.

—It would be a jolly good idea if Senator Chamarette did go out, and then she could test the letter of the law. Some of the things that she has been saying in here she would not be game to repeat outside the building. So therefore I think that the ongoing allegations of racism against 6PR really date back some time to when Mr Howard made that original statement.

PARA.TAB: As I said last night, let us not be mistaken in my defence of Mr Sattler or radio 6PR. If Senator Chamarette ever bothered to tune into 6PR or Mr Sattler, she would know full well that he is controversial. He is no real friend of the Liberal Party or the National Party at all, so I am not defending a friend in the political term; I am simply defending the right of a person to speak his mind and the right to freedom of speech, and not have some politician go into any parliament and seek to politically control what goes over the airwaves. That is entirely up to the listeners to decide. If they do not want him to be on air, or they do not want any other broadcaster to be on air, that broadcaster will be taken off.
We must remember that the ABT has never upheld any allegation against Mr Sattler, so it is quite improper of Senator Chamarette

SPEECH.PARA: to come into this place and cast the doubt that all these things have been taken into the ABT and that by that measure he must therefore be guilty. He has never once been found guilty. I suppose it is a bit like beauty; it is in the eye of the beholder. If Senator Chamarette is wanting to find fault, she will find fault, purely and simply because it has been taken to the ABT.

TALK.START.PARA: —And keep on not listening.

—And keep on not listening. I think that Mr Sattler's greatest asset at the moment is that Senator Chamarette does not listen to the program. What we must do as a parliament, and what we must do as parliamentarians, is ensure that we uphold freedom of speech at any cost.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Meat Inspection Act—Meat Inspection (Orders) Regulations—Orders 1992 No. 1—Meat Inspection (New South Wales) (Amendment).
The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 10 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the vast tracts of land studded with landmines in Cambodia and the consequent danger to the population and also to Australian troops who form part of the United Nations peace-keeping force in that country, is Australia involved in action to clear the Cambodian mine fields; if so: (a) what will be the cost of this action to Australia; (b) will Australian personnel be involved; (c) has an Australian company been contracted for this task; and (d) has the United Nations requested assistance from this country to clear Cambodian mine fields.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The agreements on a comprehensive settlement of the Cambodian conflict signed in October 1991 accord a high priority to mine-clearance and associated training programs as an essential component of the settlement implementation process. The agreements provide for mine-clearance and training operations to be coordinated and supervised by trained personnel of the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC).
Australia is only involved indirectly in the clearing of the minefields in Cambodia.

(a) Australia has contributed AUD 2.2 million to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) for the repatriation program, part of which will be concerned with mine-clearance activities and mine-awareness education programs. Mine-clearance is a crucial concern for the UNHCR which has responsibility for the repatriation of the 350,000 Cambodians in displaced persons camps in Thailand and their resettlement on mine-free land in Cambodia.
(b) Australian Defence Force personnel working with United Nations peacekeeping forces in Cambodia have not been, nor will be, directly involved in mine-clearance activities.
(c) A number of Australian companies have indicated their interest in mine-clearance activities, but to date no Australian company has been contracted by the United Nations for this task.
(d) The UN has not requested assistance from Australia in mine-clearance operations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 29 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What support has the Australian Government provided to the efforts by the European Community and the United Nations aimed at finding a peaceful solution to the dispute over recognition of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.
(2) Has the Australian Government informed parties to the dispute of the need to protect the fundamental human rights of minorities as set out in numerous international conventions.
(3) Has the Government of Greece imposed an economic and trade blockade along its border with the Republic currently known as Macedonia.
(4) What has been the impact of this blockade on the people living in that region of the Balkans.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australia, like the European Community, has expressed its willingness to recognise the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia when all outstanding issues, including the issue of the name of the state, have been settled. We have encouraged the EC to work strenuously to resolve this matter and we will continue to do so.

(2) Australia's commitment to the universal observance of internationally accepted human rights standards and its active support for the promotion and protection of human rights throughout the world are well-known and need no elaboration. In discussions with representatives and officials from the Balkan region we have regularly raised human rights concerns. We would support appropriate international action to address human rights problems in the region.

(3) From the limited information available to us, we understand that administrative procedures being implemented by Greek border authorities, combined with the political instability in the region as a whole, have had the effect of hampering normal road traffic between Greece and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.

(4) The conflict in the region and the disruption of past administrative and transport arrangements has contributed to downturn in trade and in economic activity in the Balkan region. This situation is having an adverse impact on the living standard of the people throughout the region. The people of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia are bearing a considerable burden in this regard.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations Conference on the Environment and Development

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 29 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister sought to confirm or deny allegations that the "street kids" of Rio de Janeiro are being killed by police and others in authority in order to present a "clean" image to countries attending the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED) in June 1992; if so, what has been the response; if not, why not.
(2) If a response confirms the allegations, will the Minister raise the issue at UNCED; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Government is aware of reports that street children in Rio de Janeiro are being killed as part of a campaign to reduce crime in the city before the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development takes place in June this year. The Government views these reports and other allegations of human rights violations in Brazil with concern.

Australia has raised human rights issues with the Brazilian Government on a number of occasions, and during my visit to Brazil in March this year, I expressed to the Brazilian President the Australian Government's concern that human rights, including those of children, should be respected and appropriate action taken when allegations are made that these rights have been violated. President Collor assured me that he was very concerned about the situation with respect to street children and that his Government was doing its best to rectify it.

(2) Whilst the Government will consider whether this issue might usefully be raised at UNCED, there are existing channels which have already proved to be effective for bringing human rights issues of concern to the attention of the Brazilian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 6 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did Australian Government representatives attend a meeting in April 1992 of the Standing Committee on Nuclear Issues of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna; if so, did these representatives support moves to tighten the liability regime which covers the nuclear industry.

(2) In the light of recent accidents in the Republic of Russia and the enormous cost associated with refitting nuclear reactors, what is the Australian Government's view on the continued use of these reactors.
(3) What help has Australia offered Russia on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australian representatives attended a meeting of the International Atomic Energy Agency's Standing Committee On Liability For Nuclear Damage from 30 March to 3 April 1992.
As at the earlier meetings of the Standing Committee, they firmly supported the development of an improved regime covering international nuclear liability arrangements.

(2) The Australian Government is naturally concerned when nuclear incidents or accidents occur and attaches great importance to the maintenance of the highest standards of nuclear safety in nuclear establishments wherever they are located. I emphasised this in my address to the General Conference of the IAEA in September 1991, noting Australia's view that nuclear safety was not a matter that could be left to individual states alone.

With regard to the continued use of power reactors in Russia, a major international cooperative effort has been mounted to improve the operational safety of older reactors in that country and similar models elsewhere in Central and Eastern Europe. With the full cooperation of the Russian and other governments concerned, this work has involved the IAEA, the OECD Nuclear Energy Agency (NEA), other international organisations, members of the EC and other western countries. Australia very much welcomes the priority being given to this activity.

(3) Australia is not in a position to provide direct bilateral technical help to Russia on this matter but Australia, as a member of the IAEA and OECD NEA, has supported programs assisting Russia and Australian officials have participated in international meetings dealing with the issue.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations Conference on the Environment and Development

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, upon notice, on 12 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: What is the expected cost of: (a) airfares; (b) travel allowance; (c) accommodation; and (d) other associated expenses, incurred by the Minister, his/her personnel, department and security staff, in the course of travelling to and from, and attending, the United Nations Conference on the Environment and Development in Rio de Janeiro in June 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Overseas Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: These figures represent the estimated costs expected to be incurred by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, his one staff member, the Ambassador for the Environment (and Lady Stephen), and five officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade travelling to Rio de Janeiro from Australia and a further nine officers from Australian missions overseas.
Item (d) includes the cost of establishing and maintaining two delegation offices in Rio de Janeiro, much of which will be recouped from other Government departments and agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Tourism, upon notice, on 12 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the total amount of the department's Telecom account for the financial years 1989-90 and 1990-91.

(2) What was the total amount of the department's Telecom account for the following months: (a) June 1991; (b) July 1991; (c) August 1991; (d) September 1991; (e) October 1991; (f) November 1991; (g) December 1991; (h) January 1992; (i) February 1992; and (j) March 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Nil.

(2) The Department of Tourism was established on 27 December 1991. For the period January to March 1992 expenditure on Telecom services for this Department was incorporated into the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (DASET) account. The requested information is included in the DASET response.
